Market extrordinaire. This is a no miss! Fabulous blend of food and craftspeople. Bought some lovely souvenirs and gifts for the trip home. Ate many yummy snacks and heard some fab music!

Well worth a visit. I would definitely recommend taking a morning or afternoon out of your Cape Town trip to visit Woodstock, a former industrial district that has recently seen a surge of restaurants, stores and creative spaces opening up in its abandoned warehouses and buildings. The Old Biscuit Mill is at the heart of Woodstock's rejuvenation and home to vibrant market stalls, studios, boutiques and fashionable eateries like The Pot Luck Club and The Test Kitchen.
a must to visit. I live in Woodstock Cape Town so the Biscuit Mill is practically on my door step what a gem in my area

Go here on Saturday-- well worth the trip. There are eclectic shops here in this converted mill, and they and the Test Kitchen and Pot Luck City are worth a visit anytime( good luck getting reservations at either restaurant, but especially the Test Kitchen)-- but why wait for fabulous food, when every Saturday, stalls here are filled with vendors of such things as tuna chilli flavored bill tong, pancakes, baked goods, fresh juices and smoothies, alcoholic cocktail creations, rice balls with truffles, potato latkes loaded with toppings, amazing artisan chocolates and brittles, stir fried dishes, stuffed sandwiches, amazing mushroom kebabs, dressings, jams, honeys, dried organic fruits and every other delectable food, dessert candy and drink that coul ever strike your fancy. The sounds and smells here are amazing, and large groups meet here to roam around and then eat at communal tables inside or on tree stumps and other makeshift seats outdoors. Talk about a vibrant place to enjoy this city of beauty and contrast while gobbling up some of the most delicious foods available anywhere. Unparalleled greatness in Cape Town!

Do not miss this!. My absolute favorite thing to do while traveling is go to local markets. This one was a blast. Lots of great crafts, delicious food and wonderful atmosphere. This was the highlight of my trip!

Nice place for tourists. Nice place, full of people and of the best food of South Africa and the rest of the world.Expensive, but you'll have a nice moment. Advice: draw money before you go. The queue at the only ATM is endless. Draw maybe R200-R300 per person.

Go hungry. We thought we were going to this market to view the local artisans and their products. They were there for sure. But the main attractions are the food stalls. We had breakfast before we went there and we were sorry we could not eat any of the array of multiple types of foods on sale there. Everything looked and smelled delicious. We could appreciate that most of the people eating there were locals, which is always a good indicator. Go there hungry.

My favourite Saturday morning hang out!. I just love the Biscuit Mill! Whether you are looking for an interesting breakfast or brunch/lunch dishes, coffee, a new craft beer/cider or boutique wine, crepes, smoothies, pastries - there is something for everyone's taste!And then you can go shopping with a super selection of crockery, clothing, jewellery, art and souvenirs.Just hold on tight to your children's hands as it can get rather full by mid morning!

Great experience and vibe!. Lovely locally brewed beers and others. Had first ginger beer made from Thai ginger that ferments into alcohol. Awesome. Also had a beautiful stout, almost smooth like Guinness there. Lovely chilled, yet busy vibe for a Saturday. All the markets and variety was lovely. Reminded me a little of the Plett/Harkerville Saturday morning markets (just larger scale). Think PE also now has a similar one at the Bridge Street Brewery. But it’s similar to the Foodshed festivals once a month, but in the day! Lovely experience indeed.

Great Food + Crafts Market. The Old Biscuit Mill is a has a huge range of food stalls and stores. You can probably find almost anything here, but most people come for the delicious food. This market is upscale and is clearly targeted for a certain type of audience, a large number of whom are tourists. This food is a little on the pricier side but includes rare and artisanal foods that are all very delicious. We ate everything from veggie sandwiches and springbok jerky to artisanal bread and pizza. However, one should keep in mind the type of market Old Biscuit Mill aims to be and who this space welcomes and who it excludes. With all this in mind, Old Biscuit Mill is still great place to spend a Saturday morning walking around, eating and shopping.

Saturday Market. The Saturday market has such atmosphere,lots of samples and great food and drinks to purchase. Go early otherwise really crowded.You might have to park a while away,but worth the visit.

Saturday morning at biscuit mill. Always great to visit the biscuit mill and sample all the home made scrumptious food and drink. If you're early there's not too many people else it gets really full and you won't get what you really want

Okay stables, okay food. I have been here about four times. Never got what the fuss was about. It's just okay. Very crowded,and difficult to manoeuvre around. Sometimes cant find a seat after purchasing items. Recommended if you have absolutely nothing to do on a Saturday( when the market comes round). Without the market on Saturday, its quite boring little place. If your into highly crowded Saturday morning venues go for it! Parking can be a nightmare, so don't be surprised if your car gets side swiped.

A great place to shop and eat. We visited the Mill on a Saturday morning. After shopping at many boutiques and stands with very favorable pricing, we entered a large open air eating area with well more than one hundred vendors and long dining tables. This is the palace to go

A must when in Cape Town.. If you enjoy food markets then this is the place for you. We are so happy to check this place out on a Saturday morning while we were in Cape Town. Go hungry! Amazing food, produce, flowers, beer, and wine. Must stop by the Test Kitchen stand and get there breakfast. Delicious!

Lekker, Festive. Vibey, extremely Tasty Joint. What a find. I've been to a few laces around the world (Loved Chelsea Market in New York City) but what a local find this was. A lovely morning - event bough it was cold and wet - exploring the shops, the creativity and especially all of the tasty food and drink. Definitely worth a visit on market day (Saturday)

Upgrading ancient industry. Whilst visiting Cape Town regularly, only recently I became aware of the area of Woodstock, just east of the city centre, developing as the trendy place of this metropolis. This former (and still) mainly industrial area is rapidly upgrading, with trendy shops, restaurants and cafes going there.Old Biscuit Mill is the focal point of the area. It is indeed a lovely and very tasteful upgrade of this old industrial complex. Being the first, it has attracted a nice selection of outlets. Really worth a visit. But ... very much at risk being overrated. I had a look at the Test Kitchen restaurant, a place where in the meantime you have to book 6 months in advance. At least it did not look spectacular, nothing like similarly reputed establishments I know in Europe. But, the chef's philosophy is very interesting, it seems his success is well deserved.Most of Albert Road still is industrial, as a whole the area is nothing I would expect from a vibrant upcoming hotspot. But property prices go high, so maybe in a year all will be different.

Love this place!. It wasn't our first time at the Neighbourgoods market in CT but this place never fails to disappoint! Even though the weather was overcast and drizzly, the place was packed and so vibey. The live music was awesome and added to the lively atmosphere and oh, the stalls! So much variety...from food, to clothing to gifts, beer, wine and everything in between! Not a bargain hunting kind a place but a must-go-to when you're in the area and if you love the outdoorsy-market type venues.
A Feast for the Senses. Fantastic market with the most delicious food, high quality food stalls, great beer and interesting goods

Incredible food-Worth the visit. There's not a "flea-market" or farmer's market of this caliber anywhere in America. There are a lot of young and talented people out here competing to get noticed. There is a lot of high quality food and spices there. I bought a few bottles of hot sauce there, that I continue to use to this day. I'm not a huge arts & crafts guy, but there was a lot of good stuff on display & for sale... It's a great weekend activity in Cape Town.

Visit to "The Test Kitchen". Best food!!!! Very expensive but worthwhile!! You need to book well in advance to get a place. There are also very nice shops to browse that you do not find at other malls.

Must Must see and Go. Thsi one of my favourite spots in Cape town.This palce has space for everything: shop, eat, chill, listen to music,get lostThe food is spectacular in this place I woul reccomend the chinese corner with dim sum, roibos ice tea (right on the other corner), belgian waffles, oisters,vegan food,macarrons and try everyting that you can.The clothes been selled are also very nice, most of them are hand made, vintage or has some nice touch.The furniture and decorations shops are so cute, you will find very nice and exquisite stuff.the only annoying part is when it closes :) and there is a lot of taxi drivers trying to drive out.

Fun way to spend a Saturday morning. Was a fun walk looking at all the crafts and food. They have a very nice wine shop and the staff is extremely knowledgeable on local wine. Lots of food to choose from if you do not mid the crowds. Nice way to spend a couple of hours while in town.

The best part is the food market. Once a biscuit factory, the premises have now been converted to a series of boutique style shops selling anything from clothing to sometimes-quirky souvenirs. For me, the food market in a covered hall was the most interesting part with its fresh bread, homemade cakes, tuna biltong, grilled mushrooms on skewers, cheeses, flowers and much more - a feast for the eye as well as the stomach! There is plenty of food to eat on the premises and a number of communal benches and tables for customers. It is easy to see why this "farmers' market" is a favourite with Capetonians (although I suspect this part might only be open at weekends). It is a bit out of the city centre, so best take a cab.
Saturday Neighbourly Market a gem!. Try to get to the Saturday market which runs between 9am-2pm - it's an absolute treat for foodies! Biggest challenge is choosing where to eat... Go hungry!!!

Neighbour Good!!!! . Too good to be true.. Been there on Saturday and was just awesome with local products to discover.. Eat, taste, buy or just stroll around, either way, just a great experience! A must- visit if in cape town!

MUST see!!. I cannot be effusive enough in my praise for this market. Whilst food can be a little pricey, for a foodie it's a most worthwhile experience. I could honestly go back every weekend and eat something different.

Best thing to do on a Saturday morning, if you in CapeTown. Make sure to go to this food market. It gives such a good feeling of the vibe in Cape Town and the food is fantastic. Prepare yourself for a relaxed el fresco dinning experience but the food quality is fantastic!!

A great place to be!. Like the title says, simply a great place to be! The atmosphere, the food, the people, the music, art, everything. So much to see, so much to taste. I highly recommend a visit. And if you do, the puffertjes, small dutch pancake balls, are also highly recommended!Enjoy!

All in One Happy Stop!. What a great place to stop off on a weekend, everything a happy little traveler or local could ask for, great food, craft beer, good coffee, local designers selling their goods and overall a fun bustling vibe!

Saturday morning. We went to the Old Biscuit Mill early the morning, what a surprise. The shops are stocked with good quality art, clothes and gifts.The quality of the artwork was obvious. Young and old were browsing and even though it was busy and there were a lot of people it was not difficult to get around and see what you want. I liked the bead shop and the gift shop with the up cycled gifts as well as the food court. The stalls in the foodcourt catered for every taste and more. I can really recommend a visit, but I am not sure if one visit will be enough - this is a place that must be visited again and again.

Old Biscuit Mill Weekend Market in Cape Town, South Africa. This was a wonderful experience in Cape Town. Easy to get to, busy, fun..there are crowds but it is all about friendship, fun and lovely traders bring their goods. We enjoyed every minute and we would go back in a heart beat!!! Try to include this if you are in Cape Town on a week end.Buy something if you see it, merchandise goes fast and we missed a terrific leather bag because we delayed the purchase until the end .,..missed on a special memory.Smiled all the way through until lunch at the Test Kitchen.

What a fantastic place. Conveniently situated close to town this quirky place is a total gem - a real live renovated old Biscuit Mill. Parking on site in the week but gets really busy at weekends when there's also a market. An abundance of excellent restaurants; artisan bakery; art & craft shops; an amazing bottle store; clothing stores etc - if you haven't been, it's a must for your To Do list.

A great way to start a Saturday. Crushed and crazy. But for a foodie like me a must go to. Grab a glass of bubbles first and just move with the crowd stopping to try all the culinary delights along the way. Everything was fresh and delicious. Especially the cheese stall. Very knowledgeable vendors only too happy to answer questions

One of my favorites!. Fun place but be prepared to be overwhelmed by the abundance of great food. Everything from breakfast sandwiches and smoothies to gourmet Italian dishes and wine, with everything else in between. So many different types of food that it is very difficult to choose. The live music outside is fun but be sure to arrive early as it gets crowded.

Old Biscuit Mill. Very nice open air market. We strolled with strawberry mimosas while browsing the various soaps, foods, spices, fresh cut flowers and more. It is so worth the trip. The parking was tight next to the mill but we found free street parking only a block away passed the roundabout.

Set aside some time from your weekend for this. Easily one of the best markets I've been to. Very quaint, and the food and drink available is excellent both in terms of variety and quality. Understandably, it gets quite crowded quite fast.
Cool. Great and interesting food stalls, lovely fresh veg to buy. Very cool and trendy vibe and great place to wonder. Go early though- gets very busy!

Vibey, yummy and fun. Great food, reasonable prices and huge portions... Dim sum for R50 was amazing and more than enough. Must try the honey liqueur in chocolate pots... Hhmmmm great music lovely decor and a well thought out area generating economy in a deprived area.

An absolute must. Meet Cape Town's chefs and produce at it s best. Went there just after Easter the weather was great. Plan for the whole day if you can and plan also a taxi to bring you back. Wine tasting and craft beer tasting at its best. You need to try the local Dutch specialities and do not forget worst!If you go by

Really Cool experience. This is a great food market open only on weekends. Great restaurants and great food stalls and many other vendors selling various produce. also food of the world section with many different cuisine types. Go with an apetite as lots to see, do and taste. Parking is the only issue, get something on the main road if possible and don't be fooled with private property offering parking - they usually charge exorbitantprices(R20-30) when the street parking is free with maybe a small tip(R2-R10 ) for the car guard if you feel neccessary.

Absolute must visit!. Wow! This place gets me every time. Super busy, but so worth it thanks to the variety of superb food that is available. A culinary ecstasy that you can't get enough of. Loved it! Good local clothing and leather products also available.

Delicious!. We had a great evening at The Test Kitchen. The restaurant is world class but on the current £ to ZAR conversion rate... without the world class price tag! We had a tasting menu with wine paring and everything was completely delicious and beautifully presented. It was completely fascinating to watch the kitchen staff in action - they are as talented as they are hard working. Great evening - highly recommend.

Love Biscuit Mill!. Located in Woodstock, this market is in a great location and has lots of great little botique shops. It seems very small at first, but if you are there on a Saturday morning make sure you go towards the tents and there's hundreds of stands of fresh ingredient foods! don't eat before you come here!

Spend Saturday morning here. Amazing food and lots of really cool unique shops and market stalls. Ate at the deli cafe beside the wine shop, definitely recommend although if you can't get a table there are plenty of food stalls in the neighbour goods market.

Great tourist attraction but not really Cape Town feel. Perhaps it's the day I went but I didn't really get a "Cape Town" feel on the day I visited. I can imagine many tourist liking it: afterall it is cosmopolitan, energetic, young, vibrant and, in places, very vegetarian, vegan and Eco-friendly. But I find this very exclusive for a market that is located on the border of Woodstock, a neighborhood that is very inclusive but also becoming quite a place to visit.I went with my three young daughters and the shops were not very attractive for any of us. They were more like boutiques than market stalls. There was only one part set up like stalls and I would feel more comfortable shopping there. There were practically no attractions or play area for kids....so that takes care of that as a family venue.The tent with the food stalls wee the most refreshing part. It was very crowded and you had to wait for a place to open up on the bench. Still, this was the part my children enjoyed the most. people talked to them and merchants were very nice. It felt like a market....which was gravelly lacking in the other parts of the market. We are regular visitors at the Oranjezicht City Farm Market on Saturdays and I was hoping we would find another alternative. But the Old Biscuit Mill does not come close. Here kids cannot play and run around and the whole thing seem set up for tourists to get a feel of "home away from home". I will probably return but definitely not with kids and only when I'm in the mood to rub noses with tourists.

Great Saturday market. Famous for it's Saturday market. Well worth a visit. Amazing market with cool stuff for sale, but particularly great for the food. Highly recommend going early, when they open, as from about noon onwards the place gets packed with locals who go for lunch, wine and atmosphere.

Amazing food!. A very trendy part of town located about a R50 can ride from the V&A waterfront in the area of Woodstock. This has the usual trendy craft stores as well as an amazing range of foods. Almost any food possible is on sale here in small stalls with areas to eat. The shops nearby sell furniture and crafts which is also worth a look. There are plenty of cabs out the front however choose a reputable looking cab to avoid getting ripped off. Make sure you come with an empty stomach.

Superb Saturday food market. This market only works on Saturdays and comprises a great range of food stalls in the old biscuit factory. Food is accompanied by live music and a number of beer/wine stalls. With the food, you are really "spoiled for choice" and I think I could happily have eaten the food from any of the stalls.One drawback is that it is incredibly crowded, it is well out of Cape Town and parking is hard to come by. Better to take a taxi: driver tried to charge us ZAR 70 on way back but should only be ZAR 50 - should really have insisted on the meter! The other drawback is that because it is so crowded, it is very difficult to find a place to sit at one of the long, informal benches along the middle of the halls. It would probably work OK if everyone just got their food and looked for space, but of course what happens is that one person in each group nabs spaces for their entire group so what spaces there are are taken by "saved" places. (Sorry, just a small moan about life in general!)We were told that it finishes at 1pm, but was still going strong after 2pm. We went to this market last time we were in Cape Town (2 years ago) and would certainly go again.

Fun time and good food. Another very good destination in Cape Town, there are tons of local merchants selling goods and home made foods as well--good beer and coffee as well. It's worth a few hours on a Saturday Morning--some really good local biltong as well as some beautiful vegetables and fruits

Fab place to go on a Saturday. We drove to the biscuit mill as it got a good write up but it feels like you are driving into a no-go area, but we needn't have worried. It is a very busy area and there are loads of people out who will help you find a place to park, which is worth the tip.The OBM is literally an old factory that is now a thriving saturday social scene - with a large food market, live music, artisan shops and some restaurants. The vibe is fantastic. It seems like all the CT beautiful people go there to be seen. So should you.

Don't eat before you go. Come hungry! You will want to sample everything in the Neighbourgoods market - and there are so many amazing different things to try! We also bought local honey from a vendor at the market and a ton of chocolate from Cocoafair (the desert salt dark chocolate was AMAZING), which is a normal shop at old biscuit mill. You can take a tour of the chocolate making process from beginning to end in their shop. Definitely arrive early to the Neighbourgoods market and try to find the hidden parking lots around the market because it is a shady area and I was glad to be in a group of 5 people walking back to our car. It would have made me feel uncomfortable if I was walking alone, even in broad daylight. Also, you want to get there early because once it gets crowded you have a hard time moving from one vendor to the other.... so many people!

Got to try everything once you are there. The music, the food and the people. A magical combination once you visit this place on a Saturday. The food is great and you don't want to leave the place after you tasted something. Just make sure you have enough cash with you, because you are going to eat a lot and with a lot, I mean A LOT!!!

Funky Shopping and Dining. We enjoyed 2 hours exploring and shopping at the Old Biscuit Mill prior to dining at The Pot Luck Club. The area is fun and funky - lots of great little shops with interesting and unique items. We purchased some delicious artisan chocolates, some fun jewelry and gifts.Afterwards we stepped out of the Old Biscuit Mill to explore the area which is still somewhat rundown. There are some good shops nearby too.

Once isn't enough.... This was my first trip to the market, and i know i would need several more just to try all the foods.The actual crafts and stores selling things didn't interest me much, as it is almost entirely artisan and quite pricey... The jazz band playing when we arrived was great, as were some kids with buckets just outside the entrance. Walking through the two food courts was extremely difficult, for two reasons. First there are tons of people and everyone is trying to look at the food stalls on both sides as they walk making it quite congested. Second, is that i couldn't decided what food i wanted everything looks and smells amazing!!! I ended up trying several tasters that were out there, but did buy a waffle with bacon inside it, and also a chicken kebab, the green chili sauce was so good. Both the waffle and kebab were excellent, tried 3 different smoothies between us and all were great. I especially liked the lemon and mint. I got a red velvet cupcake from the queen of tarts and it was nearly perfect. We had a great time walking around down there for about 2 hours. I would definitely go back if i was here for another saturday.

A bit of a cliché but worth visiting. Take some old disused industrial buildings and populate with artisan - food makers/restaurants, handicraft stalls, furniture, nik naks, clothes etc etc, sprinkle some chaos and huge Saturday morning crowds and you have..The Old Biscuit Mill!. It seems that a massive hype surrounds this place and yes, one will be bombarded by lovely food aroma's and the general buzz of hundreds of people, selling, buying and engaged in general excited converation. However, this is a formula repeated in many places I have visited to a greater or lesser extent that it even feels at times like a franchise but maybe that's just globalisation for you. I was happy to have been and seen but more happy to escape. Perhaps I would suggest visiting during the week when it is (I believe) less manic unless you like this type of thing.

Great Saturday Outing. We had an awesome time at the Old Biscuit Mill. Enjoyed champagne, oysters & the Chinese is a must have. Lovely items on offer from various artisans. The live music was great & created a fantastic vibe. Leave early to find parking. And don't get too annoyed by the hustle & bustle of the crowds as it will just spoil a great outing.

Wonderful Attraction in Woodstock. This was our first visit to Old Biscuit Mill and it didn't disappoint. It is a great example of what the imaginative mind can come up with for redundant industrial buildings. Shops, restaurants and even small scale manufacturing of wooden tables combine to give this place a real buzz. Not just restaurants but the BEST in SA. The Test Kitchen and Pot Luck are both at the top of the league tables for SA eating and both are to be found at the Old Biscuit Mill. We visited on a quiet weekday and were unable to book either venue so no reviews just recommendations from folk who know! We hear the Saturday market there is hectic and very crowded.

Great Cullinary Experience. The old biscuit mill has all types of food t great prices. From oysters to sushi as well as pizza and vetkoe. The aroma's are fantastic and the only problem is finding parking as well as deciding what to eat! Also home to SA best restraint, The Test Kitchen.

Excellent place to hang out on a Saturday. Super cool shops and stands selling stylish homeware and interesting clothing from local designers during the week, plus an additional very lively food market on Saturdays with a few dozen stands selling a great range of fresh, sweet and savoury food, plus good juices, smoothies, beers and wines. Of course, this is very much not all of the greatness that Cape Town offers and you could easily feel when you visit that you are in a corner of California dumped onto a pretty poor (though perhaps up-and-coming) neighbourhood. Whether you love that or have mixed feelings about it is up to you, though personally I hope that this place retains its feeling of being part of the community, not a separate enclave it. But if you want to see one part of how this city is becoming more hip and proud, this is surely a place to visit.
Nice venue!!. A nice place with restaurants, wine shops, live music and small handcraft stores. But the surrounding neighborhood it's not so nice. I think it worth a visit.

Becoming a bit of a tourist trap.. Very very busy , victim of it's own success , why they don't open longer is beyond me. Avoid the neighbourhood market on Saturday, go mid week when the surrounding shops are actually open and there's less hassling car guards.
Great atmosphere. With plenty of great food, lots of craft beers and wines and a live jazz band playing we really enjoyed the old biscuit mill.
Bohemian Biscuits.. Excellent people watching and excellent food. Outrageous prices made it a frustrating visit. Loved the way in which pizza were served and seating.

Interesting. We walked from our hotel down to the Old Biscuit Mill which was about a 2-3 mile walk. We enjoyed all the small boutiques and stores and only wish that we would have gone on a Saturday when they have the market going.

Cool place to spend a Saturday morning. I came here on a Saturday morning with my fiance and walked around for about 3 hours. We had a lovely latte from a coffee shop and then walked around doing some souvenir shopping. The coolest part was the food market that is only open on Saturday mornings and has vendors selling fresh juice, bread, craft beers, dim sum and a million other options. I would highly recommend checking this out for a relaxing Saturday morning option.
Breakfast feast. excellent place to have breakfast. Selection of a variety of International meals. Variety of shops to keep you busy. Bargains can be made. Ambience is fantastic.
Two fantastic Restaurants. We went to both the Test Kitchen and The Pot Luck Club. These are two fantastic restaurants, be sure to go there hungry as food truly fabulous and keeps coming!

Thoroughly Enjoyable Experience!!. This was a fantastic experience! A trip to Cape Town is not complete without a visit to the Old Biscuit Mill. From grilled mushrooms to tuna biltong you will find a wide variety of food here. Get there early and be prepared to squeeze your way through crowds of people and stand in ques at the variety of food stalls. This place is incredibly busy and has a relaxed and casual vibe about it. On the outside there are various clothing stalls, but the main attraction is the food. People come here to eat, socialise and while away the time. This place seems to have put an otherwise rundown area on the map. Parking was a bit of a mission. We parked a street away.
Just to full. To many people. No parking. Food market is just nice and average. Avoid the shwarma. I dont reccomend going there on a hot day.

Expected more!. Having heard about the Saturday market my wife and I made our way to the Old Biscuit Mall. Finding parking was challenging, but hey, its was just before Christmas so that was to be expected. The sheer volume of the people made moving around uncomfortable and we really expected the market to be much bigger. The wares on sale were however of good quality and reasonably priced. We were glad we went, but this falls in the 'been there done that' experience.
Worth a visit. Very nice shops! Friendly tenants AND a great choice too!Good coffee and large choice of presents to take back home!Keep on going and keep the good spirits Up.

visit on saturday for the market!. A must if you're in Cape Town on Saturday-- the Neighbourgoods market at the Old Biscuit Mill is vibrant, delicious, and so much fun! The market runs every Saturday, rain or shine, from 9am-2pm. I expected a farmers' market with some prepared items, but most food vendors sell prepared food. Dozens of stalls featured food from all around the world, including tacos, paella, barbeque, sushi, homemade ice cream, beer, coffee, chocolate, and kombucha. Though it was crowded, the atmosphere was fun and we found seats and enjoyed the live music. Good for shopping (mostly stylish and locally-made clothing and jewelry) as well.We rightfully assumed it would be busy and took a taxi. Unless you plan to arrive upon opening, I'd recommend doing the same.

Good market food. We enjoy the Old Biscuit Mill - thankfully we are local so we can avoid peak tourist season but even then it is frantic most times and this has ruined the experience for us. It is a struggle to find a quiet spot to enjoy our food, which by the way has also become pretty pricey compared to other markets, like Root 44, or the Stellenbosch Slow Market in Oude Libertas. Parking is a nightmare so you need to get there by 9h00 if you want to avoid the frustration of overcrowding.
Always worth it. If you don't mind the queues. But even with them it is worth it. The Copper Bar is a must o a hot day.

Must do if you visit Cape Town. Very busy, crazy full, Get there early and enjoy..If you dont like crowds, then stay away. Its well worth the visit as the food selections are great. but expect it to be BUSY...

Busy, fun Saturday market. We visited the Old Biscuit Mill on Saturday at 10h00 in January 2015. We were warned to arrive early to get parking outside and to avoid the crowds at the market, but 10h00 was already way too late. The market is filled with interesting foods and crafts all home made and delicious. There is a lovely vibe but it becomes very congested. If the weather is cooler it may be more pleasant to spend more time at the market. I would recommend an early breakfast there rather than lunch. There are also interesting other clothing, furniture, curios and coffee shops outside the Biscuit Mill.

Incredible...that is all. We had a superb experience visiting the old biscuit mill awesome shopping and food. Very busy this place was buzzing with energy and a great variety of cuisine ( Expect to do lots of snacking)

Interesting. This Saturday market is a must visit. Lots of unusual food and other items, great atmosphere and vibe, prices reasonable, clean and sufficient bathrooms. There is just NO (safe) PARKING nearby, so either go really very early, or get someone to drop you of.

Saturday market - bring your appetite. The Saturday morning market is fun - but go hungry! We had our hotel's huge breakfast first, and had no room for the wonderful and unique offerings. But, the people viewing was fabulous and the vibe so cheery and modern. Loved it.

Eclectic, hectic and full of variety. While it was really busy, there are such a variety of gifts and souvenirs and home crafted items to buy. However, the variety of foods is fantastic.....like visiting scores of homes with many international and local flavours. There is no ways you could ever leave this place hungry!

Do not miss out on the experience. Maybe you want some artisanal bread, something for a cheese board, some fresh fruit or homemade pickle, juicy, plump olives or delicious sausages and salami. I recommend a Bloody Mary, followed by fresh oysters and champagne or a yummy burger washed down with a craft beer. You might fancy steaming hot coffee and a work of art from one of the cup cake stalls. Whatever it is - try the Biscuit Mill first! Be warned, it is popular so go early. Grab a spot and watch the world go by.

Amazing market - go hungry!. The variety and quality of the prepared foods blew me away! Wonderful place for foodies. Great atmosphere, great people, and cute shops. Very worth a trip. Was very crowded when I went during the Christmas holidays.
Foodie Bliss. First Visit and fell in love with the vibe and all the food choices. Brilliant transformation of the old Buildings and good use of space.

Great yuppie eating outlet. First tip - do not go during the Christmas holidays - too over crowded and you will not enjoy the vibe . Fortunately I had visited previously as well so appreciated the concept . loads of food choices and drinks . Organic chocolate , pistachio fudge was fab and the paella great . You buy your food and sit at benches to eat - its a great choice if you have teenagers because they love vibes places . Must get there early to get parking .
very nice market and lovely atmosphere. one needs to go quite early since due to its populriaty it gets very very crowded. lovely market nice cafes , great vibe, not to be missed

A must while in Cape Town. This is the thing to do on a Saturday morning while in Cape Town. Be prepared for crowds, squeezing your way past hundreds as you make your round the food courts, trying to decide what to eat. Eating is what it is all about but don't expect relaxed or a space to eat. Since we were last there ( a year ago) they've expanded the seating space but it is still an arm wrestle to get anywhere and anything - all part of the fun.

great outings in neighbourgoods markets. Enjoy stylish food, wine and cheese at the Wine shop. Enjoy street food and great craft beer while you shop some organic vegetables. Check what the designers are upto with their trendy sales - all at the Old Biscuit Mill. I picked up some heavenly hand crafted chocolate ice cream. It was divine.

Delicious but extremely busy. Saturday morning markets at the Old Biscuit Mill are absolutely the place to be seen! Very trendy. Delicious food but its extremely crowded so be sure to expect that. Worth an outing.

Foodie lovers paradise. Great mix of shops and the food hall is fabulous. It is totally over crowded and queues are long but its total worth the wait. Fresh, home made, delicious food and drinks.If you enjoy wandering around markets and eating delicious food, then definitely get to the Biscuit Mill... early if you want to avoid the crowds

Foodie heaven!. We were keen to visit the Old Biscuit Mill on the only Saturday we were in Cape Town, and followed the advice of other travellers and arrived early (and hungry). At 9am it wasn't too crowded and that gave us an opportunity to look at the food stalls, where all the produce is beautifully presented. We picked up juice, coffee and some pastries to keep us going while we decided what we wanted for bruch an hour or so later.By 10am, it was filling up, so we just perched wherever we could, asked other people to shuffle up a bit so that we could sit together (which they happily did) and just soaked up the atmosphere. The vibe is great, people are chatting and catching up with friends, stallholders are explaining their food to potential buyers, kids are everywhere, there's live music playing - just fantastic.Although we stuffed ourselves full, and took cake home for later in the day, we would have loved to stay in Cape Town longer to do it all over again! If you, like me, love food, then this is a 'must' on your itinerary. Australians will find the prices very reasonable, and the choices are extensive.The shops at the Market are also excellent - I bought lots of Christmas gifts while I was there, and was impressed with the quality and price. In particular, it was great to find goods that were not mass-produced. Yes, you pay a little more than you would at a roadside stall, but this was more like a 'Handmade' market in Australia, where the person you are buying from is the person who has made the bag/jewellery/clothes.As for transport, we had a car for a couple of days during our stay, so drove to the Markets and parked on Albert Road. We just did what the locals do, and paid R20 ($2) to a guy on the street to watch the car - this is a normal practice in South Africa and we did it a lot without any issues.

Definite Must See. The Old Biscuit Mill is a jewel in the middle of Cape Town. When traveling, I always like to visit a local market and this was by far one of the best ones I've ever been to. The Old Biscuit Mill is only open on Saturdays, and I highly recommend building an itinerary around this. You don't need too much time to get the full experience, 2-3 hours is plenty of time to eat and shop. The amount of food options is overwhelming and there are some great craft and jewelry finds from local vendors. Definitely go with an empty stomach and a full wallet!
wow. this is the place to explore cutting edge food and tradesPot Luck club great, Test Kitchen is the best

Its Just Too Overcrowded. Well if an attraction does a great job of providing a unique experience, it will become popular. Unfortunately this place is just way to popular for its own good. My recommendation is that you get there really early or don't go at all.This is the place you want to be when the tourists have left town, during season its just a joke.

Artisan shopping - best in town. We wandered round the shops here before having the lunch in The Test Kitchen - South Africa's best restaurant. It's in gentrified Woodstock, which is a 15-min taxi ride from central Cape Town. It reminds me of Shoreditch or Spitalfields Market in London. The ceramics, in particular, are very stylish and reasonably-priced. There's also a fabulous coffee shop and roastery. Woodstock is not the most salubrious of areas, but you can see how and why it's the coolest neighbourhood in Cape Town. Shopping within the Old Biscuit Mill complex is safe as there are security guards at the entrance. Definitely worth a mooch. Wished we'd been there on a Sat when there's a lively market.

Such fun, albeit pretty busy on a Saturday morning. The Neighbourgoods Market at the Old Biscuit Mill seems to be the weekly meeting place of many Cape Town locals. The atmosphere is great, although it does become too packed and finding a seat is a real challenge. The food options are good, although the prices are a little steep.
Be prepared for the crowds. This is a vibrant spot and Saturday morning's are extremely busy. Might pay to go mid-week when you can enjoy the various shops when it is not so hectic!

2nd Trip. This was my second trip and this time I enjoyed it much more.The food is great An excellent trip for foodies! Average price per meal or sample is R35. This time (was over Christmas season) it seemed to be even more busy than before but my daughter is older (6yrs) and handled the experience with enthusiasm. The last time I went she was 3yrs old and hated the crowds and made it very uncomfortable for us. I don't recommend you take babies and toddler with.Food is excellent, loads of taste samples. I don't recommend buying crafts - leave it to the tourists. The highlight is the food halls. Food halls, cocktails, mocktails, asian and fusion, sweets, waffles, paella, craft beers, freshly opened coconuts where you can drink the milk with a straw, schwarmas, sushi, the frying dutchman (loved his name),fresh produce, fudge,.... all jammed into a small space.If you enjoy crowds... then a definite place to visit!There is an ATM onsite, but there are always long queues. A couple should bring about R500 if they want to try and buy a few things. Very Very easy to spend money here!Parking is insane, so best to find one of those annoying guys trying to sell off free parking 2 blocks away. (R20) I do recommend telling these guys that you will pay them on your return if your car is safe and unscratched. Technically it is free parking but the crazed guys take there spots rather seriously and they are willing to let you pay later if you stand your ground politely. There are some small stores with nice arty vibes you can pop in on your walk to the buscuit mill. There is also a weird little diner/bar hidden along your walk. The area is not the gratest but on the days of the market the area seems safe and viby because of the many tourists and visitors and has a completely different atmosphere.

Foodies Heaven. This is seriously a Foodies Heaven!Visited the Saturday after Christmas & the place was overcrowded but a still a great vibe. We fought our way through the crowds & found all types of wonderful cocktails, beers & foods. Food was delicious & the cocktails & beer were icy cold which was perfect in the hot & crowded conditions. We found a seat at a long old timber table & that's where we stayed for hours, sampling foods & drinks. Heaven!There were plenty of other goods & trinkets for sale, so allowing time for browsing is a must.Parking was extremely difficult but we did visit on their busiest day of the year.A visit to The Old Biscuit Mill should be at the top of your list if visiting Capetown.

Jam packed. We walked a long way for Saturday brunch. Lots of wonderful food stalls - it reminded me of Borough Market London. Very, very busy and car parking was obviously difficult for a lot of people once the mill car park was full.

Awesome way to spend a Saturday morning!. The Neighbourhood Goods market operates at the Old Biscuit Mill between 9am - 2pm on Saturdays only so we planned a half day around this, and we were so glad we did! The Old Biscuit Mill houses many wonderful restaurants (needing months in advance bookings, FYI) and many shops. The best part is the sheer number of local producers, be it in wine, fashion, or food. There's a ton of local designers to view and shop, and prices are very reasonable. There's also a lot of beer, wine and food choices so come hungry, for breakfast or for lunch. Parking is terrible but you'll be able to find a spot along the street if you come early. And do come early, when we got there by 10am everything was already in full swing, the streets were already clogged with cars and we had to park one street over. The place is not that large, and it gets really, really crowded, so come prepared for that too.

Go where the locals go!. What a fabulous place! So we get in early around 8am and the place was quite empty…we turned left and walked into the old section of the mill…there's a chimney, small well, some equipment etc and just one breakfast joint. Other than that just a few people setting up stalls to sell their stuff.So we have our breakfast which was excellent and then some back to the main entrance an hour later and suddenly there's like 500 people! with 20 stalls opened up and then we walk to other end which has another 50 stalls and another 500 people! It was like big grand food fair with a lot of local produce and organic stuff - looked, smelled and tasted fantastic!I think its only on - on Saturday but definitely a great stop for breakfast and some shopping in the morning...

a MUST for food lovers. It was love at first sight for me and Old Biscuit Mill. We went on Saturday when it's all decked out -the day you really should go. I mean, who couldn't love the rows of vendors and yummy different food. We had planned to make a reservation at one of the restaurants there but I was so glad that that didn't work out!! We tasted and tried several different dishes -from Italian to chinese to AMAZING wild grilled mushrooms. Food that makes your mouth water. There was also different art/craft/fashion vendors there too. We didn't do much shopping -just looking- and things looked pretty reasonably priced. Will be back when I can. Don't miss Saturday morning at the Old Biscuit Mill!!
Fantastic Saturday Market. Our favourite Saturday market. Great shopping, food and wine/beer. We went several times in the month and everything we had was delicious.
Local weekend market in Cape Town. If I lived in Cape Town I would be at he farmers market every Saturday! The food, drinks and atmosphere are to die for. It can get crowded though!

Old Biscuit Mill Cape Town. Really fun day out with lots to see and do and plenty of places to eat. We ate at a little Deli in the centre which had fabulous food. Worth going to see a bit of history and some great art.
Lots of fun. We went to the biscuit mill during their Christmas fair and loved it...we saw many great venders and bought some great gifts!!!

Loved it!. Came to the Old Biscuit Mill to do HintHunt based in the building which in itself was a great experience but I was pleasantly surprised by all the gorgeous little shops and eateries.
Definitely worth a visit making sure you have enough time to meander through the shops and grab something to eat.

THE NEW SOUTH AFRICA. The Biscuit Mill is a place not to be missed on a Saturday. It was vacant for many years and then a few years ago entrepreneurs took it over and turned it into a vibrant place to visit. Everybody is young and they do not hang on to the past, they live today. Each venue is an independent unit.
Great vibe. Some great food and drink. A really good atmosphere if you go on a Saturday. I went twice and really enjoyed it. Easy to find. Lots of people watching. A must visit.

Difficult to find Parking. The vibes are great, lots of little shops, stalls, little restaurants, a big food court under a huge tent. A large variety of things to see and buy. Plants, specialised clothing, arts and crafts, home made scrumptious goodies ect. It is just a fun place to visit, very crowded, very busy, a lot of fun. If in Cape Town, don't miss going there on a Saturday morning

lovely use of an old space. We wandered around the various shops with great gift items.We ate lunch at the deli. Great staff and yummy food! Lots of interesting good for sale as well.It was difficult to get a taxi back into town though and the security fellow flagged one down for us!
Busy and fun market. Saturday mornings is always best time to visit The Old Biscuit Mill, with its Neighbourgoods Market. Lively, fun, tasty, noisy, crowdy... don't miss it!

awesome place but lacking some capetonian flare. its an awesome place, great food and little stores. amazing atmosphere. But it is sad to see that the Salt river community is not really benefiting from the consumer activity especially since tourist flock to the Biscuit Mill. Most of the stores and restaurants are owned by people not from the neighboring community.

Biscuit Mill. Fun place, worst burger I have ever eaten and not cheap to boot. The others with me enjoyed their food, but mine was almost inedible. Great "poffertjes"
though!

A meeting place for the local (white) Livingstone tribe and globetrotters. Sorry, but the title of this review was too tempting. Yet I love this this neighbourgoods place. It is an almost all white setting. Still, an extraordinary place where one gets locally produced high quality food, wine and beer, as well as the rainbow global kitchen of South Africa: Hungary, China, Korea, Latin-America, Spain, etc etc. Just amazing. One can get the most tasteful gorgonzolas, sun dried olives, ciabattas, dim sums, oysters, handmade chocolates, cakes, and biltong you never believed existed. The crafted coffee and bubbles are worth a visit in themselves. It normally get very crowded during Saturdays. So show up before 9am. Enjoy with an open mind.

Busy, busy, busy. Very glad we went along for the experience, but on reflection it isn't a place to take the children - it was just too hot and too busy so we had to spend the time worrying about keeping them close. There was a wide array of food on offer - all of that we tasted was ok, not great - and certainly not at street food prices - definitely geared to tourist wallets.

Must visit, cool place. Visited the Biscuit Mill recently. The place is a buzz and there is lots happening for the foodies. There are many craft shops and restaurants. Had a drink at the Pot Luck Club as the kitchen had just closed from lunch. Trendy and the smells of the food from tables that were finishing off their lunch sent ones taste-buds a frenzy. Would definitely go back to the Biscuit Mill when next in Cape Town to explore further as it seems a very interesting place and there are some wonderful restaurants though I think reservations may be essential.
Busy place. To many Kids & yummy mummy's!Totally hectic (as they say in SA ) on a Saturday.Good food a bit like Borough Market in London SE1.

Must visit. Every Saturday you get to taste the most delicious, original food in Cape Town. My faves are tuna biltong, Roxy and Raw's dehydrated kale, and yogurt with toppings. My husband's are steak pie, melktert, and tiny cakes.

Worth a trip. The Biscuit Mill is well worth a trip of a Saturday morning! It has become very much part of the furniture in the Woodstock area and is responsible for a number of very cool craft/furniture-shops/cafes sprouting up in all directions away from 'the Mill'. Which are as interesting. The market itself caters for all ages/types and is full of excellent food stalls charging reasonable enough prices (but its not cheap per se). There is pretty much every type of food stall (invariably organic and good quality) available….and plenty of lovely craft offerings as well. But be aware it gets mad busy (particularly parking and don't park illegally or you'll get done) so get there early. If you haven't seen it, its worth a visit….and you'll find you'll be going back regularly enough if you're living in the city.

A Saturday morning / lunchtime must. Was recommended to visit this place by a waiter at the V n A after we complemented the oysters we had eaten. Boy was it a great tip. The old biscuit mill is buzzing with locals and tourists alike for reasons made obvious as soon as you walk through the gates. Wonderful stalls and stores containing all kinds of art, Nik-naks, jewellery etc and of course mouth watering food and drinks. No matter what your tastes they will be satisfied here. We had Japanese salads with fresh tuna and salmon, wasabi, seaseme and pickled ginger WOW it was so good. All washed down with a Black Jack's Brewery IPA. Sublime. We even bumped into the same waiter! Don't miss this if you're their on a Saturday.

Neighbourgoods market!. Amazing market on a Saturday morning! So fun, great atmosphere-fabulous local food and drink vendors plus lots of cute shops. Don't have breakfast and head straight here ready to eat and drink and take in the sights and sounds,(for Londoners it reminds me a bit of a Borough Market in Shorditch!)

Wonderful food, vibe and people. Best place to go on Saturday when in Cape Town. You will be offered variety of fresh food. My favorite dishes are the poached eggs and the pita. I did not like the Belgium waffles. I found them under cooked.

Busy busy. BUZZING !!!!!. Need to look at map to find, if going by car best from Waterfront area as you can follow signs better.Car park inside area of mill but small, can park on road if going on a Saturday need to start early. Man showed sparking spot in road, very polite and told us not to leave a thing valuable on show in car and lock in boot/ trunk, gave him small tip for his helpfulness and keeping eye on car. Place was buzzing when we went on a Saturday morning in December. lots of stalls and shops could have purchased lots but have to carry them home on plane. Oh forgot some places will ship large items for you direct to your home. Food well to much to explain just loads of all types of stalls / tables / types being cooked hot / cold ,drinks of all types and sizes , even free samples !!! Spent a good two hours looking around stall and shops we found had very friendly staff.. Just make sure infusing own transport take care and go early.. !!!

Great atmostphere. This is a great place to chill and chat, meet friends and enjoy some worldwide cuisine or do some shopping. The Old Biscuit Mill might be that place where foreigners meet with and get to know the locals. The food is great... you are spoilt for choice. A must visit!

thats why Cape Town the best city in the world. Ever feel like you can't afford to travel but so wish you could do something different. Well you don't have to go very far, The Old biscuit Mill will take you on an international cuisine experience whilst doing this amongst tourists from all over the world. There's too much to choose from. You only difficulty would be finding a seat to eat all these treats. There is local craft beers, cocktails at 10am is quite the experience at the Old Biscuit Mill. Not to mention the Test Kitchen,SA's No 1 resturant is in the same area and they have a delightful poached egg and salmon on offer at the market itself. You will find trendy little stores inbetween, and enough of an atmosphere to believe you in any other country and still have the Cape Vibe and amazing friendliness. Its a must for me as a local and the summers are divine. Can't wait for my next visit...been eyeing the oysters and champagne.

Never get bored on a Saturday morning. You can find out any food that you feel like from the selections. Lots of food from pizza to beef ribs, from pancake to salad, from fresh oyster to icecream, from grilled mushroom to homemade cheese, from fried pork dumpling to kimchi...Just bear in mind, you have to be there super early, parking is a little bit annoying since it's quite a popular food market in town.

A must-do!. We went to the Old Biscuit Mill on a Saturday morning while the market was on. We were definitely happy to have such an exeprience. It is a great ambiance with live music, local grown organic products and you can eat literally anything you feel like!

A taste of South africa. A nice place to visit on a Saturday. Lots of fresh food, drinks and little stores selling a variety of things. Can get very busy, so like to go early, have something to eat and leave. Ideal for tourists

Wish we had one of these back home!. Yes it's busy but this is a fantastic melting pot of a place, two large sheds packed with so much choice for food and I thought prices were great despite what other reviewers think, parking was ok, you need to pay the guiders for it but that happens all over Cape Town. We had a noodle meal, barbecued assorted mushroom kebabs and a curried vegetable wrap, all delicious. Plenty of other stalls selling all kinds of meat dishes, ice creams, drinks and so on. A great place to people watch in a friendly and vibrant atmosphere, ther are also lots of other craft stalls all with artisans selling their wares, well worth a visit
Best market I have been to ever. This is how a market is done. Lots of places to eat. Seriously interesting food. Music and art to enjoy. Come early to get a place at the tables
Cool spot. Lovely restaurants - cute shops. Worth exploring! We ate at The Test Kitchen which was an incredible experience!

A bit crowded - but some good food. The old biscuit mill is a Saturday attraction. Note that parking is a bit of a hassle - and can be obviated by taking a cab. We however drove, and had to park along a busy side alley. There are numerous food vendors selling produce and food. If you do purchase food - you may want to get there early - otherwise you will have to eat standing up - as seating places are limited. If that doesn't grab your fancy - there are some quirky shops selling local goods.We had lunch at the Pot Luck Club (see my review) - which sits atop the old biscuit mill. The views from this establishment are stunning! This is a nice attraction - however it gets quite busy and is a tourist mecca. There are some nice shops outside - along the road as well. If you are planning a visit - get there early

great vibe n all kinds of tasty foods/ drinks, art n trinkets. Great place to be, especially on saturdays when the Food Market's up! there's different stands with food from all over the world, from Sushi, Bratwurst, Falafels to Belgian waffles…and wine, beer and juice bars! Great food for Vegans from the Salad Lover's stand!!! There's also shops that are there on a permanent base, to visit all week from souvenirs, clothes, gifts to Art shops, there's a furniture store where 2nd hand materials are transformed into beautiful objects n furniture, an Espresso Lab with the loveliest staff ever! n a print shop with great ideas, they'll print you almost anything on canvas, fabrics or any print base!

unique entertainment and food in Cape Town. On Saturday mornings, you MUST go to the Old Biscuit Mill. It is entertaining from the nice crafts, clothes..one can buy, to the FANTASTIC FOOD venues. Never had I experienced a place where food vendors not only sold sumptuous things to eat or drink, but they gave samples of their wares as you walked by their booths. Come hungry and take your time.
nice urban respite. The part we saw was filled with nice urban, hip shops and a couple nice restaurants including the impossible to get into tasting kitchen. It was a nice oasis.

Old Biscuit Mill. Cape Town, SA has a delightful, fun filled, gastronomical event each Saturday. Walking around the artsy stores at the Mill, and seeing all the organic, natural foods sold made me want to move there. The one bad thing was deciding what on earth to eat with all the yummy options from baked goods, to paella, to potato latkes with eggs benedict on top. On my!
Great place to visit. Some great shops here including Test kitchen and the pot luck club. Make sure you take a map with you if your driving as it's tucked well out of the way.

Crowded!. On saturdays, there's a great food market here. They fill the place with locally produced and/or sourced food. Everything from a platter of oysters to crepes or braai (grill), sausages and burgers, you name it. It's a cheap way to sample south african food and very popular, so be prepared to fight through the crowds. It's located in the Woodstock area about 10-15 minutes by car/taxi from central cape town. They don't have only a food market of course, but lots of shops with clothes, art&design stuff etc. as well. The further you go from the Old Biscuit mill itself, the more dodgy the area gets, but a few blocks around it is definitely ok and has other shops and bars, restaurants and so on.

Foodie heaven!. there are certain things that set a foodie's/ chef's heart like mine aglow, and one of them is winkling out unusual or hard -to find ingredients.my latest treasures are R Capensis fresh mushrooms from Funki Fungi, and wonderful white asparagus from Ondersteun
yuppie meeting place. expensive, although lots of fresh produce too yuppie not my style . traffic congestion. love the bakery and fresh juices

Saturday Market - unenjoyable. First, try and find parking outside. Good luck with that! Then once you've negotiated all the scary car guards trying to lure you into their spaces you encounter the market area. Yes, there are some very nice food stalls, but gosh, the prices are crazy. So you've forked out your money, now you have to find somewhere to sit. Good luck with that too. I really didn't enjoy this place. Over marketed and cannot cope with the amount of people who go.
Foodie heaven. Must see for everyone visiting Cape Town. Every type of cuisine under 1 roof. Eat, drink and enjoy as you wonder from stall to stall. VERY popular so expect crowds.
"Great Dinning ". Car parking can be an issue and advisable not to park far from entrance,Once you are through the gates ,the surprises keep coming with some restaurants booked up for weeks
Awesome. Had a awesome time. Had lots of food , great food and what a vibe. Top restaurants there as well those places just to chill out.

Amazing Foodmarket on Saturday. We went to see the Old Biscuit Mill on Saturday when the Neighbour Market takes place. A MUST SEE for foodies. Food stands, all fresh and hand made. Juice Bars. Handmade desserts. A foodie will find paradise there.

Saturday Morning Neighbourgoods Market - A Bit Of A Victim Of Its Own Success. Come on a Saturday Morning and join the masses for food and shopping stalls at the Old Biscuit Mill. Great atmosphere, great food, quirky stalls and shops. However, it has become so popular, that you might want to go somewhere else on a Saturday morning for the food (e.g. one of the numerous markets in the area, e.g. Hout Bay Harbour Market, Slow Food Market in Stellenbosch etc.) and come to stroll around the great quirky shops on a weekday! If you are limited on time (which most Cape Town visitors are - just too much do to and see) and can only make it to one weekend market this is a good choice, but a bit too busy and popular for my liking. Personally I liked the Hout Bay Habour Market better. Sort of the same, but a bit less crowded, a bit more locals with food, shopping stalls and atmosphere being en par with this place.
good, busy, popular !. One can buy a good part of the weekly shopping here, ranging from cheeses, bread, veg, flowers - the proverbial neighbourhood market. Be there early

Shops and Restaurants. Well done and expanded since my last visit. Had a wonderful lunch outside of the patio in a wonderful Italian restaurant after finding out the Test Kitchen was fully booked for the day. Cute shops with local crafts and an excellent wine merchant with delicious recommendations.

Cool Place. We went here twice on a saturday and it is really cool. The best part is all the food on offer and just hanging out and having a couple drinks. They also have shops selling all sorts. Recommend taking a taxi as we did walk back once but was a little dodgy by the train station.
Market day. The food offerings on a Saturday market days are amazing. You can find anything you can imagine that is good and fattening.
Best food for years. Eat at Pot Luck (book miles in advance). Absolutely stunning and amazing food; really knowledgeable staff; great wines; buzzy atmosphere
Come early. A really really nice place but it can get very busy. Also you get lots of hassle from people just outside the venue. They should improve the security. The parking is also a pain.

THE Place to be on Saturday Morning!. The good news is, Neighbourgoods Market at the Old Biscuit Mill is the ONLY place you'll want to be in Cape Town on Saturday mornings. The bad news is, everyone else will be there too. It's totally worth swimming through the sea of humanity to score some of the tastiest treats in town. Coffee from Origin will start things off right - then we recommend staking out a spot to use as your base while members of your party take turns diving into the pandemonium to bring back food. Our favorite spot is in the front, right corner under the tree and next to the bar... the Bloody Marys are fabulous - or go with my favorite, the Mule - just the thing for morning drinking! You can't go wrong with the food in the market - everything we ate there was fantastic. And the shops are brimming with really great stuff too. The Old Biscuit Mill is definitely a MUST DO when visiting Cape Town.

Great place to be!. It's a great place to go on a Saturday when the wonderful food market is open, plus all the shops. We went again for dinner one evening and were told the shops would be open until 7, but once there, we discovered they had all closed at four!It's a great shame not to stay open as so much extra business could be done at the same time as people are waiting for their tables in the restaurants.

Beware of prices. A fun and vibey place to visit with a variety of different and good stalls with quality foods...but some vendors are really over charging for their goods, capitalising on the atmosphere and your experience.
Chill. Great way to start your Saturday. Lots and lots of different food, coffees, smoothies etc. Get something to eat and a drink and sit outside in the sun.

Great shopping & fantastic food. Parking is a problem so make sure you arrive well in time for a reservation or date. Niche shops selling great gifts, little pricey but excellent quality. The deli has the very best sandwiches & desserts. I have been twice and thoroughly enjoyed their fare.

Saturday MUST !!!. If you are in Cape Town on a Saturday and have nothing better to do YOU MUST visit this place. Lots of food stalls and art and atmosphere that is desirable. I recommend whole heartedly

Buzzing atmosphere filled with delicious flavours. This modern food market is great!Foods and flavours, both local and international.Go early to get a spot to sit, and not miss out on the good stuff. The rest of the trinkets at the market are just as lovely, but the food - do not miss the food.

Good but.... Good ambiance but way too crowded! You can barely move between stalls, the food is good but nothing original : sandwiches, chocolates, biltong, Asian food, burgers... You can pretty much find the same type of food in any other market in Cape Town... And you end up spending more money than in a restaurant!

Fun, food, atmosphere!. An amazing place to escape the dreary confines of a hotel breakfast. Head to The Biscuit Mill and feast with all your senses! Amazing stalls of locally produced yumminess, live music, and stunning flowers and produce. Sit down and feel like a local. Remember your manners though - locals never "hold" seats for others, always order and collect before trying to squeeze in to a spot! Enjoy!
No atm available . Only one atm that was out of order. Then when we did draw money the atm gave the incorrect amount. Other than that it was cool.

One of the best places for food. I really like this place. More an informal setting which is a car park during the week and becomes a food court on Saturdays until early afternoon. Great choice of different food and most looks home made. The atmosphere is great and not everything is perfect but that is part of the experience.

Creative goods, funky atmosphere, delicious food. Young entrepreneurs, older crafts people from the 60s, traditional indigenous designs, buskers, cold beer and all kinds of food - great way to spend a Saturday.
Visit to Old Biscuit Mill. Wonderful area to be in, lots of nice arty shops and some excellent food to be had , worth the visit, very relaxed atmosphere :)

My favourite place to spend an afternoon. Whenever I visit Cape Town, I always make time to visit the Old Biscuit Mill - the little deli offers the most deliciously fresh ciabattas with deli meats and fresh organic salad. Coffee is delivered from the Roastery next door and on the way out we always stop for Macarons to take home to the family. The arty atmosphere is relaxed and I always come away with a little trinket or two that I can't resist.
market with a buzz. one of the best markets to visit in Cape Town but overcrowded - get there at about 9 am and it will be pleasant

We had fun there with our Daughter. We went to Capetown to visit our daughter who was attending Capetown U. We loved the city and had a great time at our mid day visit to the Old Bisquit Mill Would go again if we visit again.

Amazing Experience! An absolute MUST DO in Cape Town!. Brilliant! Put this at the top of your list in Cape Town.Absolutely delicious food and drinks with a great atmosphere, topped off with a stunning view of Cape Town.Start your Saturday with any possible food you want and a few cocktails to get rid of the cobwebs from Friday night.

Keep on going back!. Saturday is the fresh food market day. Fantastic vibe, great fresh food and great variety. I love this place! You can’t get bored as there is a huge variety. It does get busy so I suggest going early. You can’t find parking I agree. What I usually do is park somewhere else and catch a taxi. Warning draw money before you go as the ATM queue will put you off and most stalls only accept cash. Go on an empty stomach, wonder around the various shops have something to eat and take a bag to take some food away.If ypu wish to avoid the crowds then go during the week still great restauarants and shops to wonder around.

Too busy and nothing special. I am still not sure why everyone loves the place, there is no parking, it is a pretty standard market nothing there you cannot get anywhere else that does not have parking issues
Beautiful building. It is a beautiful building. We went there to play a game with Hint Hunt. It was excellent. Thereafter we had a coffee and a bakery in the Old Biscuit Mill. Marvelous
So much fun!. The problem is deciding what to eat! Great music and people watching. Amazing food and drinks. Loved the atmosphere.

Variety is the spice of life. Brilliant Saturday market with a huge variety of food, victuals and cheap clothes on offer.
Many quirky shops open daily. Casamento is my favourite shop, with beautifully handmade furniture designed by Starry Eve and her partner. Expensive but worth every penny.

Loads to eat and see. On a Saturday there is a market, similar to the Borough Market in London. Communal tables, flower sellers, live music, unlimited food and drink.
There are a host of famous restaurants in the area as well as great art galleries.

Great Cape Town Market!. Love the whole vibe at the Biscuit Mill Market. You must go early or you won't get any parking. Not a lie :) There is so much happening at this Market, you won't know what to do first but my suggestion is to have one of the great Smoothies there and the pizza is also great. Actually, there is not ONE stall holder that sucks lol. Everything is really great, so take enough money with you if you are planning to visit the Market this Saturday!
Food stalls. Very very good food stalls, excellent variety of food, coffees,bread and organic delis. Lots of other commodities

A lot more than Old Biscuits. Plenty, of variety from food to arts and crafts. Great atmosphere with so much variety and some real specialist type things. Go for the day have lunch and a drink. You'll love it.

Crazy noisy!. Don't go there if you have a headache! But what a fabulous vibe - and the food offerings were out of this world. If I lived in Cape Town this would be a place I would visit at least one Saturday a month … just for the great fresh foods and drink!!

Alternative restaurants. The area seems to be industrial and not so safe, but we were able to drive with a taxi to this place frm the waterfront and to meet some friends from Europe. For visiting the shops, it was already to late around 7pm. It is recommended to prebook a table!
great shopping. Loved that there were South African artists' wares. I found handmade items that were evocative of the area to take home and remember.
Well worth a visit. We went to test kitchen so the area was closed but if we had more time I would have visited during day as there are shops etc.
The saturday marked. Nice food and drinks, nice leather - go as early as you can and skip breakfast, eat some nice food at the marked instead.

Food market. Great food and drink. Don't eat before you go!! The food is spectacular!!
Get there early, around 9:00am as it gets very busy with locals enjoying the place.

Love the vibe. I love this place. The food is great and I always find different produce to buy in the shed. It is impossible to enjoy in season. I made the mistake of taking family from overseas in December.......never again. When I go, I go early and just out of season - awesome experience then!

Wonderful vibrant market and shops. Loved the atmosphere, the shops and stalls on our visit. Highlight for me as used to this kind of vibe in London. Had lunch at the Pot Luck Club also a definite highlight. (Booking necessary)

Great local food market. Visited Cape Town in July 2014. We really enjoyed our morning at the old biscuit mill, amazing area of local crafts and food, don't have a big breakfast before you go and get their early! I loved the fresh juices and biltong stalls but there is something for everyone to enjoy at this market. A must visit if you are in Cape Town.
Too many people. This is a fun place for foodies, but it gets way too busy! Get there early to beat the crowds and find a spot to sit and eat.
markets and food!. went to the saturday markets twice and the restaurant upstairs (having booked 3 months in advance) which was fab

Great shopping for unique finds.. The Old Biscuit Mill is a trendy collection of shops with some really unique buys. From handmade ceramics and woodwork, to antiques and gifts, you are sure to find some treasure for your home or wardrobe. There is also a great restaurant, coffee shop and cellar for a relaxed afternoon lunch.

Old Biscuit Mill. Vibrant market, amazing food. Get there early to eat as it gets incredibly crowded at lunchtime.Also take time to visit the Artisan workshops to pick up locally made crafts and jewellery.Taxi from Green Point was 70 Ran

Biscuit mill. Only open certain days of the week. We went on a Saturday .
Numerous stalls selling all types of food and drink. Amazing.!
Other side has little stalls selling clothes and souvenirs.
A wonderful atmosphere, locals eat here regularly

Over priced and over crowded. The heading pretty much sums it up...Over priced and over crowded.
No parking
Could not wait to get out of there.

Good food market - very over crowded though.. The Old Biscuit Mill is an interresting place to visit (and a lot of interresting carachters hang out here too). The food market truly is amazing (ranging from fresh vegetable to chinese flavours and great selection for the sweet tooth), and craft beer is sold here too. There are a few shops that sells from cameras (polaroids included) to interior decorating items and if you are looking for something different you will definitely find it here.I do however feel that the effort and time to find parking and the fact that it is very overcrowded made my experience here less enjoyable.

Great Place!!!. I thought The Old Biscuit Mill was a great place! Although very busy they had a great vibe. It was filled with delicious food and crafts. I loved walking around all the stalls and looking at the variety of food they offered for people. They also had great drinks. Great way to spend your morning one weekend. I would highly recommend going if you like farmer market type things. Loved it!!

Chilled out and delicious. Having read the reviews I can’t believe that anyone could have anything negative to say about the sat markets. Yes, parking is limited. Take a taxi or park 300m down the street. But this is one groovy market that ranks among the best in the world! The food is sensational and you will be spoilt for choice. I am from Australia so I found it to be incredibly good value for money. What a chilled out, fun way to spend a sat in Cape Town. Make sure you don’t miss it if you are visiting.

A must see!. Great selection of different types of food and drink, it is also a wonderful place to people watch. We met a local couple there who gave us some great tips on what to do nad see in the area. Very friendly place.

The food market ranks with the best in the world.. We LOVED our morning at Old Biscuit Mill.Coming from Brooklyn (currently the food stall capital of the universe), we were desperately missing good food after living in Rwanda for almost a year. Cape Town was our saving grace in many ways, but the food market here was really the crown jewel. So many delicious and affordable options, super friendly people and a fun vibe, it felt like being home. :)Living in Malaysia now and DYING to go back!!!Get there early, we wished we'd had more time.

Trendy people, interesting things and good food. We went to the old biscuit Mill to see the market held there on a Saturday. Very busy with both tourists and locals which tells you something. The walk to the mill from our parking was interesting as the area has an array of design and collectable shops. The mill has been converted into shops and design studios with a deli, wine shop, coffee shop and some great clothing shops. These alone are worth a visit and the fountain in the main square will keep the kids fascinated. Try the coffee at the micro espresso bar. Great coffee and even better service from the staff. The market was mainly a foodie market with every type of food from sushi to steak! Reasonably priced too. Grab a bite to eat and a glass of wine and watch the people. Or get there early to avoid the crowds and have breakfast and feel superior that you have a prime table! ☺

Amazing Food Market. During the weekend the is a warehouse which is used I think as a car park but on Saturday a Food Market arrives from 9am to 2pm. Oysters and Champagne while sitting on a crate simply outstanding. The range of different outlets is just fantastic and everything we tried tasted fab.

Not for everyone. There are those who swear that the Old Biscuit Mill is by far the best attraction in Cape Town and for some people, I'm sure it is. I am just not one of them.Our arrival in Woodstock was a bit tricky as the roads were jam-packed. We were quite lucky to find a spot right outside the entrance. As soon as we got out of the car, we were swallowed up in a crowd. Maybe if it were less chaotic it would be more enjoyable but I found the busyness oppressive.
