On the plus side, there is a great selection of fresh food in the market section and lots of interesting things to buy for the home. I would probably come here to shop for home decor if I actually lived in Cape Town.I would say that this is a place better enjoyed by couples rather than families and one of the few lauded places that I would say to give a miss if you have young kids with you.
Overrated. This place is over crowded, not large enough to accommodate the number of people. One would enjoy best if they got there earlier. Also, parking is a nightmare, rather take a cab/taxi.
Underwhelmed. It was okay, parking was an issue. We went during the week, told the weekends are busier and thus more lively.

Awesome!. An awesome place thats open only on saturdays! There's tons of international food options - but be mindful it isn't your local "African" experience - it's also kind of pricy. The atmosphere is great and there's lots of trinkets and things you could buy.
Great food. Old Biscuit Mill is only open on Saturdays and a must but don't eat before you get there as the food is fantastic and a lot to choose from.

Not the average run of the mill..... what a pleasant surprise it was to discover the Old Biscuit Mill Market. we arrived at around 9h00 and we were absolutely astounded by the wide array of fresh food available. The area where the market is located is quite small so get there early to enjoy the best of the best food available. Karoo Moon is one of the shops that i really enjoyed visiting as well as the pottery studio.
Lots of food stalls. Visit the market on Saturdays and enjoy a selection of food choices . The atmosphere is vibrant and fun.

What a wonderful venue!. We went to the Old Biscuit Mill on Feb 1 prior to our excellent lunch at Test Kitchen What a wonderful in-town market. While the location is not really central, it is an easy taxi ride away. The atmosphere was like a country fair with excellent food with lots of free samples and wonderful crafts. I recommend this attraction highly.

Great food,great vibe. Food from the neighbourgoods market is great and there is more variety than the one in Johannesburg. Theres a chocolate factory and nice hippy styled and antique clothing and other garmets for sale

Lovely market food and great for people watching. Come to the Old Biscuit Mill on saturday for the market, if you like to people watch and try different food. Dont expect much of a "normal market" (with stalls selling fruit, cheese, vegetable, artisans etc.). This is not really a market where you come and buy produce to take home, or where you come looking for artsy souvenirs. Yes, there are a couple of stalls selling clothes, shoes, one selling flowers, one selling veggies. And there are a couple of small stores around the "market square" (including a great photografic store). The main reason to come however are the many many stalls selling food and drinks. Come hungry ! You can pretty much eat or drink everything, from fresh oysters with a glass of bubbly (lovely and very cheap - at least for swiss standards), via paella, bretzels, hot dogs, tarte flambè, belgian craft beer, lovely local wine, chinese dim sum and much more.The atmosphere at the market is very relaxed and its a fantastic place for people watching. I will be sure to return on my next trip to Cape Town.

Over crowded, overrated. I hadn't been down to the biscuit mill for years so we gave it another go. While the food was great as always it had lost the uniqueness that made it such fun in the early years.It was just too packed with people, parking was a nightmare and it wasn't the chilled, fun experience it used to be. I am now an Oranjeziche City Market convert instead.

What a find!. Woodstock is just so quaint with such lovely shops and renovated buildings all over the show. The biscuit mill is such a treasure but can be awfully crowded over the weekend and parking becomes a nightmare. Its best to visit during the week if possible and just be patient, the parking will become available right inside and once youre in, there is so much to see and good food to be had. The deli is amazing and have the freshest tastiest food. The owner has her charmiong father working alongside her and what a great combination they are !!!
Too busy!!!. I heard much of this market. There are many things to eat and drink, but it is very overated. There is too many people in too small space. Everything is overpriced!

Great Shopping & Food experience. Last day before we left South Africa we went here for the Saturday market and wow it was great. Some lovely hand made crafts and then the best bit......stall upon stall of food....there was everything you could think of! Lots of homegrown, organic, healthy but yummy foods at great prices. The place with just buzzing with lots of young locals. Difficult to get around if you are a bit later in day, but if you have the time, go check it out and sample some great delights
Massive crowds. We went on market day so it was immensely overcrowded. The market itself had some great food on offer but the shops which are open all week didn't excite us much.

Absolutely delightful afternoon. Husband and I recently visited Cape town for the first time and heard that coming to Old Biscuit Mill on Saturday is great fun -- boy was that correct! We were at OBM the evening before for dinner at Test Kitchen, but it was great to see and walk around during the day.  This market is fabulous. Come hungry, try as much as your tummy will allow. Neat shops and clothing as well. The atmosphere and vibe was great, also helped by the perfect weather. Highly recommend.

Outdoor Market. One of the best outdoor markets in CPT. The Biscuit mill offers a wide range of food and fresh produce. there are some great shops surround the market place as well for a lazy Saturday of browsing

fantastic variety and freshness!. the Mill has a fantastic vibe and large variety of food really makes choosing difficult, definitely something to please everyone! not to mention the craft beer from Jack Black, always good!and its not just the food, the shops and craft markets are also very varied and interesting.
Still probably one of Cape Town's best. Great vibe, great venue, great food! Be sure to try the Love sandwich at The Kitchen's stand .. amazing value, and it is delicious!

Something for everyone. Camera shop, chocolate factory (licorice dark chocolate is fab), pottery ( bought a beautiful plate for friend), hippie junk store ( found some great martini glass swizzle sticks). Test kitchen. Just a fun place to spend a few hours walking around and poking through the shops.
Lunch at the hot kitchen. One of a kind, great experience, I had a chance to find a table for lunch. Requires reservation for diner.The stores in the mill are unique.
Nothing short of Amazing!. Such an incredibly beautiful mix of art, culture, food and fun. Great aesthetic and I only wish I could go there every weekend.

overcrowded. If you like being in a tight press with strangers' bodies, this is the place for you. what started out as a lovely food market has become a serious tourist trap. unfortunately it means the place is super full; it's near impossible to get parking anywhere near; there are some aggressive car guards that don't leave one feeling safe about leaving your vehicle in their care; there are long waits at the various stalls, especially popular ones like for coffee (so don't go there desperate for a cuppa as it will take a while before you get served); it's near impossible to find a place to sit if you want brekkie, brunch or lunch. if you have kids definitely give it a miss as the crowding makes it difficult to keep your child in view. if you like food markets but don't want to be in a press, get there super early. if you get there after 9.30am expect a press until closing time. i'd rather give it a miss than deal with the overcrowding, hipster-style. won't be going there any time soon.

Multicultural. On saturdays I often think about the Old Biscuite Mill in Woodstock and want to go there again. It is such an hip and modern meetingplace for all, young and old , tourist or nativ.There are young desinger on the one side and on the other side are so many delicious goodies. Not only south african dishes also belgium waffles or indian chicken and much more !It´s a must do in Woodstock ! Enjoy

Glorious Saturday food-fest. If you love food this is the place to be on a Saturday! The food hall is just filled with food from all over the word, all seemingly excellent standard. Paella, sushi, all kinds of beer, cheeses, fruit and veg, all kinds of amazing cakes and buns. We ended up opting for a very tasty gourmet burger with some pear champagne with pomegranate seeds from another stall. We were sadly too full for dessert after that but got a selection of macaroons to take away which we ate later on Camp's Bay beach :-). It has a great atmosphere, very crowded but just buzzing, and food is eaten at big long communal tables. There are also a good selection of craft shops, wine, art, jewellery, furniture etc. We only wished we'd gotten there a bit earlier than we did to enjoy it for longer.
Saturday shopping spree. A lovely way to spend one's Saturday afternoon enjoying all the yummy food. Loved buying all the veggies, atmosphere great had a fab day with my ladies.

Doing as the locals do. If you want a taste of modern day Cape Town on a Saturday then take a trip to the Neighbourgoods Market at the Biscuit Mill.Lots of nice little shops here and a big food hall. You grab the food you want and then sit at communal tables.There is a real buzz to this place and you can really see how it brings the rainbow nation together.Interesting dock area that looks to be on the up. Lots of old Art Deco style buildings around the area

Busy and crowded but good value for money. Parking is a problem in the area so go early if you don't want to walk for a bit.Good food on sale and lots of different optionsYoung children would be a problem as could quite easily get lost in the crowd.To be honest I found it a bit over rated and not enough seating space to enjoy what you buy

Foodie's Heaven on Saturdays. Not a heck lot of parking on Saturdays -- be prepared to pay off a local who will watch over your vehicle while you shop...and that is common practice in many areas of South Africa. The food stands on Saturday are absolutely delightful --from gourmet sandwiches, belgian waffles, wildmushroom kebabs, dumplings, sushi, pizza, pastries, baked goods, fresh juices, cocktails, paella, jerky, oysters...pretty much anything you can name, you will find it here made cheap and fresh.

Favourite Market. I have been to a few neighbourhood markets and this one is probably my favourite! The vibe is just energetic and you almost feel like, even though everyone is strangers, you belong. There is different food choices and different values, and amazing smoothies and coffee and wine options. Everything looks so delicious you just want to buy buy buy.The last time we were here was after the two ocean's, and we bought some yummy food to get our energy levels back up!What is great about this market is that you can either spend like 3hours here, or pop buy for a quick visit, buy some yummy food and drive somewhere scenic for a picnic.

Very dynamic market. We visited the Old Biscuit Mill on a Saturday. What a dynamic and vibrant venue. Its really worth the visit. The small art shops, the boutiques and last but not least the fresh and food market. Strolling thru the food market is a feast for eyes ears and mouth.

Great market. We went on our last 1/2 day in Cape Town and we wished we did not have to have rushed. It was a fantastic market, lots of people, all sorts of interesting items both in the shops as well as in the market stalls. The food looked amazing...
Excellent food. Make sure you go early to get a seat. The food is incredible and it is even possible to get a glass of bubbly to have with your breakfast. Highly recommended

Gastronomy and people watching. It's a fabulous way to spend a Saturday.
Sit and drink an Everson's Cider, eat some delicious locally made food, and people watch.
The crowds are pretty insane but on a nice sunny day it's fun to sit on the pavement, eat, drink and be merry.

Hustle, bustle .... This is a fun area to visit. But you must go on Saturday morning when all the fantastic looking food vendors are set up. The place a very lively. The craft venders had some interesting things as well. In addition the stores that are there have lovely items for sale.
Very, good. Just say..and we are there... Just always a big treat. The food are just "out of this worled" There is absolutaly nothing that can be faulted.

Go here!. Great atmosphere, and such a diverse selection of food. Also very good for shopping local artists and designers. Lovely jewellery design. I'm definitly going back here both for the food, the drinks and the shopping. (Best on Saturdays)

Wonderful market. Visit on a Saturday morning for a wonderful market full of foods one can graze on. So many different flavours. Also some stalls for purchasing non food goods. There are also shops and some wine tasting in the wine shop! Great atmosphere.
Always a treat. Whether you are going to pot luck restaurant or treating yourself to the saturday market - the biscuit mill is a delightful experience again and again

Senses overloaded!. Awesome! The smells, sights,sounds and tastes were memorable. We enjoyed strolling around but should have stayed longer. Will visit here again when we have more time. A bit crowded so will try a visit during the week.Parking was a nightmare and we were nervous leaving our luggage in the car.

Interesting experience.. The shops are interesting. You see many things there that are definitely not found in the shopping malls. There are nice places/ restaurants to eat. It is a little bit too busy on a Saturday and parking nearby is a challenge. We discovered that one could park at College of Cape Town opposite the mill at a reasonable price PLUS your car is safe.
Go Hungry!. Local hangout on Saturday mornings. So much beautiful food to choose from, international and unique, South African wines and beer. Great people watching.
What fun. Good intentions to avoid naughty food fell away as soon as we spotted the eggs benedict, home made ice creams, fudges, etc
Old biscuit mill. Classy, up-market, but very touristy. Good food and beer, interesting boutique type shops. BUT, if you don't like crowds, avoid! Or go early!
The Mill. Expected perhaps too much. Restaurants slow with sevice, food excelent though but too mant of the same kind of stores or articles.
Worth only on Saturdays. There's nothing there except on Saturdays....except a brilliant chocolate artisan..and a Redemption burger which i didn't have opportunity to try cause it was early morning..

Jumping and Jamming. A visit to the biscuit mill market on a Saturday is a must. Food from every corner of the world is available. The stalls selling wares are mostly organic and the vibe is really good. The place fills up quickly, come early and come hungry you wont be dissapointed

Great Saturday Morning. This whole area is a real gem.
The mill itself has some nice boutiques and some great eats. The artisan food doesn't fail you. Very good young vibe.
Be sure to have a look at the galleries around the market as well for some very innovative and cool design.

Old Biscuit Mill in heart of Woodstock. A vibrant, warm-hearted village in the heart of Woodstock where talented people come together to share, collaborate and well... show off the heart-felt passion. The Mill is home to day and night markets, dynamic office space, a range of workshops and designer stores, delicious farm stalls, decadent restaurants as well as an inspiring line-up of festivals and productions. some of South Africa's most talented, innovative designers, artists, photographers, and connoisseurs of fine taste and decor.
Very pretty and touristy. Lots to look at, buy and eat and lovely to wonder around looking for gifts for loved ones. Had waffles for brunch, were delightful yum yum yum!!!
Was expecting more. We went to the old biscuit mill during the week and I think week end atmosphere is busier and nicer. Was disappointed by the stores in general and little food option

Such an interesting place.... A lovely mix of multi cultural people and tastes.
It is very popular on Saturdays mornings as there is a food marked. Please make sure you get there early as it gets very busy.
A must, is the rooibos, lemon and mint ice tea. I also enjoy the music and just walk around on the shops.

Food and destination observations. Overall the mill does not deliver to the expectations that I would expect from a food niched destination for the following reasons;Many of the stalls are staffed by learners/ helpers which effects the consistancy of food delivery. Whilst there is an amazimg variety available I get the impression that everything is priced/ margined to the max resulting in my opinion on a pretty expensive Saturday morning out for brekky! Very little change for R500 drawn at the local ATM is expensive for 2 people! R15 bucks for a 500 ml bottle of water is unreasonable. This in itself will not phase me if the culinary experience matched Meinhard's in Vancouver or for that matter Giovanni's in Greepoint. The coffee machine broke down( and if any barrista had to look at the condition of the machine he would refuse to operate it). Cape Town is perceived to be SA's premium coffe destination- so this oversight is really not up to speed. Yes, the breads and the fresh fruit and range of goods are impressive. HOWEVER my takout perception is that the mill is punching above its weight at the moment. I will not be going back in a hurry.

Very lively...very interesting. Don't expect to find good deals but you'll not be disappointed. many vendors and artists and entrepreneurs etc.... it is a must see and the earlier you get there the better. i went twice and enjoyed it each time. i highly recommend this to any visitor.
Get there early.... There are so many different food stalls to try that it will take you months of Saturdays to get through them all. It gets insanely crowded so get there early.

Foody heaven. On a sunn Saturday there is no other place to be than at the biscuit mill!! There are many clothing stores and accessory stores but my main draw are the food stalls!! Absolutely the best tastes of Cape Town !!

Go for the surprises. For me this was a great experience. I really enjoyed all the different flavours and types of food. The wine was great and to be honest I think I enjoyed it to much and overstayed myself :-). The women were shopping, shopping and shopping while we men had a great lunch. You get everything here from pancakes to excellent cheese. Great wines to jams. I will strongly recommend you to spoil yourself on a Saturday morning - don't be rushed, but rather enjoy your time at this great market.

Amazing Local Market with Delicious Food Vendors and Local Designer Fare! A MUST in Cape Town. Saturdays from 9am-2pm. THE best local weekend market I've ever been to. If you're in Cape Town on a Saturday, then The Old Biscuit Mill is a MUST! On Saturdays from 9am-2pm, the old mill fills with local restauranteurs and businesses. Think of a smorgasbord of delicious flavors from all over the world. Everything from Indian, to Greek to Chinese to Cape Malay...wines, beers, fresh juices, pastries, the list goes on. You could easily spend the whole time here eating, all the food is locally sourced and made and worth the 10 minute cab ride from the city center. The food vendors take cash only but there's an ATM onsite too. Highly recommend trying the potato latke with slow roasted lamb, the homemade fudge guy and the Indian curries booth. In addition to the amazing food, a lot of local designers come in on Saturdays as well in order to sell their designs. They have jewelry, bags, wallets, belts, luggage, clothes, shoes, etc. Very boutiquey type stuff that they sell for a lot cheaper at the market versus in the big stores on Long Street. You save money by buying the item at the Biscuit Mill versus buying the same item in the stores on Long Street. Great for going alone or with a big group. The Biscuit Mill is also open throughout the week but the food vendors and the boutique designer stalls are only there on Saturdays. MUST DO...especially for great people watching :)
Great place to buy local crafts and good food. I regret going right after a big breakfast as the food there looked amazing. Lots of young hipsters as well as us middle aged folk.

Yum, Yum, Yum!. If you want to give your tastebuds a treat, take them to the Old Biscuit Mill, but don't have a large breakfast that day! Gourmet food from scores of food purveyors from the Cape Town area. Only on Saturdays!
Good visit for Saturdays. Trying wide variety of food and shopping of local craft is a must. Go for it if you are in Cape Town on a saturday.

Love . The atmosphere is awesome but it does get a bit too crowded, so go as early as possible!
The fallafel stall is a good lunch choice and espresso lab for
A good cup of coffee.
I enjoyed cacoa as well a chocolate shop where you can watch them make chocolate and buy pure cocoa as well as chocolate shaped spoons!

Excellent and exciting area. Loved the test kitchen restaurant. Excellent service and excellent food. Also visited on Saturday morning, such an amazing and exciting area, lots to eat and buy from local crafts.
So much to see!. Definitely worth stopping at the Wine @ the Mill for a botlle (or 6) of wine or MCC. Reasonably priced and knowledgeable staff!

Popular with a dash of quirkiness. Visiting the Old Biscuit Mill on a Saturday morning gives you a good flavour of Cape Town's quirky and creative side. The place has lots of little shops to browse and the market boasts an awesome selection of great food and drinks. Our strategy was: eat, browse, eat, browse, eat… It can get very busy as it is such a popular place, so it's not for the slightly claustrophobic. And finding parking can quickly become a nightmare, so try to be there early.

Every visitor to Cape Town needs to experience!. Capetonians at their best at this wonderful Saturday morning mainly food market. Fresh food and wonderful vibe make this a must when visiting Cape Town.

Not as big as expected. We went here very early, because we thought it was very big. There are some shops with souvenirs, but most of it is food. we were there in the morning, so not into the food. We already left after 1,5 hour, a bit disappointing. It will be better if you go there to have lunch

Neat. ^That's where The Test Kitchen restaurant is. If you can plan very far in advance, be sure to get a reservation. Six months ahead, and we could only get lunch. But what a lunch. One of the best meal of my life!

Great buzz and variety. The vibrancy at the Mill every Saturday morning is palpable with the extensive selection of international foods and the market stalls offering all sorts of clothing and accessories. It is a must on not only locals' list, but especially for visitors to the Mother City. Get there early!

Saturday Morning Rush. If you don't mind very crowded spaces, not always sitting down when eating and parking in a small, low-income area street a walk away... You will love it! Amazing food and atmosphere with diversity in flavour, culture and price.

Always too busy, over priced food and too many beggars outside. This market is Always too busy, where you have to push your way to buy anything or move any where.Most of the food and drinks are over priced, it's cheaper to eat and drink in a cafe.Outside there are too many beggars tugging at tourist heart strings.The parking is a circus, having to park miles away and walk.I'd skip and go to one of the small local or weekday markets.

Not just for hipsters ;). We visited the Neighbourgoods market on a chilly Saturday morning and spent the entire day sampling the food, and taking in the sights and sounds of the market. As a frequent visitor of the JHB franchise, I liked the fact that the Cape Town market had its own unique character and vibe. We didn't have too much trouble finding a parking spot nearby, but if you are looking to park in the Old Biscuit Mill's parking lot after 11am, good luck!I would definitely make this a stop again on my next visit and would love to try out Test Kitchen.

A fun way to spend an afternoon. We were pleasantly surprised at the Old Biscuit Mill, and were most excited about all of the various items, and particularly food items, available from the various vendors here. A highly recommended stop for those visiting Cape Town.

Charming and somewhat bohemian. This is a must to visit. Especially on a Saturday, but go early as parking is a problem and the place gets very busy. An eclectic mix of stalls and people. Stalls sell mainly food and fresh produce. The choice is overwhelming and the tastes are fantastic. Very reasonably priced. Great experience especially with a group of friends for brunch.

You have to hit the food market first thing on a Saturday. This place is amazing! It may take months in advance to get a reservation at the Test Kitchen but do... And make sure to get their when the best chefs from around Cape Town gather on a Saturday Morning to cook brunch. It is an unforgettable experience.

Only on saturdays!. This place is dead otherwise. Unfortunately I visited on a weekday as I couldn't spend the weekend in Cape Town. Had lunch at Test Kitchen which is another story, but this place is relatively dead! A couple of boutique / designer shops selling great items to nobody, and a few cafes selling coffee to nobody etc. you get the idea...Nevertheless, I don't doubt the Saturdays! :)

A really fun Saturday. Our family thoroughly enjoyed shopping in the open market for gifts -- from crafts and little unique gift items to clothing, and then trying a variety of delicious foods in the food market area. We found it to be very reasonable cost-wise and came away with several fun souvenirs and gifts.

Hidden Treasure for a Saturday Morning. I stumbled upon the Biscuit Mill on a trip to Cape Town a few years back and couldn't believe my luck. The biggest issue with the place is trying to decide what to eat. There are so many amazing food stalls that choosing just one (or even two) things is overwhelming. However, once you've made your selection, going outside to enjoy it in the sunshine makes for an absolutely divine way to spend the day. There are also drinks available, so doing a little Saturday afternoon day drinking outside is something I will definitely put on my agenda for my next trip to Cape Town. Absolute gem!

Great food, great ambiance. Go here on a Saturday without breakfast. In fact, it doesn't harm to skip dinner the previous night. In this nicely located food market with space to sit and enjoy your food you will have a hard time to decide how to fill the limited space your stomach offers. Add to this the design market with beautiful, though pricey, hand crafted items and two hours will have passed before you know it.

Not to be missed by visitors to Cape Town. Arrive hungry to the bustling Saturday market, or visit for fine dining and crowd-free shopping on weekdays. The best way to get there on a Saturday is by cab, or if you have to park, use the parking at the College opposite. Fabulous food, great clothing market, with superb designer stores and arts and craft by some of SA's most well-know creatives. You'll not leave empty handed.

A must for travellers and locals alike. Food food food! A smorgasbord of fresh food and alternative delights! You won't be bored on a Saturday morning...eat, drink and be very merry! Top class stuff which shouldn't only be restricted to Saturdays...

Good reputation Good experience for many Ghastly for me. I may be out of step. I just fail to understand why Old Biscuit Mill is so popular
Sure the Test Kitchen Restaurant is deservedly highly rated Reservations essential
Well what more can I say?

Taste for everyone. As far as Markets go... This is probably the best one that I have been to in the country. There is a flavour for everyone! The market is very well run and there are strict rules for those that have been lucky enough to get a stand so service, presentation and quality are top class! Everyone is very friendly and happy to interact with you. try a little bit of everything to really get a grasp of the good food. Make sure to check out the design section where local tradesmen/woman showcase their craft in true Captonian fashion, lots of little gems to pick up!

Pricey but fun. Rub shoulders with the Uber trendy and pay a fortune for food! This market is hugely popular and very expensive yet fun to visit. Many food stalls and a craft and clothing section as well as cute shops. Go early!

Ol' Biscuit Mill. Saturday morning and its always a hustling and a bustling at the Ol' Mill. The variety of eats and drinks and catching up with friends for brunch is just sublime..... and to shop to take some unusual treats to friends or even to one's own home offers diversity. Freshness.The atmosphere is fabulous, too much to sample from the genuine French, cheeses by the mile, pastries, other foreign cuisines, jams and bottled heavenly fruits, the list goes on and on. Certainly can while away an hour or two quite happily.Parking is a pain unless you are either early or lucky, but it's fun and lively and a great Saturday start. Enjoy !

Fabulous Saturday morning destination in Cape Town. The Old Biscuit Mill- everyone loves it. Everything is on offer on Saturdays from fresh organic food to wine, beer, flowers...you name it! It's such a vibe and is crammed with locals and tourists alike all having the best time. During the week it's open for business as well with a few top end stores selling wares like ceramics, clothing, photography equipment, great coffee, etc etc...and of course th famous Pot Luck Club and Test Kitchen are there as well- amongst the best food in the city! Beware pick pockets on a Saturday and street people on the sidewalks. Advisable to take a cab there if you're from out of town.

Quirky gem. What a nice little farmers market. Packed with fresh produce, baked goodies, freshly made eats, biltongs etc. I suggest heading over early, as it can get really crowded and pretty unpleasant later in the morning. Also quite difficult to find parking when arriving late.Not cheap but worth seeing. Cute stalls and goodies to see too.

Packed food market. The Old Biscuit Mill has a lot to offer: food, drink, jewellery, clothing. Parking, however, isn't abundant and traffic can be an issue. The market tends to get full and there is limited seating. Best to get here early.
Foodie Fantasy. A must when in cape town. The atmosphere is fabulous. There were so many wonderful things to taste I could not decide what is best so try as much as you can.

Highly recommended. Went on a saturday to catch the market. I would advise going as early as possible as parking is a nightmare! This place is filled to the brim with top quality produce. Its quirky, youthful and has a buzzing atmosphere. The food and crafts were of a very good standard, and would make perfect presents. Even without buying, a browse through the stalls is exciting. People watching is a must while you sit on one of the many communal benches sampling some of the finest food Capetown vendors have to offer. There really is something for everyone, from fresh oysters to gourmet pizzas.
Excellent Outing. Excellent idea with lots to look at, fantastic food and fresh produce available. Shopping choices galore. Will keep the family busy for a few hours!!

Great Entertainment. We got there early on Saturday morning 9:05am and still had to park a little down the road - this is worth it. There is a wide offering of speaicalst food for gorumet types. Huge selection of cuisines - go hungry. The place fills up fast though, better stay for lunch and really pig out.

Disappointing during midweek visit. I wanted to see Old Biscuit Mill without the crowds of the Saturday Neighbourhood Market. It would seem however that the food market is the key to this attraction's success. The decor / craft shops mostly felt the same - same style of product etc. The staff inside the decor shops were disinterested and glued to their phones. Some didn't even look up when we walked in and greeted them. No one tried to make a sale. The few food establishments that were open midweek were however very friendly. Would only therefore recommend this as a must do if in Cape Town on extended stay and only on a Saturday.

So many things to see and buy. Lovely place to walk around, variety of things to purchase. Only problem was the parking. Had to walk quite far when I eventually found parking, but well worth the visit!

Great market and variety. We really enjoy visiting the old biscuit mill on weekends. There is a large variety of vendors selling all kinds of interesting items. Sometimes parking is a bit tough to find but it is definitely worth it.

Trendy/arty but a bit generic. Lovely arty stores and people but you could be in Williamsburg, New York or Shoreditch, London. Great to visit if you have several days in Cape Town but not essential if you live in a City with a good arty/crafty scene.

Busy and buzzy. A very vibey spot with some good eateries and a mix of upmarket and craft type shops. Seems to be a big hit with tourists and locals alike, especially on Saturday when the Neighbourhood Goods Market really buzzes.

A Hipster's true north. Fun eclectic collection of craft shops, art dens and cafes. Therein lie all the hipsters in Cape Town. The best part for me was definitely the food market. Grab a slice of pizza, some paella and a glass of wine or bottle of craft beer and try to squeeze into a spot at the tables set up in the middle decorated with freshly cut flowers and candles. Great for instagram photo ops! Beware that the food market packs up early though.

Old Biscuit Mill a Fun Place. We visited the Old Biscuit Mill on a Saturday morning, well, it's only open on Saturdays, in May during our time in Cape Town. Our private guide, Zakkie Parker, took us there on our way to the winelands. I don't know if we would have gone if we had been on our own but what a fun place. I had read about in the guide book but didn't have it down to see. Thank heavens, Zakkie di!Vendors set up their food, drinks, samples of fruit, cheeses, and fresh foods, like a super market all under this one roof. What an experience to walk around and see the various kinds of food! There were so many ethnic foods to try as well, and it was a fun morning.It was great to meet the locals as well and a few college students. We had some crepes with eggs and ham rolled up, fresh squeezed o.j, coffee and just soaked up the atmosphere.It was chilly and rainy that day but we loved it! I think many people may miss this but they should put in on the things to do while in Cape Town. What a treat!

Fresh Food Fun!. So much food, so many people, so many choices, so much fun! Go hungry, conserve your calories before you go because you will get a whopping case of the hungries at this super food festival. So many ethnic offerings eaten by so many different ethnics and everyone having the best time. If you are in Capetown treat yourself to this les than serious venue for foodies. It's the best!
Not to be missed when in Cape Town. Best local dishes and more. Saterday morning well spend. Good food of all cultures and good wine and local beer. Festive atmosphere and just a joll.

Very hip. This is a very hip market in Woodstock. Go there hungry and not only do they have cool local crafts but a food area which is delightful. Have a cider and a prosciutto sandwich drizzled in balsamic reduction and watch the many shoppers spending their rand. You will enjoy hanging with the locals and tourists.
FREAKING AMAZING. Take money and an empty stomach! The food is the best I have ever tasted! Have the Dim Sum! and the Rosti! such amazing stalls that we had to roll out of there

Very popular on Saturdays. This is a tourist mecca on Saturdays. Parking is difficult and congestion is great. If you are going to be traveling in the area, you can probably find better. There are a few interesting options in the food court.

Potluck ...a jewel. A crisp chilled 1998 bottle of Dom...and 6 courses of mind blowing dishes, served by attentive Waiters in a world class restaurant perched on the 6 th floor of an old biscuit mill, rates as our favourite experience ever in cape town

Great Every Time. I've had the chance to go to the Old Biscuit Mill on numerous occasions. I prefer it during a rainy Saturday because it is less crowded. It's great way to nurse a hangover and a chance to try a variety of amazing food.
Bustling - A must-see for tourists and locals alike. Great atmosphere. Go early to avoid the massive crowds. Splurge on the tasty foods. There will be a stall to suit all tastes.

Don't Eat before you go!. Saturday morning, even in the pouring rain this was the best place to be in Cape Town. Homemade treats from jams, coffee, craft beer and pizza to full breakfast or lunchtime meals. Found great tasting chutney and nuts here and samples many other foods too. Crowded though so expect to stand!

an interesting market on saturday morning. when old bisquit mill open up the saturday morning market i don't think any one expected this huge change in the woodstock/salt river area. but the truth is that the impact has made properties rise in value and a new crowd is slowly moving in. it's perfect location close to the city and it suits young urban people. the market is a mix of new designers and delicious food, much of it organic. expect traffic jam from about 10.30

Wonderful shopping and eating experience. Go early especially in Dec and Jan. Have breakfast there and then start to shop and then have morning tea and then have lunch ! all delicious. Parking a bit of a hassle and beware of the guys who tell you that certain spots are legal as they probably are not.

Foodie fun but not for those who do not enjoy crowds. The Biscuit Mill is a popular Saturday morning event and you can expect to find the entire Woodstock area flooded with people. If you can find a way to get here without having to find parking your day will be far more enjoyable. Food is interesting and always delicious. Trendy jewellery and clothes are also in abundance. Bring a BIG wad of cash as this is not a cheap outing, but is mostly worth the money you will spend. Also, there is only one ATM and you will spend the whole day in the line without having brought cash with you. Not a place for people who struggle with crowds. It is especially packed on sunny days.

Always a winner. The Old Biscuit Mill has to be one of the best places and spaces in Cape Town that always delivers.
Love the stuff you can do there and the people who go there - a must do in Cape Town, any day of the week, but particularly on weekends!

worth a visit, but crowded. a morning at the old biscuit mill is worth a visit - there's lots of food and drink to try out and it's always full of people. However, its precisely because it's usually so full of people that you'll either love it or hate it. Standing with food and drink in hand, you'll have to keep your eyes open for an open seat at one of the tables and dash across to get it before someone else does... If you're not one for crowded spaces, you'd probably prefer the Hout Bay market, which is very similar, but more spacious...
so interesting. the neighbour goods market on a saturday is a must . actually the absolute very best food you will eat in cape town in an informal setting .

Go and have a squizz on a Saturday if you can. This is a great place to visit on a Saturday (although it's a bit manic) and also nice (and calmer) during the week - without the market though. A couple of great restaurants too.

Excellent food. Dutch poffertjes, kroketten en bitterballen. Great people, nice atmosphere. And when you're tired of eating good food, just relax on the couches outside. De Old Buscuit Mill is in Woodstock, the oldest area of Cape Town. Enough taxi's to take you wherever you want.

Over-rated. I can't work this one out - perhaps I am not trendy. No seating, over-crowded, over-priced and in a rubbish area. Admittedly, the food selection is delicious. So if you not cost sensitive then you may well love it.
Always fun and vibrant. Every time Im in Cape Town I keep popping in.Its so alive and always something new on display.Love it there.Not to be missed!

A Buzz of Activity. Close your eyes and picture this, a beehive with files of bees moving in opposite directions in every conceivable open space, very ordered chaos. be prepared to be pushed and shoved, especially in the food hall but not in a frightening way. If you suffer from claustrophobia, take medication or keep your eyes closed and get led. Find a spot, sit down, then send the rest of the conquering party to search for food. The ice coffee, pizzas and basically everything is good. An absolute great market place atmosphere and definitely worth a visit. Be warned, parking is a big problem.

Hipster, but worth it for the food/drink. This place was recommended to us by our B&B; she said the area looked a bit "dodgy" and she's right - it looks sketchy when you're parking a few blocks away. However, we didn't encounter any trouble and the market was great. There are lots of shops with unique items - scarves, jewelry, and for some reason a lot of glassware. We went on Saturday when they had more vendors (clothes, jewelry, leather goods, etc.) but the best part is the market. There are so many food vendors and everything looks amazing and fresh - and it's all really cheap. There are also a lot of drink (wine, beer, cocktails) vendors as well. To boot, they had live music. Overall it was a great atmosphere and a great way to spend a Saturday morning.
Dicey neighborhood, but charming mall. This place has two of the best restaurants in the city, a very cool chocolate factory, and a bunch of craft and artist places. Highly recommended.
A given Saturday activity. We try to go back as often as we can to this lovely place. Lots of good foods and drinks. It is a bit pricey though. The small market also have a lot of interesting goods.

Schwarma & a Smoothie worked for me. Came here with my 17 & 19 year old sons on a Saturday lunchtime, like Camden market but so much better. Foodies paradise at reasonable prices. Great place to meet up, hang out.
Arty and great food!. Really crowded and hard to get to food but so much to try - Do not go with an impatient husband , you need time to queue and absorb everything and spend time tating
great place to find clothes/stuff for your home. I thought they have mainly food stuff but was surprised to find great shops with clothes and things for your home. great place!

Best Saturday morning foodie experience. An absolute must-visit when in Cape Town. Go early as later on there can be huge crowds and it can be tricky to move around the food area. Too many amazing foodie experiences to single one out. Well worth dedicating the better part of Saturday to.

Love love love this place. Went here as it was recommended to us Saturday mornings marketAwesome shopping and amazing foodDefinitely not to be missedWe went back the following weekHad fresh coconutLive entertainment by a fantastic couple wish I had bought their cd nowCan't wait to go back next year and I just hope the same entertainers are thereAlso the cold apple cider is a must

Trendy & Vibey. Very popular and loads of interest from the crowds. Many different types of food and coffees with flavours from all over the world. Little space for prams, but young families were there!Arts and crafts outside the food hall for those not interested in eating. Parking is at a premium, so arrive early.Definitely worth further visits.
Very trendy. Take lots of money ! The prices are not so cheap but very enjoyable walk through the aisles of interesting South African art

Fabulously fresh food. This place is amazing, wide variety to satisfy just about everyone, lots to buy and plenty to drink. Loved the champagne stands, the lamb schwarmas is a must, the freshly prepared fillings too many to choose from. Special mention to the "Queen of Tarts" for lovely macarons and cupcakes. On the way out we enjoyed some interesting shopping, do pop into the printing shop. Bought an "air plant as a souvenir. a must to visit.
Mind your toes and elbows. This market looks like it could be fascinating, but is so crowded that it is almost impossible to get to the stalls to see. Possibly it will be easier in mid winter ?
If you in CT you have to go!. This place is awesome, great food, fun and worth going to every time you in Cape town. Its definitely worth a visit for friends and family
Awesome market!. Just what you've always wanted from a weekend market! Awesome shopping and draw dropping food shed (serious – so much amazing food). Defiantly not to be missed.

Perfect place for Saturday lunch. Biscuit Mill is the perfect place to meet with friends on Saturday for lunch. Everyone can choose food they like - from sushi and oysters to paella and steak rolls. Drink selection is good as well - craft beers and wine, teas and coffees, smoothies and fresh coconut water...Not enough seating space makes Biscuit Mill perfect venue to meet new people. Spend a few hours shopping is really easy there - original jewelry, vintage clothe, bath salt, souvenirs, scarfs, photo accessories and much more.
Great food and cheap. This is an amazing place to go and spend a Saturday morning. It is vibrant and there are so many different foods to choose from.

Old Biscuit Mill on a weekday. From other reviews I gather that the Saturday market is a special experience not to be missed. I missed it! I went to see the Old Biscuit Mill on a weekday and I found it very relaxing. There are a couple of shops and one or too restaurants. The popular one is supposed to be very good but they were full. The next place was mediocre and wasn't doing much business at all. The espresso bar looks really good but I did not like the espresso so that was a downer. The wineshop is excellent, they sell many many wines that I know of or heard of that are great, Other shops there are all part of the same setting, semi arty which is fun but after one or two hours you'll have seen enough. I recommend visiting only if you happen to be in the area, don't go out of your way to see the Old Biscuit Mill on a weekday.

Authentic Shopping. A busy Saturday Market place - cash only where you can find all authentic goodies (clothing, artwork and artifacts) as well as lots of fresh food - cooked and uncooked. I found tuna biltong - healthy protein. You can take a tour of the "chocolate factory" and buy the most divine chocolates, fresh preserves as well as condiments. I just loved browsing along the bustling aisles.

Very nice design market. Very nice market with a lot of unique design stuff. And a very delicious and international food market. There are also some artist playing music for a good atmosphere. Lovely place to spend your saturday morning!
Excellent small plates restaurant. This tappas-style. This place is located at the top of an old grain elevator - very cool ambiance. The food was really excellent. I would definitely go again!
Great place. Relaxed atmosphere and much to see and the food selection is great. Parking is a problem so you need to get there early

Pretentious. This market is very pretentious - a place ''to be seen'' rather than an actual enjoyable experience. Earth Fair Market in Tokai or Hope Street Market are both on Saturdays as well and offer much more variety, affordability and interesting goods to buy.

Don't miss it if you are in Capetown on Saturdays!!!. Vibe...great food....beautiful people..craft and art...this is where you can see the young trendy face of "mother city" and you can't miss it if you want to experience CapeTown ....situated in Woodstock it is open on Saturday morning and you can find there so much....from the outstanding food market with the most incredible selection of dishes prepared on the spot, to galleries and small shops and stalls where you can browse and find any sort of things..it is very safe inside the complex so do not be worried about the beggars at the entrance or the unpleasant car guards on the road.

Add it to your Cape Town to-do list. Every town has markets these days, but this is one of the best. Held every Saturday at the Old Biscuit Mill in Woodstock near the city centre, the food is out of this world and there's a huge variety of craft etc in the sprawling complex. It's worth it just to come here for breakfast. It seems every nationality is represented in the food halls, with people preparing mouth-watering fresh food in front of you. You can slurp an oyster and sip champagne at a long table next to people eating Bratwurst sausage or Belgian chocolate tarts. It's buzzy, busy and friendly. But you MUST get there early if you want to find a parking spot. We went twice, around 8.30am, and it was already humming.

For food lovers. This is a great place to visit Saturday morning is the best time, but don't have breakfast save yourself for all the fantastic street food. So much to choose from you will be spoilt. There are lots of small stalls and shops as well to browse. Top tip get there as early as you can, as they can sell out fast

Busy Busy Busy. This place on a Saturday is hectic, good vibes, good food, craft beer, organic wine, funky threads and beautiful people from every corner of the planet. A great place that's not too pretentious yet!

Amazing for luxurious dinners!. It seems like no matter where you chose to dine in this lovely revitalized section of the city, the plethora of restaurants, cafe and chocolateria always delivered beyond expectations. Views from the Potluck Club at Sunset are spectacular.

A must if you have free time on a Saturday. If you like to blend in and do as the locals do, the Old Biscuit Mill is a must. The earlier you get there the better! There are tons of food stalls, drinks, and shops to buy art, jewelry, clothes, etc. We bought South African wine and spent more time in the chocolate shop than we probably should have. This was a very unique place and we loved it. It closes at about 3 pm on Saturdays.

Another place in Cape Town that is a favourite. I love the variety that is the Biscuit Mill - from delicate macaroons to boutique wineries - its where I discovered Saltare Boutique wines at 10am one Saturday morning. Its also the place where i added another 2 teapots to my growing collection (on different visits ...) - the latest being one by Sandile Dyalvane, who was inspired by Picasso. To visit Cape Town and to miss out on the eating and shopping experience that is the Old Biscuit Mill would be a big loss

So spacious. The Old Biscuit Mill is home to Neighburgoods Market and other things on the side, which is why I loved it so much. It had a greater focus on the market side rather than the social side (such as the Jozi Neighbourgoods Market).The Market in terms of food stalls seemed healthier and more organic. The weather was great. It was conducive of floor seating rather than standing around waiting for a bench to open up, and the positioning allowed for equal amount of sun and shade exposure.

Non touristic charming place. There are few places that you can buy perfect interesting things for your house. After that you can have rest in a cafe there. I recommend everyone to go there. Because none of the toursist know that place . So If you are the one who don't want to go to touristic places always, you should go.

Local and Lekker. The Old Biscuit Mill is the revival of a part of Cape Town previously plagued by poverty. The mill has been converted into shops and restaurants with a market on Saturdays. There are two great restaurants, the Pot Luck Club with a magnificent view of the harbour and the smaller Test Kitchen. As the latter was rated the 49th best restaurant in the world and the best in Africa, I tried my luck at a booking but as could be expected, the restaurant was booked till mid July for dinner. The market had the most wonderful food with a variety and a difference. The market is busy and space is limited to move. Leave the pram outside. Inside is a great vibe. The arts and crafts are local and delightfully there are no Chinese cheap imports so regularly found at markets in South Africa as such goods are being dumped in South Africa. Enjoy!

Biscuit Mill market. Very busy market. We went on a Saturday ( not sure what days it operates normally) . So many people and so many different food stalls. The music was vibesyand everyone was very friendly. The shops in the same area were different and stocked with clever interesting gifts and clothes

What a busy place!. The place was buzzing with activity because of the Saturday market, crowded and took a while to find parking. However, it has a lovely vibe. Found it "charming" Very chilled atmosphere. Nice to look around even if you don't actually purchase the highly priced goods

Food Experience of a lifetime!. This place is amazing! Every time we go there we have a different taste experience! From the varieties of coffees to the myriad of food stalls selling the most delectable and tasty food. It all looks so good.Go early on a Saturday morning to avoid the rush. There are stores that sell the most quant and unusual gifts and furniture too.Loved every moment.

good on a Saturday. Go on a Saturday and don't eat before you go - try the food market area which is packed with different types of local and international type foods. some of the best restaurants in the country in this building
Money well spend. Food is delicious! Shopping there is really nice! even thought it is always busy, it is not busy in a bad way! but there are manymanymany tourists.

Fun!. Went here a couple of times because it has some really nice restaurants (make sure to reserve spots for dinner well ahead your trip otherwise you're in for a bad time). The only issue is that most of the crafty stores close really early (around 4 PM) and we weren't able to make it to the Neighborgoods Market on Saturday because we didn't know that. But also, it is an interesting visit because you can see how the gentrification process is occurring in Cape Town, as The Old Biscuit Mill is surrounded by more low-income areas.

Get there early armed with an empty belly.. You need to be there before 10am, especially if you have a pram/stroller with you. In fact if you can forget about the pram for the morning. There is so much food and drink, to choose from, all reasonably priced. There is only one cash machine on site (easy to find due to the long queue)!

Best market ever!. This is such an fantastic market! The atmosphere is awesome and food variety so interesting and tasty. The shops are also very nice, especially the beads shop. Go very early to ensure you get parking and to walk through the market and have a look at everything before it gets too crowded (and believe me it does). Weather wise I would say a cool but sunny day is the best.
very good for saturday farmers market. Go there on saturday for the farmers market, shop clothes and/ or food/ drinks/ local produce. Great food, and very nice atmosphere

Awesome! A MUST for foodies. Fantastic market especially the food section, could spend all day there! Would reccomend going near the start of your trip so you can make the most of all the goodies they have for sale!!! A shame it is only open on Saturdays

Get there early as it fills up quickly. I love food markets and this has to be one of my favourites, with a wide range of locally produced fare it's perfect for brunch. Really fantastic coffee, really yummy omelettes and enough baked goods that you can roll out. Don't miss it!

Very busy vibey market. Stunning fresh food and goods market at the Biscuit Mill. Everything from fresh vege's to the most delectable chocolate cake and freshly ground coffee's. This is a must for all.
Food glorious Food. Excellent place to visit and eat-great atmosphere with a huge selection of fresh food & drinks-loads of different shops to browse and people watch♡#LoveCapeTown #gotosouthafrica
Just OK. Went to Old Biscuit Mill on a Saturday morning. Took us about 20 minutes to get there from our hotel. Average local food and average shops.

Great Saturday morning food market. So much choice of food! We were only disappointed that we became full too quick!
Go early as it becomes crowded by about 10.30am
So busy!. I came to the market early to get ahead of the crowds, the food and coffee are brilliant as always. But so busy within an hour we had to fight to escape. worth a trip though
BEST Macroons ever!. I loved the Macroons! I hate how its only open on saturdays when I crave their food during their week!

Fantastic vibe. What a brilliant place to visit and the variety of food and other artisan products available was huge. Dont park at the first space offered it is usually quite a distance. If necessary go past the biscuit mill and turn right where helpful parking assistants will find you a place for R10.

Come Hungry and Be Prepared To Spend LOTS of Time Here. I was totally overwhelmed with all the food stands. Wish i had more time and a bigger tummy to taste all the delicious food.
So many brilliant stores, restaurants and attractions at the Old Biscuit Mill.
On my top 10 list of places to visit in Cape Town.

Don't miss the Saturday morning market. We arrived in Cape Town on a Saturday morning and went almost directly to the Old Biscuit Mill. The food market is trendy, lively and will give you a great overview of the typical Cape Town foods, drinks and snacks, many cooked right in front of you. You can take a taxi from the center to Woodstock where the Mill is located for about R50 but take a lot more money with, as you cannot miss trying all the different delicacies you will find there!

Great vibe and great food. The variety of fresh food and produce is amazing. If you are hungry , first walk through the market before you buy , as there is so much to choose from you could make a mistake. Go early as parking is a problem. Although Saturday traffic is ok .Even if Parking can becomes an issue,It is a must if you are in Cape Town

Not into biscuits? Not to worry! Much more here than just biscuits!. Amazing new concept for a flea market! Using the old mill buildings for little stalls! And the fresh meals served in the big tent was stunning!

Saturday Market!. Try to have as empty a stomach as possible before you come here because this place redefines the phrase "spoilt for choice". When I visited I did 3 laps of the food market before contemplating long and hard about which of the numerous mouth-watering offerings appealed to me the most. Aside from the amazing food there are some really great craft stores here too. There is a great atmosphere and buzz about the place also. If I lived in Cape Town I'd be here every week without fail!

visit to the old biscuit mill in woodstock Cape Town. I loved it! The food products on sale for the most part were the business. I loved the quality and attention to detail I found at the stalls I stopped at. People are friendly and they smile!! Downside: The crowds. At one point I almost had a panic attack! I suffer from claustrophobia so being squished and shoved about was almost much for me. I loved the vibrancy though and the chap playing his "didgeridoo" was fantastic. Would I visit again: definitely
Saturday is the day. Go there for lunch and you can find nice music, cool people and really good food and drinks. I suggest to try the chocolate ice cream at the factory under the elevator
Interesting. Creatively revitalized. One of the better place to visit in Cape Town. The food and restaurants here are highly palatable. Adequate parking.

Great market but very crowded. Be sure to go early to find parking. Great food, try the grilled mushrooms. Goods sold at stalls are very expensive though and the market is too busy with very little places to seat at a table to eat.

food, wine and vintage. loved this place! went there twice, the food is very good, the shops are lovely, design mised with vintage, african crafts, etc. Nice ambiance to spend a few hours. Be early, can be busy, closes at ca. 14h00

Homely meets hipster: the best of all worlds. A superlative market in a superlative city. The caliber of Old Biscuit Mill is high--and reflects the understated sophistication of Cape Town itself. I put together a photo essay of our experience. We went several times during our 3 mo. stay in the area. The quality of food here is remarkable. More for prepared foods than raw ingredients or produce, although there is ample picnic material. You can (and should) get fat here.http://drinkvicariously.com/2014/04/06/photo-essay-cape-towns-food-markets/Top tip would be arriving as early as possible.

Old Biscuit Mill. An awesome vibey, whole food market (Saturdays) in the heart of the city. Wide choice of food and drinks to choose from, occasional entertainment. One of those 'must do' places when in Cape Town. Get there early for parking close by, and then sit back and 'people watch' while you eat way too much! When you've finished eating, choose your fresh veggies to take home for the week, and stroll through the shops and galleries in the Mill. Very enjoyable morning out. The Mill is open 7 days a week, but the food market is only on a Saturday. Funky part of town, so visit some of the nearby places as well.

Chic market with food & products to match. Great place for shopping – designer ceramics, gourmet food, African-sourced housewears, some home & fashion accessories. We missed the Saturday Neighbourgoods market (www.neighbourgoodsmarket.co.za), but you still have an excellent choice of eateries: Saucisse Boutique deli, The Test Kitchen and The Pot Luck Club – you need to book! We liked the ‘Plush Props’ store, which had wooden plates we spotted in many Franschhoek restaurants.Worth a visit to this place, if you wish to find that something extra above the standard souvenir shacks in Waterfront/Bay Harbour area. There are many creative/advertising agencies based around here so the look and feel is more chic!

Market day. We visited Saturday when it's the food market Loads of lovely foods to try and buyPermanent shops to buy traditionally produced township products , supporting locals :-)Need to visit a couple of times at least to be able to experience all the different types of foodBring cash for the stalls

Fun to do but watch out if you have food allergies. The Biscuit Mill is super fun and vibey on a Saturday with amazingly tantalizing food to choose from for brunch/ lunch or to snack on. Be warned if you have food allergies p, e.g. gluten intolerant. There is very little for you to choose from and the place is so rammed with other hungry people, that very few have the patience for you to ponder what to do; they'll either elbow you out the way, steal your seat, or shrug and move on to the next, seemingly more interesting person behind you in the queue.

A nice way to spend a Saturday morning. We visited here in feb and were worried about parking seeing as everyone tells you how popular it is. But not to worry always someone showing you a place to park for a few rand. The market itself was very busy but def worth it, we got ourself some yummy food and drink and sat down in the sun without a care in the world :) def recommend.
Nice Market. Very nice market in Woodstock. Fresh products and stuff you wont find anywhere else. Its a bit busy though, so just be prepared for crowds.

Lively Saturday market. Brilliant market. Lots of fresh home made products. Lovely place for eating breakfast/lunch. Nice stalls and gift shops. You will always find a gift to buy your friends and family at home. I love Kalila's jewelry. The market is a little crowded.

Cool way to spend a sunny Saturday morning in Cape Town. A very hip market - must see if you are staying in Cape Town over a weekend. Taste The Love Sandwich - I don't usually get excited by sandwiches, but this one is SO yummy!!! Espresso Lab does great coffee. Otherwise, just walk around, enjoy the sun, the music, cool stores and a great vibe. Shame that it closes really early.

A definite Saturday/Sunday morning experience to be enjoyed @ Cape Town. Bustling to the brim with people from all of the planet. If you like your retail therapy on the cool/chic/trendy/unique side then this is definitely the place for you. Good vibe, friendly people, no pushy sales techniques. You look, you browse, you buy or you walk on. And the food selections available is outstanding. Just make sure you go hungry. Way too much to choose from and it's all good.

What a fun morning!!. This market is unbelievably cool! The variety of food, art and design on offer at the Old Biscuit Mill makes it a must see in Cape Town. We visited on a Saturday morning and it was bustling, but that is part of the experience. This is a low cost way to hang out in the morning.
Everything closes early!. An amazing place with beautiful restaurants and a killer saturday market, but be really careful with your timing. Everything closes really early.
Great Saturday morning. A wonderful, eclectic collection of shops and food. We spent Saturday morning there shopping and eating. Such a pleasant place with an excellent variety to enjoy.

Awesome market on saturday. Amazing atmosphere!! U can find a lot of little shops, most of them are selling self-made stuff from cloths to handcraft art. After shopping look for the two halls full of stands with lovely self-made food and drinks (sandwiches, cakes, curry‘s, smothies, cocktails etc.) During eating and sitting in the sun.. enjoy the live music (for expl. Manouche).Best place how to spend saturday morning in Cape town

Sunday morning visit. Was nice to see all kind of food in the same market in a Sunday. Worth to visit the market. I liked the tastes on the market. There were also some other suvenier shops around the food market.

old style eating. just roll up very casual, grab a bite, sit schoolroom style, chat with next person, check out the homemade items and all the countryside type offerings. not your usual table menu. then browse all the shops, stalls, verandah "tiendas" (anything goes)
another buzzing market with good food. i just liked everything. especially my painting by arthur an african artist that i bought on the street just outside the market.
Brunch. What a nice cosy place to have a brunch with your colleagues...I'm sure to make my way there again.The atmosphere is so relaxed. The staff so friendly and professional. What a great venue.

Yumalicious!!Do not eat for a day befor you visit!!!!. A wonderful way to lose saturday morning--the best food and interesting market stands.OK so its a bit chi chi and not really african --its for the wealthy foodies---but --its worth experiencing.The local food being cooked on site is mouth watering --everything from falafels to biltong--champagne and coffee---the smells and atmosphere are great.It is easy to reach by taxi and then i walked all the way back to the Castle --about 20 mins --a great morning .if you want a real lunch time treat ---book the TEST KITCHEN --i didnt and ate way too much just wandering around but I ve heard amazing things about this restaurant,

One for the cool kids. Situated in a very hip, up-and-coming suburb. A market with some of the best food, drink and music in town, as long as you have absolutely no issues with invasion of personal space. Noise and laughter is a guarantee, but well worth it while walking with a glass of bubbly to help you laugh along

A must visit. What a treat. A friend recommended that I try the Biscuit Mill. What a treat. The fresh food market is only open on a Saturday and can get really busy. It is a lovely experience though. There are also many little shops that you can wonder in and buy goodies. I would recommend eating at one of the restaurants, the food looked really good and little less manic to the fresh food market. A joinable experience and remember to go there hungry.

Fun Morning. Loved the Biscuit Mill, lots of quirky little stalls and shops, many exciting foodie places with samples available for tasting. A great vibe. Don't forget to wander down Albert Road to see the other shops. Some amazing unique things to see and buy

Go Hungary. What a perfect way to spend a Saturday, go early as it gets very busy and skip breakfast as the choice of food there is fab, it will be packed but it is a must do, has a great feel good factor. Be mindful of your surroundings!

Fascinating development...up and coming.... Worth a visit to browse...Saturday markets are fascinating...a bit concerned at times re crowd safety and the possibility a fire could break out with some of the market cooking!! Interesting shops and crafts.
Try the Pot Luck Restaurant (but book!!)

No better way to spend a Saturday morning in Cape Town. A friend found great reviews about the Old Biscuit Mill online so we headed down on Saturday morning. AMAZING! It was very busy but that helped create a great atmosphere. The choice a different foods is out of this world, you are literally spoiled for choice. There are 2 areas next to one another that sell food for breakfast / lunch, this can be eaten on tables provided in the area of the foods stalls. Great for chatting to other people visiting. There are also items to take home eg olives breads cakes etc etc, all looked amazing. There are also stalls / shops to visit selling all manner of items, clothes, sunglasses, home items, African goods and much more. Late morning a jazz band played in the courtyard, a great pan to chill and enjoy. A must for Cape Town visitors or locals.

What a gem!. We visited the Old Biscuit Mill on a Saturday, when the food market and stores are open. So much fun! The food selection is pretty amazing, so if you are planning on having lunch there, you can easily skip breakfast. Try the Chorizo Ovo sandwich... yummy, and the refreshing orange/ginger/mint tea. Great stores to find unusual, hand-made in South Africa gifts. Bring cash with you, as many places do not accept credit cards (there is an ATM next to the elevator). A wonderful place not to be missed.

Fabulous fusion of people, food, food and food!. Fabulous selection of food and drink to choose from, makes for a wonderful morning out with friends!! Very busy, so get there early. Borders on over-crowded later in the morning. If you are not into crowds and queues and pushing and shoving, think twice. Great for people watching;-)

Great food at Saturdays market / nice shops throughout the week. Come really early Saturday morning if you want to avoid the crowds. As almost all markets, the food is very well presented and delicious. Bought very good honey with ginger and lemon cordial. At the stand of the Woodstock Bakery Get a loaf or two of the best bread in Cape Town. The baker is just a few hundred meters down the road where they bake and sell that mouthwatering bread throughout the week! The shops, those open all week, are of an excellent variety. The Test Kitchen, The Pot Luck Club are Cape Towns best restaurants… I love the Biscuit Mill as well as the shops around on Albert Street!

A must see in Cape Town. I visited The OBM and markets on Saturday after reading about it online. I have to say it was just brilliant.The parking can be tough after 11:00 so if you are driving then be patient or get there early.Once in you have a genuine local market which was packed with locals and tourists alike. The food markets are full with a variety of choice from a great steak sandwich, a selection of omelettes, local craft beers, cheeses, confectionery, sushi, flatbreads and pizzas.I found the whole experience both great value for money and great fun.There are also some great shops and restaurants in the mill... We had a quick drink and a pizza but take a walk around the courtyard and you will find a great art studio, a stunning patisserie shop and a great wine merchant with lots of choice.The beauty of this really is that male or female, young or old, tourist or local, you have something for everyone....Loved it and if you are reading this as a tourist then it's a safe, inexpensive and excellent way to spend a few hours on a Saturday,

Yum!. The perfect place to buy the freshest, good quality, high value food items. From fresh pesto's, to cold meats, pate's, bread and organic fruit and veg, this place covers everything! Get there early to avoid the crowds, which can sometimes be a little unbearable, and make sure that you take a shopping bag with, as you will end up leaving with heaps of goodies!
food heaven for foodies and others. The food at the biscuit mill is very good. Local people and stores present their best. Its a must go to if you like food.
Great place. Nice small shops, but the best thing is the restaurant the Pot Luck club. You have to visit that. Great views, but the service and food are even better

Just fun. I am almost once a month at the Biscuit Mill and it's always fun. It's a place where u will find both tourists and locals. I prefer going there in winter, since it's not too full. Most of the food is good, though it's not about food, but the vibe. But try the guy, who claims to make the best Burgers in Cape Town. They are really good. But a visit is not complete without visiting the wine shop. On Saturday they always have some winemakers presenting their wines and it's great chatting with them. Just spend some hours there and enjoy the vibe.

Great Saturday market. This is a great Saturday market to visit don't eat before you go as there are so many stalls selling deliciously prepared food it will make your mouth water and you will have difficulty deciding what to try. There are also many artisan shops and stalls selling local crafts which are both diverse and interesting, take a shopping bag.

Test kitchen. Fine dining at the Test Kitchen and great shopping in this restored Biscuit Mill in Woodstock area, said to be getting very trendy. Some arty antiquey shops opening, but you need a local to show you around. Albert Road still very bleak mid week with its disused factories, shops and warehouses!
Great place to visit. We were there on a Saturday when the place is at its busiest. It is a must if in Cape Town with clothing and craft stalls a plenty and a food court to die for.,

Incredible food market. the main attraction here is the food. An incredible array of things to taste and then the decision of what to buy. There was great live music on the day we were there and we enjoyed our lunch being entertained by a very talented musician. Very busy and not easy to find a park but worth the trip.

Nice foodie market. Nice food market in an old biscuit factory. Lots of homemade treats, juices, beers and delicatessen products. Good for breakfast, brunch or lunch visit with family and friends. One of the best treats are the large thin pizzas. As it has become something of a tourist destination, its often cramped with little seating space. Also, its indoors in a large not particularly interesting shed like structure so does not have that authentic European market feel. There are some cute shops selling vintage products, crafts and clothing and a couple of good restaurants on site. Parking in and around the market is difficult.

Worth a visit....just!. We had been told two things about the Saturday market at the Old Biscuit Mill:- This is a "must see" venue- Get there EARLYSo, we got there at 08:45hrs and the stall holders were still setting up...so schedule your visit for a 10:00hrs start!There are many stalls selling both food and a variety of items (clothes, jewellery, African goods, ceramics, etc.) but we had expected there to be more "top end" designer crafts folk there which was disappointing.The market got VERY busy around mid-day so getting (and holding onto) seats was problematic and leaving a perch - one at a time, obviously - to get some food was a "push'n'shove" against humanity!Having said all this, we did it (so should you) and it's something else ticked off the list.PS Climb to the very top of the main building to get some worthwhile views of the surrounding area
Pizza and Wine. Enjoy a great Pizzas then relax while the ladies shop and you discuss and enjoy South Africa wines with owner Neil Grant.

Plenty to see but far to crowded. Visited while on holiday with relatives and there are loads of stall selling everything particularly food but unfortunately it was far too crowded to enjoy and we had to park a long way away.However we found another market in Woodstock - Market at the Palms which was less full, had some great food produce and free parking,
Fun morning. Awesome variety of fresh foods from all over the world. Not many foods you won't find at the Biscuit Mill. Be warned though that you must get there early as it becomes extremely busy.
Foodies delight. nice organic fresh food. hive of activity. very cosmopolitan and typical of CT culture. prices are not cheap but neither are the ingredients.
New experience. Take a cab to this hidden gem of some of the best restaurants and boutiques stores to be found very near Cape Town.

Great value fresh produce. If you're in Cape Town and fancy a break from restaurant meals, the Biscuit Mill is a great alternative. On a Saturday they have a fantastic food market with all sorts of food and drink on offer. It all looked great quality and very fresh. There were lots of locals there buying the produce and sitting at the long communal tables to eat. Outside the food market there were lots of stalls selling a range of products mainly to tourists, although there were a couple of interesting shops selling local artefacts, interesting art, tables etc.Definitely worth a visit.

very yummy market on a saturday with delicious brekkie options, just very crowded. The biscuit,mills saturday morning market offers interesting clothes and wares and the mist Delicious foods to take away or eat there, but its very crowded

Bun-fight. This is a vibey and trendy market. The selection of foods is excellent although quite expensive. It is VERY busy. In my opinion not worth the pushing and shoving. You can hardly move! Forget about carrying a drink without spilling, or finding a place to sit and eat. Younger people might not mind this and will enjoy the atmosphere. Not for me!
Crowded but interesting. On Saturdays they hold a street fair that is very interesting. Several local food options and handcrafts.
Exciting tastebud experience. Although the weekend was very hot, the place was awesome, food yummy and goods on sale varied. A must visit when in Cape Town

Good Experiance. This was a fun market place built up around The Old Biscuit Mill, not too many stalls but a great place to go at the weekend especially for foodies, good choice of brunch/lunch type foods. Very busy which gave it that buzz.

Great selection. Parking may be a bit of a problem or expect to park a distance away and walk.There is a great selection of places to eat at and the only problem one has is deciding which one to choose. Both places we had food from were great. Atmosphere great and band contributed greatly to this.
The best. Should have one of these the Perth, Australia...the best food, drinks and atmosphere and only way to spend at Saturday !!!
