vintage style! i love it!. first of all, you sure have to check out the market on saturdays. but also the mill itself is quite neat! vintage style, which i love and a cute art gallery. on top you find a cafe with a great view!

I could spend every day here. This is my kind of vibe and scene and I could have spent all day every day here. We went here to go to Test Kitchen and then came back on Saturday when the Neighborhood Food Market opened at 9 and ate breakfast there. make sure to go when it opens cause it gets super crowded and is truly a treat. Then we stayed fro a few hours to shop the unique stores, many of which showcase designers that are also available at SAM on Bree street. Was an excellent day, with live music, beer, shopping food and a great vibe. When I return to CT this will be the first place I go back to.

Great food and great fun ... Especially Sat Mornings!!!. Never seen a great variety of food stalls (highly recommend the Eggslut muffin), boutique beers and wines, plus a range of funky stores in the one location. Pumping atmosphere on a Saturday morning with the city chic crowd doing brunch - really good fun. I wish they had something like this is Sydney!! A great Capetown experience ... After you've done all the other stuff.

Make sure you're hungry. The food market offers very good quality food of every corner of the world. You can take your plate or cup and sit at the long tables and mingle... Check out what the other ones are having, comment on it, ask their opinion and then, order some more!

Great urban buzz with a variety of shops. Urban regeneration at its best - using old buildings and turning them into design, restaurant, coworking hubs done best at Old Biscuit Mill. A variety of shops on site, with great restaurants and even better views!

Fabulous shops and eateries.. The development of the Woodstock area as a shopping and eating destination centres on the Old Biscuit mill. There is parking right in the centre and lots of intersting places to browse and eat. This is a new addition to Cape Town since our last visit and it is leading a re-development of the whole neighbourhood, with some quirky and off-beat shops within a couple of hundred yards. We finished our morning off with lunch in the Pot Luck Club in the tower part of the mill.

Be there at 08:30 to avoid the crowds. The big drawback of the Mill is the crushing crowd. It can really ruin your afternoon, which is why I always ensure I'm there by 08:30. All stalls are ready to help you, but there are hardly more than 20 or 30 customers about at that time. By the time you've finished your artisan breakfast the crowd will be in action, but you'll feel relaxed and ready for the day.

Great Saturday Brunch. A fabulous destination for Saturday brunch. An old factory turned into young designer outlet. Everyone chic gathers on Saturday for an incredible food fest. It is like a farmers market but with an amazing array of delicious food and drinks. It is also where you will find The Test Kitchen restaurant - but you need to book well in advance.
So nice and special. This place is simply the best.It is unique and vivid.Lovely crowd on saturday morning.We all go a bunch of people and eat and drink too much !
Gotta see!. Foodies will love this place. Everything is freshly made and they neighbourhood market is great gem. Make sure to get there early as it gets really crowded on Saturdays!
An experience. There are plenty of dainty little stalls and definitely worth the experience, but be prepared to be trampled as it is always packed.
Great food, busy place. Very popular place, very crowded but it was good experience. There was great variety of local food and drinks, some clothes and art and there was also some nice live music.

Amazing variety of food. I had a really good time at the Old Biscuit Mill, i was surprised to see such a great little market in South Africa, the market had a good relaxing vibe and a large variety of food and drinks.

over crowded and overpriced. this place seems to be hugely popular, but I will not go there again. It is very crowded and the food at the market (although very nice) is over priced. It is situated in a not very nice part of town and I felt unsafe walking around in the main street.

Not to be missed!. Get here on a Saturday morning and enjoy a few hours people watching - there will be some weird and wonderful music happening. The market is an absolute blast - such a range of delights. Grab some food and go the back of the market for a beer or glass of champagne. Enjoy all of the cool shops and the general vibe of this unique woodstock gem.

Definitely Worth A Visit. Be sure not to miss a Saturday At the aloe Biscuit Mill! The selection of tasty treats is unbelievable! My girlfriends and I chose to buy various meals and share them so that we could taste a whole load! Nothing Short of Yummmmmmy!! As you walk around the market you could be forgiven for thinking you were lost to a market in France! There are also loving stands selling some handmade crafts, and some lovely clothing.A Great day Out!
Great place. Liked everything, all the home made goodies are delish. Nothing there thats not to like. Yummy food and very busy if you don't get there early

Food, wine, people. One the the best markets I have been to, and I love markets. Outstanding food to eat there, the pizza is my favourite, but nearly open ended selection, all made by individuals, most of it on the premises. Great selection of craft bear and fair selection of wines. Also great place to buy groceries, organic vegetables, meat and responsibly caught fish. Stunning breads and condiments. A must do for Capetonians and visitors. Note, go early, it gets busy, very busy.
Busy but nice. Great coffee and fresh oyster with bubbly. Mosh pit busy on a saturday morning. Overall nice place for a short market visit if you don't mind crowds.

everyone should make this their saturday chillax ndawo*plc. The markt! OBM! I love thes place! The buzz! The people! *make that the beautiful funky people of the world! I'm talking fashion, accents,I love the diversity that the OBM has to offer! Here u can meet the gal next door and on the same breath bump into Ryan Goosling!* No one shud ever come to cpt and not experonce this, it would be a crime!My personal favourite stand is the tuna stand. It sells fresh tuna. Salad, seared tuna , tuna burger, ooh did I mention the yellow tale spring rolls! I always get greedy and have everything. Well almost everything coz their prices are so affordable. My dessert choice. The lady who sells cake! Carrot cake slice for only 20 rands! Ooh so good.. And she make sthe best chai latte in cpt! The secret she told me , was that she mixes her own chai spices, I wrote the recipe somewhere and I lost it! Must ask her again next time I'm there.If u are a non alcohol drinker like me, there's a ladywith a rooibos tea (cold) stand , it is the most refreshing drink ever! Served cold with lots of ice and mint!The vibe is just soooo!* ayoba! Go on a hot day. (I shud actually check it out on a cold day) shud be fun too!!I love this market! It is a must experience

Treats galore. Lovely place to visit on the weekend for their market, be prepared for long queues but you can always reward yourself with a glass of wine in the courtyard. On the opposite side there is a vast area where the food is displayed, from breakfast, mains and puddings, to organic veg, chocolate and teas. Whatever you desire you should fine it here.

BEST RESTAURANTS. The fresh food stalls with their mouth watering dishes is a foodies rush! If you can't satisfy your tastebuds at the stalls walk across to some of the best Restaurants in Cape Town. A must on your list when in Cape Town
amazing. something awesome for intelligent tongue ;) make sure you go there hungry! Its closed during the week
To crowded. Sounds okay on paper but the main thing there is the sale of food. Very crowded and really not enjoyable

Fantastic remodeling with unique shops. This is a place to add to your list when you visit Cape Town, little shops filled with art, wine, and local crafts, but at a higher end, so be prepared to pay a higher price.Their is secured parking but it is at a fee.I had reservations at The Test Kitchen which is rated as one of the top 100 restaurants in the world, and my god was it. Make your reservations way in advance, because it was the best meal i had on my entire trip to South Africa. Read my TripAdvisor review for the Test Kitchen.
The Best. The Old Biscuit Mill is an absolute joy to visit. Fashion, food, atmosphere ... all there in massive quantities --- the best way to spend a Saturday morning in Cape Town.

Quality stuff in a nice setting. An old time market with quality vendors, products and produce. It may be in a rough section of town, but it is an oasis. It is a must-see-must-do. Take a taxi back and forth, though. The area immediately adjacent looks interesting with many neat buildings, decorated with wild paintings. Beyond the first couple of blocks, however, you are truely on your own as a foreign dude. Do not go there. Take a taxi.

Saturday morning treat. What a brilliant spot to spend a Saturday morning - absolutely delicious freshly prepared food - with enough variety to satisfy even the pickiest eater. And when you have sampled all your tummy will allow there are a whole selection of art, crafts, fashion, jewellry stalls and shops to explore. Excellent live music... Just get there early the crowds can be overwhelming!

DO NOT eat before you visit...!!. What a fab place!! WHY don't we have more of these in the UK !?? So many stalls full of the most amazing looking and smelling food !! plenty to sample but good luck deciding what to eat :) it gets BUSY !!! its a struggle to walk around and finding somewhere to sit can also be a pain but it is sooo worth it.. if your a foody, enjoy fresh, well put together LOCAL food then you must check this place out.. the locals beer (darling) is good and if the weiss beer is there !! YUM..You may struggle to park but the guys around helping you park, don't be worried, just hand them some change and they will keep an eye on it you, they are quite comical, friendly guys..

Great outdoor ambience. A must visit for all travellers - esp on a saturday morning. Great vibe and a feast for all tastes. Its very easy to spend the whole morning walking around sampling wares and buying trinkets

must visit on a saturday morning. the biscuit mill is a hype of activity on a saturday morning with varied food choices.
one is not short for choices and the coffee lab is a must visit place for a cuppa
the place is abound with positive energy and can lift the spirits of anyone looking for a :pick me up"
Great vibe. Get here VERY early if you want to get to the food stalls! Place is packed, Interesting food, quirky shops, well worth a visit.

I simply love this place. It's plain and simple - food galore. There's an awesome outdoor environment, tons of food stalls, all types of foods and plenty of people around. Parking is always a challenge so take a cab or come very early. Also accept that you may or may not have a comfy place to sit....
Something for everyone. The venue caters for all and, depending on the day, will take a few hours out of your day at least. Saturdays longer!

Hoers disapired. À more relaxing and nive enviroment is hard to find in CT.
Any kind of food so come hungry and just stroll around without benig in rush.
Best tips would be to be there ealier than late due to more people comes around midday.

Best food market I've ever been to!. This place is brilliant and is enough to make me want to move to Cape Town. The market stalls here on a Saturday are world class. There are lovely local clothes, jewellery and leather goods designers where you can pick up great gifts that are set apart from your standard African tourist nic-nacs, but the most amazing part of the Old Biscuit Mill on a Saturday is the food market!There is everything you could want to buy, and more. Do you feel like champagne and oysters for breakfast? no problem. How about an amazing rosti with smoked salmon, poached egg and hollandaise sauce? sure! Bagels, biltong, dumplings, fudge, freshly brewed coffee, HUGE fresh paninis with every topping under the sun, jams, olives, cheese, pastries, fresh juices & smoothies, fresh flowers, organic produce... the list goes on! Everything is made with the highest quality and freshest of ingredients. It's one of those places where you could spend all day. Go for breakfast, stay for lunch and leave with a bunch of ingredients that could see you through afternoon tea and dinner. My tip would be to get there as the market opens at 9am, as by 10am it is already packed liked sardines! Also make sure you take a walk through the suburb of Woodstock, there's great vintage and furniture stores.

Well worth a visit. Lots of small shops selling ceramics, handicrafts, art and clothes. The prices have risen considerably since our last visit 3 years ago. The food market can be VERY crowded and busy during the holiday season (watch your handbag/purse). Great atmosphere anyway. Try to be there early.Quite a few beggars at the entrance.

The BEST restaurant in CPT. Great atmosphere and incredible food at The Pot Luck Club. The quirky 'Biscuit Mill' area is very relaxed and on Saturday mornings there's a fabulous market selling everything from homemade sweet and savoury treats to gifts, clothes and shoes.

Great shops and the Saturday market is too good to be true!. I just love the shops at the Biscuit Mill, and I can truly say that the Neighbourgoods Market on Saturdays has the best food that I've EVER seen in a market in the world. True top value and quality. LOVE IT LOVE IT LOVE IT!

Nice artwork but too crowded. Several years ago, the venue was still a somewhat well-kept secret. This is no longer so and it was literally packed during our visit. If you like shopping for art and trendy souvenirs, it is still a spot worth visiting.

For the 'trendies'...... A hub of international tourism.....this place is hot for trendy international giftware and full of tasty food choices. The place is absolutely packed with tourism, with people looking for something 'different' from the main shopping mall. Check out times for when the market is on....well worth a visit.....reminds me of a hot Camden market.....

great place but very congested in food hall. wow such a variety of fantastic food. You need to go very early as it is very popular and becomes very crowded. Great craft items for sale in small shops in vicinity. A must see, an experience

Worths the visit!. Really interesting place to visit, this street market happens every Saturday on the Woodstock neighborhood. There's food for all tastes and for a very reasonable price, besides the souvenirs shops, where you can find some unique pieces (these can be a little more expensive). I recommend the paella guy and the dumplings!
Awesome place. A vibey funky place to go on a Saturday. We liked the diverse restaurants and the different shops that were there.

Yum but touristy and packed. I've been to the market a few times and must admit the earlier the better, at least for me :) After 11am it gets really really packed which for me makes it less enjoyable. But anyways, the food is great and relatively affordable. My favorite are the rotis at the juice stand to the left upon entering the first hall.The shops close by are also nice with lots of crafts and much much more. Don't miss the view over Woodstock's roofs you can get when going up all the way at the back :)

A bit of Europe or America in Cape Town. The sophisticated gourmet offerings at the biscuit mill on a Saturday morning surprise the most seasoned of travelers.To grab a bite then mingle with your fresh Kale and Lettuce juice amongst visiting students at UCT for a semester or merely visiting french german and dutch tourists is truly amazing. A uniquely Cape Town experience particularly regarding the quality of the offerings. I also love the craft side where Andile shows his ceramic talent off as well as the chocolaterie and the outsized digital store with images of Persian Rugs attached to the cement floor.

Great for food pricey shopping. We went here to pick up some souvenirs however we ended up grabbing food and leaving to get souvenirs elsewhere as the shopping was more for locals... Pricey large items not meant for bringing home abroad.

Great if you go on Saturday. The big market day at The Old Biscuit Mill is Saturday, and I wouldn't go any other day. We explored fabric shops, antique shops, coffee and pastry shops, crafts shops and stalls, and a HUGE market of dozens of types of delcious ethnic foods and wines. You can eat and drink there or take-away, as you wish.

Had a gret time on Saturday. What a lovely place to shop and eat, an atmosphere that I have not experienced in a while, fabulous? I loved all the diverse range of shops and sitting outside enjoying a meal, people watching.

Disappointing. After reading reviews in TripAdvisor we were intrigued to visit Old Biscuit Mill and to explore what it was famous for. After we arrived we saw little courtyard with closed restaurants and some local shops. The only place to eat was serving sandwiches and coffees/teas. Zero people around. The ones working there did not seem welcoming. Maybe it was a bad timing, but for now I think it was a waste of our time and money, as it is far away from city center and one has to grab a cab to get there.
gourme food!!!. amazing markets and stalls! some of the best restaurants i ever visited! upmarket and very refreshing and entertaining!

Vibey market. The Old Biscuit Mill is a wonderful food market with huge variety from breads, cheeses, cakes, to burgers, curries - you name it. The market does get extremely busy and parking is a problem so try and get there early like 09h00 to avoid hectic crowds.
Lovely way to spend a Saturday. Really enjoyed grazing my way around the food stalls and looking at the vintage shops. Picked up fresh produce and some nice thngs for a picnic as well!

Good for Saturday Morning Brekkie. Crowded but great to go to and sample (ok buy) the beers and feeds..... lots to see, eat, and watch.
Definitely recommended to all so go and do it.

Don't eat breakfast before you go.... My boyfriend and I arrived around 10am on a Saturday in Dec and the place was buzzing. Lots of really delicious foodie treats and all sorts of drinks to choose from beer on tap, glass of bubbles, Rooibos Ice Tea (with vodka). The best part was being in the atmosphere sharing long tables with strangers and buying local produce from the growers... yummy chorizo, cakes and olive jams etc. The shops selling clothes and art were a bit pricey and we didn't see anything at caught our eye. Will definatly go again for the food. Taxi cost R65 each way from central CT.

Wondeful market. We waited for the only Saturday to arrive because everybody told us that the Old Biscuit Mill is excellent. And it was true.Beautiful and colorful market...full of good merchandise...food... clothing crafts....

Great, but take care..... We had a wonderful experience visiting the biscuit mill and savoured all the wonderful goodies on offer. Rounded it off with a perfect meal at the Test Kitchen! However, when we got back to our car that was parked in the road (because the parking area was full), our window was smashed and an iPad stolen from under the seat. So please take care and check that you park in an area where security guards keep watch.

A must for food lovers. What a fantastic experience! We went on a rainy busy Saturday morning and although it was a bit crowded you quickly get sucked into the lively vibe. There are a lot of interesting arty stalls/ shops where you're sure to find souvenirs or gifts for friends or loved ones. The highlight is, however, the enormous food/ fresh produce hall with interesting and delicious foods and desserts, beers and wines. You will want to go back again and again until you've tried everything because at the Biscuit Mill you really are spoiled for choice. Go hungry!Parking is a bit of a problem though, and we parked quite a distance from the Biscuit Mill in kind of a dodgy area, but we've been told by the locals that arriving early on a Saturday morning will be your best chance to secure a parking close by.

no thank you.... Firstly parking is an absolute nightmare. You cannot move inside - it was totally over crowded - you cannot get close to a stall to buy something - the stall owners are unfriendly and irritated - no thank you... never again

over priced and too busy.. When I went to the Saturday market, there was little that made me want to return. It was far too overpriced and seemed to be mainly for the tourists. It was so busy that one had to fight to find either a place to walk or sit. I wouldn't recommend the Saturdays. But if one goes in the week, it is quite nice, some lovely shops and an amazing pizza restaurant.

Sat Markets are fantastic. The regular shops and restaurants are great (you can pick up some unique souvenirs that are different from the standard) but the place really comes to life on Saturday for the Neighbourgoods Markets. There are amazing food stalls for both things to eat on the spot or for picking up ingredients, but the wine stalls and bars give the place a fun vibe that make it a great place to go for lunch with a group of friends.

Fantastic. Having been to Cape Town many times I am not sure why we have never been here before. Tricky to find but It is now a must visit everytime we come. DO NOT eat breakfast before you go - the food available is vast and absolutely gorgeous.

Go on Saturday. This is such a fun place. We went during the week for to eat at the Pot Luck Club (which is excellent) and unfortunately, the shops close by 4pm. We went on Saturday and it was wonderful. The back area is just a huge food/fresh produce market, and the front area is clothes/funiture etc shops. The vibe was exellent. I recommend you take a cab there and there are plenty of cabs that are standing around that you can use on the return journey.

ARTISAN SHOPS. A short taxi ride out of Cape Town to an old factory which has been turned into a conclave of shops selling artisan goods & unusual gifts, African products, furniture. Quite a few restaurants.Worth a visit.

The Pot Luck Club - Wow !. At the top floor of the Old Biscuit Warehouse is an amazing place to eat, very basic look to tables with an open kitchen, the food was incredible, each dish is like a Tappas, but what different tastes, a must if you can get a seat.

Its a vibe!. The Neighbour Goods market on a Saturday is really lovely, there's is a great variety of food choices for all palates to eat right there while you're browsing the wares of local designers or fresh goods to take home! The parking is a bit of a problem so I would recommend public transport and be prepared for this places popularity to be very apparent with the the numbers of visitors but it is definitely something to go check out.

Go on an empty stomach. To appreciate this culinary delight you must go on an empty stomach. The Old Biscuit Mill is a must see experience if you go to Cape Town. It is set in the old port district which is amazing in itself. The market has many stalls selling such homemade delights as artisan pesto, liqueurs in chocolate cups, freshly pressed passion fruit juice plus every type of lunch time snacks that you can imagine. I ate a variance of Eggs Benedict on bubble and squeak pancakes with smoked salmon - exquisite! The stalls are set around the side, then every one sits at communal trestle tables in the middle. The centre also has some excellent craft shops on the site. A must for all visitors to Cape town. The market is only open on a Saturday morning mores the pity.

Must visit.. The food products on sale at this Saturday only market are just superb. I headed back there the 2nd November, which was also the second day of this years visit to The Cape. I headed straight for the butcher and bought a load of superior meat at very fair prices, which will keep us going until next month. Included in the selection were 2 chickens the size of small turkeys, Karoo lamb, which is almost on a par with Welsh lamb,some excellent steaks, and the best veal chops that I have tasted in many years. I also bought some of the most fantastic sirloin biltong from another stall, several artisan produced local cheeses and charcutery.Next visit will be with the wife, so I expect some of the fine looking cakes and biscuits that are on offer,will also be heading my way.

Homemade delicious food and vibrant atmosphere. Old Biscuit Mill is one of those places which astonishes you as you walk in. Countless countries' culinary masterpieces are displayed here, all homemade and mostly organic. Trust me, you will find everything you are looking for, from Argentinian to Portuguese food! The atmosphere is vibrant on the weekends, but you better get there early if you want to get your hands on the delicacies Cape Town has to offer.

Cullinary Experience. What a culinary experience! We had spend the morning part at the food market diving into great food and drink while sitting back and doing some interesting people watching! Ended it off with lunch at The Test Kitchen! Great day!

Fantastic!. Wow! This is must if you're in Cape Town. Best food/ service/ atmosphere in relation to price. Take a seat at the bar so you can see how the kitchen works like an oiled machine! We were very lucky because we did not make a reservation so if you would like to go there, please do!

Fantastic place for a breakfast. You will find a large variety of food and drinks from CapeTown cafes and shops, inside the Biscuit Mill every saturday. Be there before 09:00! Good food for a very low price.

One of the best experiences we ever had in Cape Town!!!. The shops are great, but greater still is the fodmarket, that starts around 12. There the locals from all over start selling selfmade goodies, which you can eat then and there, or take away etc.The atmosphere is just splendid, the food is mmmmmmmmmmmm!!We love it so much that every time we come to Cape Town we plan in a saturday (it is only open on saturdays, although the shops also open during the week) especially for this!!!

Awesome market. This is similar to the Brooklyn Flea in NY if anyone has ever been. Food options are great. The shops also sell art and clothing - I recommend making sure you're not buying mass produced Chinese made goods (a scarf we bought there was unfortunately just that) - that can be rather unique.

Best Food Market. I have been to many food markets, in South Africa and overseas, but must say that I enjoy this one the most. Every time I visit Cape Town, I make sure my stay covers a Saturday morning, so that I can stock up with local fresh homemade delicacies! Don't eat breakfast before you arrive, because there are so many diverse stalls, that I am sure that anyone will find something interesting and delicious to eat. It opens at 9am, so get there before 10am, otherwise you won't find parking, and you'll have to elbow your way through the crowds. All portions are generous, albeit a little expensive (around R40 and upwards). Definitely worth a visit if you are in Cape Town!

Loved it, one of the highlights. Being a lover of food markets this was one of my highlights of my 3 days in Cape Town. The food selection is varied with really healthy and very tasty options. Try the Love Sandwhiches - awesome and soooo generous. It's not large but we still spent almost three hrs there tasting and eating and drinking.

Wonderful local market. Great place with lots of atmosphere!! Very popular and only open Saturday - get there early. Very crowded with lots of locals sampling fabulous food & drink (alcoholic one's too) plus stalls selling a miriad of goods including artwork, antiques, clothing, souvenirs & so much more. Mostly indoors so weather not a problem. Finding a seat to watch the world go by might be more difficult. Great fun!!!
Old Biscuit Factory market.. A very good weekend market .... with some excellent food to be tasted ...... don't have breakfast before you visit the market food area!!!

Best Market Ever. If you want to experience something totally different the The Old Biscuit Mill will definitely blow your mind away. There is crafty and all sorts of markets to shot at. The food side is so awesome that you can get anything your heart desire. Parking can be a problem but go early and it will be fine. You will find anything from food , fashion and art.

Tourist trap? Still a great one-stop CT market experience. OBM has evolved over the past 3 years, from a small neighbourhood market to the most hip, see-and-be-seen Saturday morning pilgrimage worshiped by locals & travelers! Has it become a tourist trap? Local residents like myself will argues YES - over priced food, artisan produce and fashion. Avoid the market after 9:30am if you get claustrophobic among crowds, because you will feel like you are in a sardine can.That being said, it is still a great one-stop market experience to showcase Cape Town's glory. OBM's restored mill adds to its rustic charm, the vendors there have the highest quality produce, preserves, meats, fish, you name it. Come people-watching and mingle with a diverse crowd, beer gardens are a summer-hit and its a guaranteed good time. Enjoy with a pinch of salt, as OBM's price tag does limit itself to a certain demographic of visitors.

far too crowded. impossible to park, too many people, everything is too expensive. It is over rated really! a car guide told me to park in a particular place, and when I came out (having spent far too much money), the police were ticketing the cars in that area, with the car guide no-where to be seen.

A bit of everything for everyone. You cannot go to the Biscuit Mill on a saturday and come away sad. The food is excellent and there is something for everyone. We love the champagne and oysters for breakfast and end up staying for the paella for lunch. There is everything for the health conscious to the very un-healthy. Besides the food there are stunning outfits made locally and you can stock up on fresh veggies and organic meats. There are treasures, trinkets and home made soaps. But mostly you'll love the atmosphere and the people. Don't miss this saturday market :-)

Saturday is for eating. The food market is fun and accessible, limited by your stomach and budget. Many interesting stores and galleries, better than the typical African Craft shops. With the Test Kitchen as a food anchor, this is best considered an amazing food mall with two person foodies offering a range of beers, drinks, and finger foods.

Fun at the Old Biscuit Mill (OBM). The OBM is a really cool place to visit for food and a cool vibe. It's really pricey if you're a local, but that's probably because it attracts so many tourists - I'd say mostly Dutch and American. People who visit are young adults, and university students, but folks come with their young kids and parents too.Bring cash, R100-R200 there's only one ATM - which wasn't working when I was there.Must Eat - prices average R35 per meal and R15 per coffee/hot choc and R30 per smoothie: - Grilled Mushrooms (try the pink oyster)- Fresh Smoothies (try the peanut-butter smoothie)- Organic coffee and chocolate (try the "hot-cold" hot choc and the Sumatra coffee)- Home-made ice-cream (try the banana flavour)It gets very crowded, so try to be there at 10h00 on a Saturday - it's not open on a Sunday. You'll struggle to find a place to sit and eat and many people actually just sit on the floor outside, which is totally acceptable at the OBM. Soft-close is at 12h00, you really don't want to be there after that, stalls close off soon after.

Hipster Heaven. High Points: live music, great food at most of the multitude of stalls, craft beers.Low Points: shopping is overpriced, everything else is very pricey for SA standards, and it's very crowded.

Stunning food market. We went to this market on the recommendation of our B&B (Boutique @ 10) - the food selection was amazing and of the highest quality and taste. It was really crowded, so brunch might be a better option than lunch although I'm not sure if all the meals would be ready.
Don't Thing About it, just go.. Perfect for an Saturday morning brunch and for some shopping. A paradise for foodies. Taste and drink everything you can... it's all good.

Great for foodies. My husband and I go here a few times a month on a saturday for the market. We are foodies and love to graze, sampling and sharing items. You cant go wrong with most of the food stalls. Tip- get there early as it does tend to get really crowded in the food area under the tent. There is also a shopping section with local handmade goods.

If you are in Cape Town on a Saturday, you have to visit the Old Biscuit Mill Factory!. The mistake that we have done, was to have (a poor) breakfast in our guesthouse. Here you can find a lot of variety of food and beverages. I have eaten the best chocolatecake I have ever eaten! You can eat cake, Belgian waffles, chocolate, bread, paella, smoothies, pizza, meat, .... So if you are in Cape Town you have to visit the Old Biscuit Mill!

Definetly worth a look!. Great way to spend a lazy Saturday afternoon. Portion sizes are a bit big at the booths which makes it a bit hard to sample everything, so bring friends to share with and a big appetite.
A real cool cookie!. Great spot for shopping and eating! We bought wines, art, visited the chocolate guys and lunched at Test Kitchen. Cool Cape Town city regeneration at its best!

A taste extravaganza. It is such a wonderful way to indulge your taste buds. The different foods are so well prepared and it is really value for money. It is really like a carnival atmosphere. It comes highly recommended.

Awesome food market. I love all the Neighborgoods market!! The mood, the open-air place, the people, and specially the food and drinks, coffee...
It's a must-go for saturdays morning with friends, family or just yourself..

Eat, drink, shop and people watch and some parking advice. Located about a ten minute taxi ride from Cape Town Central in a re-development area (still a bit dodgy but changing fast). Best parking is opposite the Biscuit Mill in the School opposite for R10.00. A variety of food, best burgers I have ever tasted, the waffles and crepes are just great. A year round market (not just for tourists) housing local men's and ladies fashion, children's quirky gifts and there are shops that are open 6 days a week (pottery, decor, gifts, clothing) when the market is not on. There are a couple of award winning restaurants, book to be sure for a table. Parking is available during the week in the Mill but not on a Saturday. Taxi;s are available just outside, if you are a visitor be sure to get a licensed one or a fixed price. Please be careful with your bags as during peak times it can attract pick pockets (sadly!).. Enjoy this lovely market
cape town must for all!. an awesome vibey market filled with food , foood and more food - such choice and brilliant for a saturday morning brunch and walk with friends

A great place to Eat on the weekend. This market is quite small, so easy to walk around. The food section is extensive and offers you the chance to either sit down and tuck into one of a variety of meals on offer accompanied by a whole host of drinks. Alternatively you can purcahse food stuff to take with you and enjoy at home.The other side of the market sells locally made products ranging from fashion items such as wooden sunglasses & clothes to art and homedecor items.
Amazing attraction. It's got everything a visitor could want. Top class restaurants, the best coffee roaster, delectable chocolotair and boutique wine store. Plus knick knack and decor shops.
Organic all the way. Great food / drinks and tastings, very busy set-up, huge clientel on a Saturday morning, lovely buzz until 2pm. Great for group gatherings.

Too busy. Needs a bigger space. Just too crowded to be enjoyed on the weekend. Manic is all we can say. Perhaps better during the week, however, dont think that the food stalls etc are there. Pity that it was just too manic as it has the potential to be a fantastic place to chill.
One market to many. There are to many markets in cape town and this one is squashed. Not very comfortable. The stalls are ok but quite pricy.

hipster hell. If you like fake people saying things like divine, awesome, amazeballs, bru and dude whilst drinking your organic locally sourced ethinically diverse bio coffee and thinking they are african then this is your place. Bear in mind that to have your african experience you will have to ignore the real african street children who sat wtaching you drink your organic coffee. In a nutshell this is the fakest place on earth. it is ridiculous. Yummy mummy hell

Organic and great taste.... Had oysters and champagne for breakfast, followed by crepes and waffles that were so light I had to double check my fork to see if it was there. After that we bought local produce, wines and condiment that you will not find anywhere. I was especially impressed with the beer selection and is the one market where you can buy it to take home. A definite must see if you can get there.

Saturday MUST DO. We enjoyed a lovely informal breakfast amongst the very many people who frequent this popular venue. Sipping bubbly sitting on a bale of hay having smoked salmon rosti was a wonderful experience. Visit this venue only on a Saturday.

Large choice of food. Food, food and .... more food! You also have a variety of wine & beer bars to accompany your meal.A bit too crowdy to my liking... But I guess this is the due to it's immense success.well done!
Just go!!!. Great place to spend a Saturday morning. Spoil yourself and have a steak roll at the Kitchen Cowboys stand - you'll never be the same after!! It is FANTASTIC
Biscuit Mill Breakfast. We had breakfast there. Quite busy and quaint place. The kids loved the sweet croissants on display while we settled for a cheese platter with lovely aromatic coffee.

Food food food food. Oh glorious cuisine from Mexican to western to Spanish! Take the chance to also sample the pests, cheeses, chocolates that's there's. best way to spend breakfast, brunch on a Saturday afternoon, listen to a live band, drink some wine, and sample some amazing food. It's about 80-90 rand from Green point so be sure to share a cab with fellow travelers ESP. If you're in a hostel. Also be prepared to spend some srious money on home furnishings, bags, clothes - all of which likely handmade!

Cape Town institution. Locals come here on sunny Saturday mornings for brunch followed by a class of beer or champers. Some food is better than others and can be a bit crowded but worth it to experience and come back once ever so often.

Woodstock. Most delicouise food and desserts ! I was there every Saturday. Mostly there are some singer or dancer who performe there style. All are so friendly and you can taste a lot of diffrent dishes. From olives to tartes, everything you want you will find it there.

Saturday Brunch!. This place is only worth going on Saturday as this is the only day that it becomes very lively and vibrant.Rate experience? - FABULOUS! Shops: We found the prices to be pretty expensive for most of the South African souvenirs - even though there were a lot of locals we felt that the price tags were aimed at tourists. Restaurants/Food: We walked around to sample the food - we found all the vendors to be extremely friendly and willing to allow one to taste the food before buying. I highly recommend skipping breakfast because the variety of food is incredibly tasty! Everything from dips, crepes, paella, fine wines, beers, ciders ....... As much as it is aimed for tourists - this is a great place for Saturday brunch in Cape Town.Location:The hotel told us that the area was not very reputable but as long as you take usual tourist precautions - you should be ok.

Cool. Really cool markets with incredible food. Some stuff was overpriced but that's just what you get at markets. I would recommend withdrawing cash before going to the Biscuit Mill on market day because all the ATMs were very busy.

Great for an early start on the weekend. A great place to taste all the artisanal bakers, butchers, patisseries in Cape Town. Best enjoyed on a Saturday morning, but be warned it gets busy, so it's best to get there early, find a hay bale to sit on, and send your friends, or partners out on a hunt for an artisanal beer, or organic coffee. Once you're done tasting all the amazing food, you can stroll through various galleries and home stores, which have bespoke, handmade and proudly South African product.

Great spot for sensory satisfaction. Love the different type of shops and eateries on offer. Always a great vibe; even mid-week. Public toilets however need a face lift; a bit isolated and not very inviting. I was on crutches when visiting and struggled opening the stiff door to the Disabled loo whilst trying to balance on my crutches. Safe parking available; though a bit pricey for a long visit.

Just wish I get here without eating breakfast. This is definitely a place to enjoy artisanal baking and good wholesome food.Just disappointed that on every visit we were at a hotel with breakfast included so I miss out on sampling the good food on offer!

Nothing special when there is no market. Don't waste your time to go there when there is no market, unless you want to have dinner. The area is very nicely renovated and there some quaint shops and two restaurants en a small food shop and that is it.

Worth a visit even when the Saturday market is not on. I actually went here for lunch at the Test Kitchen but spent 2 hours wandering around afterwardsThere are some very quirky shops, galleries, potteries, delis, and my favourite the wine shop with some more unusual boutique wineries. It is run by the guy who set up Majestic Wines in the UK. E is quite happy to spend half an hour with you helping you to pick out wineThere are also a couple of very good coffee shops and Burata does very good pizzas aDefinitely worth a visit Monday to Friday. They are not very good at promoting themselves apart from the Neighbourhood goods MarketParking is tricky though but secure

Popular weekly food market and top restaurant(s). I would generally be surprised if a tourist visited here other than to attend one of the best restaurants in the city. This is not one of Cape Town's more upmarket suburbs but lots of people come to the Saturday food market where parking can be limited if you don't get there early.

be early. be early there! its damn busy and if you like to trade its easier with the locals in the morning than with the tourist at lunch ;) if you love food, please don´t eat before you visit and just enjoy the market!!! lovely specialities and not all of them are local (I´ve had bavarian bratwurst or spanish baella) and of course local things like biltong and so on ;)for the girls, yeah, you should take some money with you, there are plenty lovely shops with thousands of lovely things to buy there lol not only clothes ;)if you like wine, you are right as well!! this is a place where you could spend half of a day and you won´t get bored, meet the locals there..just in the front of the market before you enter, will a lot of people beg you for some coins.. mostly kids.. its on you.for pictures and nice stories visit my travel blog on Facebook "my life with my backpack" so see you there ;)have fun!! :)

Atmosphere!!. The atmosphere is astonishing!! From young to old and rich to poor and old-school to hip!! It is all present!! The food is great and the drinks are incredible! A great platform for young entrepreneurs to put a foot on th ground and see how their product is accepted on the local market!!Spend your time and your money wisely!! Because around the next corner there is always another attraction waiting!!!ENJOY!!!

A market lovers paradise. The Biscuit Mill has a fantastic saturday market on the go. The food is especially brilliant with every thing from fresh fruit juices, organic vegetables, gourmet sandwiches, fresh organic meat produce, home made jams and on and on the list goes....Beautiful clothing, vintage and new, exquisite hand made original pieces of jewellry, shoes, sunglasses & hats...you name it they have it!!! A real picture of a trendy capetonians saturday morning day out. Great for families too, though i'd suggest to go early as it can get jam packed, therefore extremely uncomfortable!

Best markets ever -amazing food!. We just loved these very eclectic markets. It wasn't just African craft goods, it was beautiful quality goods that you will love to take home.Make sure you go hungry because the array of food is mind blowing and we were devastated that we were still full from breakfast and literally not able to eat. Sacrilegious!You must go, you won't be disappointed.

Beautiful food!. I visited this market during a trip to Cape Town and only wish I'd gone earlier in the month so could have gone back more! A huge selection of delicious food at decent prices (I had the german Rostis and bought some cinnamon roast macademias.. mmm) the only hard part is trying to choose! A tip - don't eat before you go :)

Lovely experience. Great place to visit and loads of unusual products as well as fresh produce including stunning wines from Cloof wines estate where they are offering a free tablet PC on a selection of medal winning wines. Cloof.co.za

Popular Woodstock market. The popular Saturday morning market at this venue is a good place to grab a bite to eat and hang out with friends. Cape Town's version of London's Borough Market. Take your pick from the many food items on sale, grab a table and watch the passing parade. The complex also houses a selection of interesting shops and restaurants. Only negative is the lack of sufficient parking in the area. Be careful as the traffic police like to patrol the area and issue tickets for cars parked illegally.

Foodlovers. Nothing much to dislike, when there are a variety foods.If you are into these types of attractions; then you should also visit the market at Hout Bay and the Market at the V & A Waterfront.They are similar, yet different and my opinion must be visited to enjoy the experience that these types of attractions have to offer.
Vibrant. This market is worth a visit as there are lots of little shops where you can buy all kinds of goods and all kinds of great food. The tourists will love this.

...the place to be on a Saturday morning :-). The Saturday market is worth a visit - you can buy some fresh goods (some traders offer small helpings to try - so just try), sit down and listen to live music, enjoy some oysters with a glass of bubbly (the food offer is great and everyone will find something), watch the trendy people walk by...there is really lots to see!downsides:...parking ...is a desaster (traffic also) - can be VERY crowded...some stuff is ridiciously overprized...and sometimes there are so many cool people - I automatically doublecheck how I look:-)

A flea market with creativity. Although parking in the street is a challenge during the weekend, this is the only time to go because it's when all the food artisans come out to display their wonderful wares. There are really interesting foods for sale - apart from an unusual fresh fruit and veggie stall, there are breads and cheeses and pickles and jams and spreads, and they're all different from the ordinary stuff available at retailers. And then there is a whole selection of delicious pancakes, wraps and other yummy stuff for sale - to eat there with some delicious coffee. All in all, a great vibe and well worth a Saturday morning visit. During the week, however, the place is fairly deserted and the shops can't do much business; their wares are expensive and not really worth the trip.

CT's best kept secret. Wow wow and wow again. Every time I am in CT I make a point of including this in my trip. If you enjoy organic fresh food, creative ambiance you would love this place! Take time to visit all the local shops especially Abode, Wessel Snyman Creative.
pricey. Had to go and see what it was all about but defintely been, seen and not going back. Goods very pricey.
A jummy experience. A wonderful fresh market with wonderful foods to eat or take away. Good coffees, bit crowded and parking is an issue but it is now linked to the MyCity bus. A lively vibe.

Food and beautiful people. I visit the Old Biscuit Mill repeatedly with my family. It looks like something out of a Jamie Oliver film - a huge hall of delicious deli-type stalls offering cheeses, preserves, artisan breads, cured meats, boutique coffee, teas, etc.Get there early to avoid big crowds. Parking can be a challenge too.Walk through the main hall on your right to get to the covered eating area - a huge selection for breakfast, including craft beers and boutique wine/sparkling wine. Chill, enjoy the bustle, and treat your taste buds.There are lots of other boutique or barrow sellers with handmade Jewellery and clothes, plus unique furniture. The Old Biscuit Mill is a 'must-see' on your trip to Cape Town!
REJUVENATION OF A RUN DOWN PLACE!. WOW, loads of "happenings" around one of the very old areas of CT. Gone from Drab to Fab! - new creative innovations, initiatives and entrepreneurship is alive!!
Vibey food market. Vibey and a bit bohemian. Great eats and chilling areas. But parking is a challenge. Best on Saturday mornings.

Saturday morning mayhem. The Biscuit Mill is well worth visiting.. The Saturday market gets very busy so get there early, buy some excellent artisan food, and watch the trendy people arrive. There are also some interesting stores just outside the Biscuit Mill, but parking is a problem so you might be forced to park a distance away and walk.
fun, used to be less commercial... good for the area. go there for fresh produce... check out one of the places to eat and buy lots of tat if you like....
Great food!. Defiantly worth going to. A range of almost anything to eat. Upmarket Flea Market vibe with loads to look at.
shopping adventure. a great place to spend some time. you get to visit unusual shops and there is super fresh food and drink available. parking can be an issue though.

Saturday morning outing. Best to go early as it really fills up and can be quite unpleasant when too crowded. Great food on offer along with live entertainment! A great vibe! Also look at the surrounding are shops - some great new ones.
Interesting market. A really interesting place to sample local & overseas cuisine, as well as mingle with locals. A real melting pot of cultures & tastes.
awesome vibey spot. Great place to go either during the week when it is quitter or on a Saturday when it is a hive of activity. Great food spots and excellent coffee at Espressolab.

Great markets if you go early!!. Love this place although I've only been here a few times. A great way to spend a Saturday morning with the family/friends. Make sure to go early as it gets very crowded by 10.30 or so and you'll struggle to find a seat. There is a lot of amazing goodies and artisan products to try so remember to bring cash along! I personally love the honest chocolate and the tarts stall.

LOVED OUR EXPERIENCES. Went to the Saturday market which was hopping; this market features artisanal foods, locally grown produce and creative crafts! Most of the vendors were up and coming talented "artists." Returned that night to dine at TEST KITCHEN. All I can say is OMG!!! This trendy restaurant puts out the most extraordinary and unique dishes thanks to chef Luke Dale Roberts!
Biscuit Mill Visit. I liked that it was eclectic and vibey. If one is not into food & wine give it a miss. Also do go before 10am..

Worth a visit for food and crafts. Take a taxi for a nice ride out to the Biscuit Mill. Book in advance for The Test Kitchen restaurant, one of the top in South Africa. Also lovely deli, cafe, wine shop and other eating venues and lots of local arts and crafts in attractive units in the converted Biscuit Mill. i think most things close at four and open again at 6pm ? So check times before heading out there.

don't miss this. we visited the farmers market here on Saturday mornings from 9am. there is a great market set up selling SA produce and an array of breakfast options all interesting and different. after breakfast we wandered around the mill for a while. there are interesting stalls set up selling local SA designer items of a high quality. there is great coffee to be drunk and the restaurant at the top of the building the pot luck club looks fabulous

Perfect Saturday morning market. I just love this place. Do not eat before you go ! The variety of fresh foods, fruits, sweet treats, etc is overwhelming. It does get crowded, but just relax and enjoy the happy vibrant vibe. There is a teller machine to draw more cash. Most stalls take credit card. Visit the organic chocolate factory.. O my word.. The central coffee shop/restaurant serves very good food & coffee if you want some space & seating. Great leather products on offer surrounded by interesting little shops. Be prepared to carry many bags back with you !
Nice complex, very creative!. This is a very nicely renovated place, with creative shops and restaurants (Test Kitchen!). Always an adventure to go there! Warmly recommended!

Interesting Place for Foodies. Old Biscuit Mill is a fun and lively market with heaps of food options. It's a great way to uncover many of the food, drink, market and art options Cape Town has to offer. You will not find the most diverse crowd of people here but still an interesting look into Cape Town life. It may be one of the only ways you'll find yourself in Woodstock, which has a rising art scene.
Hipster paradise. Everything is the same old. There are lots of markets in cape town which seem to recycle the same traders.

A C.T Visit must!. Fellow travelers if visiting Cape Town this has to be on your list to do's! Artistic and interesting people everywhere, everything is of highest quality and lots of wonderful finds to tickle all sensory bits! Only open on Saturdays so parking is difficult but it's well worth it. Locals from all over gather together to sell their pieces whether it be art, clothing food etc.I recommend:Taste the local Flavour, they all have something interesting!Take a cameraDrink the local beer (Bone crusher, a darling beer is unreal)!!!Explore even the smallest of placesEnjoy!

Excellent market! Food, drink, music, shopping!. Go early to get your pick of delicious, fresh food cooked just for you! When you get in the main entrance, go to the right for the best food in a pavilion sort of thing. Then grab a cold beer and walk to the other side to do some shopping in art galleries, bead shops, and other just cool, funky design-oriented stores. Some things are priced very well, so you CAN get some good deals! Beware of tourist prices though. Enjoy!

Biscuit Mill. Wonderful atmosphere and amazing array of foods and drinks! Hipster heaven!! :) Definitely worth a visit if you get a chance. If you do go...try go early as it starts getting ridiculously busy with the highest concentration of mommies strolling their babies in CPT! But seriously, it is definitely worth checking out!
a must!!!!!! 5 stars. Food was fabulous, great shops, flowers and vendors care about their customers. Go, Go, Go!!!!! Everything from fudge to pizza to ice cream to the most unbelievable sandwiches.

A must for the fans of organic food. Even during the winter season it was very busy on the market, so if you don't like crowded places make your way there before 10 am. The sandwiches and all dishes offered are or at least look delicious. Brilliant!
good start of your saturday. a bit touristy, but the food and atmosphere is nice! also visit some of the shops there with nice picture frames

Inexpensive and delicious!. My daughter lived in Cape Town for six months and raved about this place and so when we went over to visit here, this was one of the first places she took us too. The mill and shops are open every day, but the best part (the food stalls) are only open on Saturdays to about 2pm so this is when people go.Parking can be a problem, but there are of course car guards everywhere to help you find a spot on the nearby streets. We went on 2 consecutive Saturdays. In fact, I made a night-time 10 and a half hour power drive from Bloemfontein just to get back in time to go to the Old Biscuit Mill one last time before flying home. Go early to avoid the big crowds and to secure a spot to sit. No matter what kind of food you like, you will find something satisfying here.

Saturday morning must-do!. Come early on Saturday morning and bring your appetite and your wallet! Great atmosphere, live music, every type of cuisine you could want, and lots of cute boutiques and shops. We found out about the Saturday market a bit late and almost didn't go, but it was a highlight of our five days in CT.
Awesome. Some of the best food I have ever had. Go early and go hungry. A fair amount of art too - but the food is to die for.

Have some cheese and wine. We bought a bottle of red wine and the owner lent us two glasses, which we took next door and had a cheese platter. We returned the glasses and walked next door for a nice cup of coffee. It was memorable and I would like to go back.Walke the streets outside the Old Biscuit Mill - they have the cutest shops that will take you down memory lane - who remembers Atari Computer games - the days before Playstation 3 and 4 and XBox 360.

Vibey atmosphere. I keep forgetting about this little gem. It is situated in Salt River and is great on a nice day with cushions made from hay where one can sit and eat your take outs. WIth little stalls of food there is plenty to choose from whether you are just wanting a coffee and cake or a full meal. Prices are not cheap for it not being a restaurant but a food market but food is good and atmosphere great. Go early to avoid the crowds.

Average.... Food is expensive, staff not really friendly, parking is a problem. I looked forward to visiting the Old Biscuit Mill, but really, the markets we have in Jhb are of a great quality aswell.. so im not really that impressed to be honest.. But glad we went, always wanted to visit the Biscuit Mill. We loved the old buildings (especially the Biscuit Mill) and in Woodstock in general.

Bustling Market. If you want to feel the pulse of Cape Town in a market place this would definitely be a good old hang out. It can get crowded and you may have to be quite good at musical chairs to get a seat. But there is a good selection of food and stall to choose from and if you want to upscale your eating experience then try the pot luck club, a reservation is needed here. Voted amongst the best in the country a definite must try"

Amazing atmosphere and food - just a little pricey. There were several craft stalls but not as many as I expected. The food court is amazing but some of the items are very expensive. And there was not enough seating.

Good fun, a little overcrowded for me though. Great market and vibe, but it gets super crowded and isn't a cheap morning out either. You'll get quality food and drinks, and be able to browse some really cool stalls, but be prepared to spend around R120 for a meal and a drink
Saturday Market Vibe. A great Saturday food and local designers market. All the locals descend on this Woodstock Market to grab a taste of Cape Town.

Taste bud adventures. we were told to get there early as the place gets very crowded, the day we went was disaterous weather but still the crowds flocked to this semi covered taste sensation. On the one side are clothes and other interesting shops (even for guys) and the other side is the famous food side where you can try anything from cheeses to chcolates, bratwursts to brazilian, chinese to vegetarian, water to wine. great for the senses, bad for the stomach.

So much to choose from. I love the vibe at the Old Biscuit Mill, and the variety of stalls catering for all sorts of needs. The food is divine. I like the fact that this place has been a launch pad for many successful creative entrepreneurs, and people that care about our planet. Parking is the only downside.
Yummy food. Our hotel recommended going here aftervwe went to table mountain - it is a big food market and very inexpensive we had lunch here for like $5,
Buzzing and beautiful!. Always a winner, cosmopolitan, arty and fun! Loads of excellent eats and treats. Worth a visit every time you are in the Mother City!

Eat your heart out!. Go to the biscuit mill hungry, You'll be sorry if you don't! And try take a cab instead of your own car as parking is always a mare. Oh and make sure you take cash as there is only one ATM that is always in high demand.

Great market , but too crowded. Excellent offerings,from fresh farm produce,breads,bakery,wine,breakfasts,etc, but, too crowded.
Can hardly walk between stalls. Good for the traders,but not good for getting to chat to the traders and enjoying...
Saturday lunch and more!. Go on a Saturday and be wowed by the selection of delicious foods and drink. Be prepared to squeeze into a table--its worth it.

Saturday Farmer's Market=GREAT!. What a treat! Great shopping and so many booths of great food. Stop here on the first Saturday of your visit so you can sample food from local restaurants and decide where you want to dine the rest of your visit. Local crafts and stores are great gift shopping. One-stop shopping!

Great Neighbour Goods market to visit!. Wow, what an amazing experience!!! Much to munch on from and it's such a great opportunity to support the locals! Get some friends together and meet for brunch! My advice - get an early start and arrive early it's a challenge to get parking but, well worth the walk!

Bustling Flea Market. Warning: you will definitely struggle to find parking. This flea market is so packed and popular for a good reason, the products are so diverse making exploring here a 100% must when you're in Cape Town! The difference between this market and the others would be that it feels much more organized and upmarket (typically flea markets has a lot of cheap second hand goods). It is definitely worth the experience but way too crowded to frequent in my opinion.
Saturday morning vibe. A must for Saturday morning breakfast, Get there earl, by 09h30 and enjoy the vast array of delicious treats

Old Biscuit Mill. Highly recommend the Old Biscuit Mill for enjoying a day milling about. The gourmet food stalls were all tempting (unfortunately we ate before we arrived so I would recommend that you go on an empty stomach), we loved the Boheme atmosphere and picked up quite a lot of treasures. Can't wait to go back.

FAR TOO CROWDED. This is one of Cape Town's attractions which is hopelessly over-rated. I would only recommend it If you're looking for a one off experience or want to be able to tell your friends that you've been there! First of all, parking is at a premium and you have to contend with informal 'car guards" vying for your tip. Then, when you eventually enter the food hall, you have to push and shove to find something to eat. No, this place is definitely not for the faint hearted. Besides there are so many other food fairs where you will find tasty fare which you can enjoy in a relaxed atmosphere.

Quick shopping. Found the cutest stuff, like a knitted cactus for my desk. We couldn't stay for the market on the Saturday but the shops that are there permanently have a great selection of gifts and trinkets.

Cape Town's Camden Market. Excellent place to pick up souvenirs, food or just browse. The covered market has lots of food stands and stalls. The adjacent shops are packed with antiques, bijoutery and locally made souvenirs. Great atmosphere

down to the freshness. Awesome vibes! Great place with friends or meeting new people, a lot of foreigners. You find anything and you crave for everything. The prices are average. Great place in general.
A nice concept. GReat concept yet can become very crowed quickly and very noisy. Go early and enjoy the market setup.
Fantastic. The food hall is the place to be. You have a choice of a variety of tastes from food, drinks, pickles, cheeses and most important for the olives.

Food heaven!. Must go to place on a Saturday. The array of food and options is unbelievable and each counter is better than the other. One can spend hours over here. Plus there are some fun stores and local designers selling clothing and other items as well. Not to be missed.

Feast for the senses. A really nice Saturday morning activity. Even though products are rather expensive for what they are- it is worth going to check this out- sights, smells and tastes. I recommend the potato rosti, salmon, poached egg and hollandaise sauce breakfast with a big fat bloody mary to start off your morning with a bang. Steer clear of the dim sum- the pot stickers were not the best. The paella leaves much to be desired after enticing you with it's colour and the enormous frying pan it's heated in. The hand-made fruit popsicles are really fresh way to end your experience- greek yoghurt, honey and blackberry flavour was my favourite.

Charming afternoon. Great food with a cool retro vibe. Cuisine available from all corners of the globe. Most of the stalls extremely friendly and the meals fresh and delicious. Also arts and crafts etc which is great. Great place to kick back with friends or to make new ones.

over priced wannabes. What a odd place. Full and I mean full of people who ant to be seen to be there. Spending vast amounts on "artisan" bread and "artisan" beer seems at odds with the reality of Africa where people can't afford any bread. Also the quality of the food is not what I would expect from this sort of place, maybe they just cater for South African taste but it wasnt mine. I ate some "french artisan bread" and after spending lots of time in france I can say this was the first time ive eaten a bageutte wich doesnt make crumbs. In summary soft and squidgy bread, tastless sausages and sugar on 90% of the food and packed full of middle class tourists and South Africans trying to connect with African and completly missing that Africa is on the other side other electric fence, Africa is the people begging on the street kept away from you and your artisan bread by armed guards.

A great lunch spot on the go!. The old biscuit market was a 15 minute drive out of town and well worth going to see. The main reason to visit is the variety of food on offer! There was so much to choose from. It's lively and bustling, and perfect to people watch as you dine. Only downfall was that it didn't feel majority safe outside of the market! Worth a visit though!
Fun Outing. The produce is fresh and tasty. Excellent coffee beans can be bought there. Go early as the place fills up quickly and it actually becomes difficult to get to the stalls.

Always Fun. If for no other reason... EAT there!
Don't buy the flowers unless you realize that they have been boiled/steamed at the bases to keep them looking fresh and that even if you cut them, you will have a very short life for them. They are very expensive for such a short "shelf life"
One of our favorite places... go EARLY!.

A great place for a market!. Saturday markets here are packed! Obviously many folks know about the wonderful foods and drinks on offer, as well as the permanent shops too. Make sure you have enough time to browse and a big shopping bag too! Try the seared tuna on noodles with a pure fruit smoothie or a glass of champagne...
old ? NEW. I expected more like an African market, not this expensive arts and clothing. The food market was cool tho !
Interesting. Enjoyed walking around, very expensive and obviously aimed at the tourist market. But still enkjoyed very much.

Fun Saturday Morning. This was a last minute decision and we are SO glad that we took the time to go to the Old Biscuit Mill. We attended the Sat market and had a wonderful breakfast of waffles topped with chocolate, nuts and cream!! YUM!! Most of all, we loved the atmosphere and activity - and the crowds of people sitting together and enjoying a beautiful morning. We will definitely do this again!

Too Busy. The idea is great but it has become a mission to get food or drinks because the place gets too busy. There is hardly any place to sit at peak time and food can be a little disappointing. But generally speaking, it's worth going, at least once to have experienced it. Great concept!

Beware of the Hipsters. You are not cool enough for this place. You'll never be.Why? Because the cool people were here before it was cool.While you will surely find a few interesting things here, there's also a massive amount of nonsense. This place is too trendy for it's own good and is yet another sad example of how hipsters move into an area, "uplift" it by opening trendy and retro stores and then drive up the prices of everything in the area so that the locals who gave it the charm that attracted them in the first place suddenly can't afford to live there. Places like this suck the very soul out of cities like Cape Town.However, if your choice form of transport is a pennyfarthing bicycle and your idea of fashion involves high-cut shorts, velskoene, a blazer, a trilby and a carefully-maintained scruffy beard and you need a place to have a cup of single-origin-micro-roasted-fair-trade-organic coffee that tastes like dishwater while you listen to bootleg recordings of the latest obscure band you're pretending to like on a battery-operated reel-to-reel tape recorder while uploading photos that you took on a polaroid and then instagramed to your to MySpace page on an iPad using a bluetooth keyboard that looks like a vintage typewriter, then this is just the place for you.
Amazing food market. I love this food market and try to visit it every time I visit Cape Town. With a wide variety of food to choose from, there will be something to cater for everyone's tastes.

Great Market. Great way to spend a Saturday morning - just remember not to eat breakfast beforehand - as the food is fantastic. All the store holders were interesting, passionate people and the produce was exceptional.

Great Food, Nice Vibe. The food is incredible. Best to walk the whole place then start the snacking as you'll want keep "space" for everything. Parking is tight, but the unofficial parking spots with car guards are cool.

Artisan's Market. This is a great place to find hand crafted items including shoes, clothes, jewelry, glass, purses etc. The market has a vibrant feel and walking through the food section is a bit challenging trying to juggle food and crowds but well worth it. Come hungry and expect to make some wonderful unique buys!
Not for weekday exploring. We visited the OBM on a weekday and were very disappointed to find that all the magic is reserved for the weekends. Not much happening during the week.

Fantastic Atmosphere. All the different stalls and interesting small shops, fantastic wipe and best street food! The best place to get together with families and taste the various food, breads, olives , meats, cheese , wines and a lot more . Sit on the bales outside and have drink of coffee or go inside and have oysters and champagne. This market has anything your heart desires! You can buy clothes and other unique items at the Biscuit mill that you will get nowhere else! A must place to visit when you in Cape Town!

I will never get tired of visiting this food market!. I recently popped in at the Old Biscuit Mill food market since my last visit in Feb or so. I don't think I will ever get tired of visiting this foodie heaven. Generally we tend to get there very early to avoid the crowds and enjoy the market before the crowds flock in. My personal foodie journey through the market starts with an Origin coffee,fruit salad and yoghurt from the smoothie stall and then a smoothie as well as whatever else tickles my fancy. One generally cannot leave with a little take-away something too! On this trip to the market my cousin and I shared a most delicious seafood paella as well as the mushroom kebab!!!! Soooo good. We did try the sangria too and this time my take-away treat was something very different. It wasn't from the actual food stalls but from one of the little shops at the Mill. I took home some "ginger-beered" flavored Wilson's toffees and a puffnut sweet. You don't find those puffnut sweets in the supermarkets anymore. The market is a fantastic place for people watching while you explore different types of cuisines and treats. It does get super crowded so I would recommend getting there at about 8:45 or heading there at about 1:30. Enjoy!

If you love food, GO on SATURDAY Mornings!. We went on a Saturday morning and LOVED the food experience. The are a lot of different food vendors with local, homemade, creative offerings - for a Foodie, the experience is awesome. However, I would not go back if food was not a focus - the rest of the place is fairly pretencious, expensive, full of "beautiful people", and generally not terribly interesting. We did not feel that the place was over-crowded, but we did have to leave by 11am - maybe it gets jampacked later in the day. We are already looking forward to going back (probably many times) and will spend a lot more time exploring the food section - and we will make sure to go hungryIn summary, Old Biscuit Mill is brilliant for food but weak for everything else...

Must See!. The Old Biscuit Mill is now part of the Neighborgoods Market. It's filled with clothing merchants, great restaurants and an amazing chocolate shop. Go early to beat the crowds and be prepared to spend money!

Country and City Meet. what a lovely discovery made whilst strolling the suburb of Woodstock, Old Biscuit Mill. It is fun and real social get together for everyone! O the food is just so delicious with such a variety: from tradition South African to Asian, etc. My only negative comment would be that it gets too crowded and loud.

Yuppy and over rated!. What an over rated and over priced experience! Too crowded with lots of tourists, food that is really over priced and a lot of pretentious yuppies! The Hope Street market is really so much nicer. The only plus of going there was Odeds Kitchen.

Even more than expected.... What a great stop - try to visit on Saturday for the local food market with scores of vendors. Great shops are open all week but the food fair is not to be missed. Locals predominate which makes the visit even more fun.

Go hungry, and get there well before 2pm!. At the suggestion of several people, I found myself at the Old Biscuit Mill on a Saturday. The gentleman who runs the guest house I'm staying at told me all the action happens between about 10am and 2pm - but what I didn't realise is that places start to close at 2pm!This is a great place to get quirky and cool presents for friends and family - and for yourself! As you walk in the main entrance, if you go off to the right, you'll find a huge shed with lots of pop-up eateries. Go hungry, eat, and get some snacks for the road. The array of food (not to mention wines, craft beers and ciders etc) is mouth-watering!You could easily spend a few hours swanning around, browsing the stalls with a drink in hand, enjoying the music and the friendly market vibe - so get there well before noon to make the most of it!

Go there saturdays. This place has become extremely popular, its situated in a rough neighbourhood named Woodstock. The Mill itself however is one of the safest places Ive walked around in CT. Less need to watch your purse here. Design shops, art shops and clothes stores. Plus the Test Kitchen which you might get a table if you are lucky and reserve it months in advance. On saturdays there is a food marked, it is amazing and sells truly good food.

Must do Saturday short experience in Cape Town.. It's like an afro Camden Market (which is a useful comparison if you've been to Camden!). Trendy, arts/crafts and great food. We arrived around 08:30 Saturday morning which is about right, by 11:00 it was heaving. Must see.

Very fun and trendy-make sure you get their early. Loved visiting the market and trying the delicious food, although we arrived a bit late (1pm) and would have probably enjoyed more stuff had we gotten there a couple hours earlier! It's a bit out of the way, and taxi will not be super cheap if you're on a budget, but absolutely worth it.

Biscuit Mill. The Old Biscuit Mill has become a Saturday outing for many. It has evolved into a real tourist spot. Crowded and busy with lots of food stalls plus a few arty type shops. The tourist element has seen the prices getting out of hand - you can buy better elsewhere. But worth a visit.
Great to do on a Saturday morning. Lovely atmosphere, great food but very crowded. Food stalls and some interesting shops. Don't eat anything before you go!
Great Vibe. The biscuit Mill is really something to experience when in Cape Town and seems to improve every time I go down to Cape Town. The variety and vibe of the place is amazing.

Mix with the Locals. Every Saturday the old Biscuit Mill becomes a hive of stalls holding local produce and a huge variety of dishes being cooked to order. Crepes, curries, burgers, smoothies, you are likely to find something that appeals to even the fussiest eater. It is a place to hang out, enjoy people watching whilst teasing your sense buds.Some craft stalls and shops available. Parking is quite difficult.

Old Biscuit Mill. Local artists sell their wares here. It's artistic and quaint, but over crowded. I preferred buying trinkets from sidewalk and street vendors who had the same items at lower prices. You can always bargain on the streets.

Come on Saturdays and join the crowd.. The OBM is hectic and crowded and atmospheric. It contains loads of types of food and produce and it's a great place for Saturday brunch.My advice is that you should get there early before all the crowds arrive...before 10.00 and then you've got a chance to sample some of the stalls and make a purchase.Parking is typically South African. Follow the car guards and they'll point you to a place and give them a few Rand for their services. They're non threatening and part of the culture.If you're in CT over the weekend give it a spin on a Saturday morning and enjoy the locals and tourists fighting for a cup of coffee and something to eat.
Nice farmers market. This place is filled to the brim with hipsters. I think the local term is bergiez. Loads of eclectic people milling about with nothing to do, a good visit.
So cool. Don't miss the Biscuit Mill on Saturdays! It's a wonderful place to wander, people-watch, eat great food, and generally just laze around. This is Cape Town's culture. See it.

Not quite what I expected. HHaving no parking was a concern. Bit crowded. I expected more and assumed more food to taste before buying or just a taste experience. I went for food, but pretty much a fleamarket.

The radio ads are better than the reality. We decided to visit after hear the radio adverts. The OBM is popular BUT this is not a place for the claustrophobic - you could not move, everywhere was packed with people, the parking is a nightmare and everything is expensive.
Been there, seen it and won't be going back.
