The best market uet. As a tourist always searching for the next best place to visit. I'm so thankful I found a great place. Sat morning I did expect crowds so that was not a problem. As we were driving down from green point we noticed car park guys waving us down to park, but be warned it will be a walk away if you park at the first person waving you in. Drive closer to 375( the house address) and it was easy to find closer parking in a small lot. For R10. That's lekkarThe place was busy before 10:30 but it was such a lively crowd. And food. Lots of food to choose from. I want to make note of the smoothie stand that sold pomegranate juice. Best tasting juice forR80 1 ltr. Was worth it. The pizza although too early to eat for me looked divine. And I went for the omelette station. Mmmm delicious. Finding a seat may be tricky but it was all amazing and we are heading back next Sat. The fruits and veggies were a little bit more costly than i have bought at other markets. Great food. And I will check out the shopping on my return visit. I could spend my day here. I agree. Any visitor and local would like. But if you hate crowds, you should avoid

Yum yum. Great place to go on a Saturday morning to taste lots of yummy treats and great coffee. Lots of stalls (not just food) but the food stood out. Try a coffee at the Espresso Lab Micro Roasters - fab coffee with a smile. Then perhaps some Korean food to start, some amazing pizzas and good looking burgers, steaks, curries.....cakes...Also a great place if you just like people watching.

I fell in love with the market.. A visit to Cape Town is not complete without a visit to The Old Biscuit Mill Market. I fell in love with Cape Town again. I have been living in JHB for 8 years now and I saw what I am missing...

For all the hipsters. The old biscuit mill was awesome. Lots of cute quirky stores filled with little gems. Excellent food and coffee! The testing room is currently one of the best restaurants in CT and was booked out till May! but is situated in a corner of the Mill. There are numerous stalls set up within the Mill itself which had some very pretty dresses and leather bags and shoes. Well worth a visit with a couple friends and some time to browse.

THE Saturday morning hangout. There's not too many alternatives to the OBM on a Saturday morning/early afternoon. There are clothes shops and stands but the main attraction is the food market with tons of samples and yummy food. Sure, the crowds are massive, but for a reason. To quote an earlier reviewer: bring plenty of cash and come hungry!

Great food on the go!. Had a fantastic morning at the Old Biscuit Mill, lots of local designer products, very fun, however quite expensive. The food market is the best part, had one of the most delicious pizzas ever!

Food, GLORIOUS Food! Don't miss this.. The Old Biscuit Mill is on on Saturdays.We visited first thing after getting a taxifrom our hotel in Central Cape Town (this only costs a few pounds).It's basically a posh market with lots of stalls selling clothes, handbags amd south african wares. There is a huge food hall with fresh produce, selling everything from wraps, oysters, hams, sandwiches, fruits, smoothies, breads and dips. Absolutely everything and plenty of opportunity for free tasting. The chocolate shop is worth a visit for some unusual tasting chocolate. I also did the chocolate tour, a 1 on 1 tour with the manager, which was excellent and their ice cream is to die for.It's a very busy place so keep your valuables safe and secure in case of pickpockets. This is a place you must visit if you're in Cape Town and I would allow a full morning to ensure you see everything.

CRUMBS. Go on a Saturday it's a hive of activity. You may think you have been to a Farmer's Market but you havnt until you have made this trip. In addition there are the shops and eateries etc that are there each day. Dont be put off by the road in its perfectly OK and if you walk it there are some unusual outlets selling a variety of goods.
Hot Zone for Local Artisans. The former biscuit mill turned art shop community is worth a trip. The entire mill has about 30 shops spanning local arts and crafts, wine and restaurants.

Crowds overwhelming. We visited this trendy spot with a local, who was able to find excellent parking in the nearby maze of streets. We loved the shops, and the organic food market, and particularly the fact that a centrally placed table allowed people to sit right down and taste the fare. But it was hot, and by 11.30am, overwhelmingly overcrowded. As a result we cut our visit short and left after an hour. Recommended, but NOT after 11am. Go early for the best experience.

Absolutely amazing !!!. I absolutely loved it: the food, the atmosphere, the clothes- everything about it. It gets a little bit crowded, but I think it is normal for such places. You have to go there very hungry and try as much as you can: I tried extremely tasty hot dogs, great chocolate, smoothies, olives, juice and fresh ice tea at the hot dog stand. The food is very fresh and there is a lot to choose from. If I was lucky enough to live in Cape Town ;) I would go there every Saturday. A MUST TO DO WHILE IN CAPE TOWN.

A hidden treasure !. Heard about this place from friends. Went there today, in the rain. Delightful ! Loads of stalls with wonderful fresh food, great leather bags, small bistro's and coffee shops, art shops, atmosphere and loads of energy. Luckily an ATM as well. Could spend the whole day here. Come hungry, with cash and time to just enjoy life. Parking in the surrounding streets. Treat yourself !
Worth the crowd. Went this morning sat the 26th of 2013. Incredible food. Great people. Im already looking forward to going back for another round.
Cool place. Great food options, good shopping for small nick nacks and funking little things. Just make sure you get there early it can get super crowded and hard to get a seat.
Do not miss this. What a wonderful experience. All we can say is go very hungry. alot of food vendors with top grade food. We have not experienced something so wonderful and were blown away.

Love this place..... The atmosphere is great and there are really interesting things to look at and sample. My only criticism is that it is now so full that you kind of want to leave soon after arriving. Perhaps we need to try a different time of the day...

Fabulous concept and stores, but now just too crowded to really enjoy (on Sat.)!. We went on a Saturday in January 2013 and loved the laid-back vibe with old doors acting as tables and a wide choice of great food in the food market section. However, it was packed to the point of suffocation (one middle age man did in fact faint right in-front of us). My advice would be to visit when the main tourist season is over. also if you go during the main season (Nov.-March) go early. Otherwise parking becomes a big problem. I ended up with a 300 rand parking ticket like a lot of people.Without the crowds it really would be a 5 star recommendation.

Great place to mooch. Just back from a fab morning at Old Biscuit Mill which is a Flea/Farmers market offering lots of handmade , designer and unusual products plus a delightful food and beverage area.Parking was a tad problmatic as it is outside the venue but spaces are no problem as local guys try hard to get you parked and will look after your car for a few rand coins.The venue is always busy but it's a delight from Camden Market & Borough Market in London as it is 75 degrees and theres so much to do and see plus grabbing some food is a delight.Food is served from 10am until 2pm and the variety on offer was an abundance of Fresh Oysters, Home Cooked Burgers, Flat bread with Italian Proscuitto & Parmesan, Steak Rolls with Balsamic Onions and many more stalls along with juices & alcohol beverages.Well recomended to all visitors on holiday for something different.

Fantastic Saturday Market. This Saturday market (open 9 a.m.-2 p.m.) was recommended to us by our foodie/wine lover friend in Paarl. The numerous food stalls were the perfect place for us to grab coffee, savory breakfast pastries, and a fresh passionfruit (grenadilla) smoothie. We also picked up some delicious custard pies for later. There are also some great custom & vintage furniture stalls, handicraft shops, and accessory boutiques. The Old Biscuit Mill is a great place where the locals flock on Saturdays. We had a rental car, and we found parking on a side street. Located in an old repurposed mill, visitors can be a little nervous about the sketchy neighborhood, but it is perfectly safe with hundreds of market-goers milling about on Saturday as mentioned in a previous review. Don't miss it if you want a true taste of the area!

A good morning out. I really enjoyed our visit to the Old Biscuit Mill. The crafts were quirky and some really good quality stuff, not your average flea market sort of stuff. The food hall was wonderful, the choices were many and people were friendly. We arrived a little after 10am and the place very quickly packed up... so I recommend being there at 9am.My 4yr old loved her fresh coconut milk served directly from a green coconut... cocktails for breakfast anyone? Really nice vibe, loud and busy with exciting food. Definitely a must visit in CT. Parking was a bit crazy, our car was well looked after by the guys on the road. We had quiet a walk to the mill but we were with friends and it was daylight so wasn't an issue.It is very busy and probably not such a great place for small kids, especially in the food section. I can imagine it being very unpleasant if I had a second child. The flea market area is fine it is just the food section which got rather crowded. Overall a great place to visit.
Get here Early. Crowded. Mostly Food outlets of every description. Gets very busy. I would take a cab both ways as parking would be an issue. Good place to mooch about!

Best attraction. Saturday mornings are not the same without a visit here. Incredible food offering - we wanted to try everything it all looked so good. Pork belly pies were ambrosial. Plenty o craft beers on offer too. Brilliant place for breakfast - and to gather stuff for a lunch picnic at Kirstenbosch.
Get there early!. A must for the lovely produce sold on a Saturday in the farmer's market as well as a breakfast/lunch snack from the myriad of stalls with a worldwide appeal.

Foodies Heaven. This market is a must go on saturday morning (9 am to 2 pm). It was one of the highlights of Cape Town for me. expect to find foods from different countries, specialty ingredients, fresh drinks, coffees and pastries. Definitely plan on having breakfast and lunch there. There are also cute little homeware/souvenirs stores in the market.

A weekend must !. This is where hip Cape Town and visitors alike gather at the weekends and sample homemade foods, avantgarde clothes and art and shop til they drop.Even a chocolate shop and fabulous wine tastings.

In Cape Town on a Sat morning - looking for something to do!. Had heard a lot about this market so was keen to see and experience it. It is located in a dodge area of Cape Town but due to it being s busy on a Saturday morning it is fine to visit. Only en for early in the morning till 14h00. If you are wanting to get fresh produce to take home and do not like crowds go early. If you are looking to enjoy a morning of tasting good food and enjoy a glass of sparkling wine or two you can go later. Be prepared to have to look out for seating and then grab it!Lots of people around inside the market and outside. Seating is very casual - long benches and straw bales. One need to be prepared to fight the crowds to find a spot to sit but the food quality is worth it.There are also a few great funky shops around that you can browse through.

Food is simply a.m.a.z.i.n.g!. The Saturday morning (0900 - 1400) Neighbourgood's Market at the Old Biscuit Mill is a MUST DO activity while in Cape Town!There are countless stalls with everything from chocolate to omelettes to oysters to paella. You can quench your thirst with rooibos ice tea, wine, beer, or pretty much anything else you can think of. Really, something for everyone! I could keep going back for weeks and try something new each time. There's no entrance fee, but of course you pay for whatever food/drink you want.The Old Biscuit Mill is an old brick warehouse that has been renovated with shops and restaurants. At first I was concerned about the area being a bit dodgy, but I've actually found it to be just fine. Although Saturdays at the market are busy, there is lots of parking on the nearby side streets. There are also lots of local people milling about the side streets, eager to direct you to a parking lot and charge you a small fee (e.g. R10) to look after your car.

For a fun Saturday morning. Went with friends to this open air market place, which was crowded with people when we arrived. A fun band was playing outside, and belly dancers performing. The food stalls were producing wonderful smells, which made choosing from all the wonderful foods and drinks that were on display, really difficult . Got a stuffed pita which was yummy, but had to stand and walk to eat it, as there was no seating by the time we got there. It was fun shopping with all the vendors there too. A must see for a Cape Town visit!

Food Frenzy. The Old Biscuit Mill has a weekly food market on a Saturday morning from 9 to 1 - get htere early as it fills up and it is nicer to be seated than standing as you chomp on your rosti/ dim sum/ oysters....we had freshly squeezed juice, fine patisserie and good coffee as well as rostis with salmon and poached eggs and dim sum(fried alas, not steamed) We bought fresh asparagus and strawberries and if one had a limitless capacity we could have had pizza and oysters and espetada and so much more... pretty people, families, serene people... lovely.

Spend Saturday Morning visiting this interesting market. having some free time on a Saturday morning , one will really enjoy walking and visiting the different stalls at the Old Biscuit Mill market in Salt River , Cape Town. Great alternative if you are looking for something different to the normal shopping centre experience ( Waterfront , Canal Walk , Cavendish etc). Stalls offer organic and homemade goodies and good alternative experience if you have 2 - 3 hours. Visit early as at 11 am , very , very busy. Try to go at 8am. Whilst there , visit the Good Hope Butchery which is close by for a great Chicken Tikka for only R17.

social gathering place. One of my favourite Saturday morning places to visit. Go for a delicious breakfast from bacon and egg, to Thai, to Indian, to just plain good and healthy. Tastings for all sorts of delicious foods. They have several organic honey's to taste and buy. Meat, biltong (jerkey) which is delicious. Organic vegetables, chocolate. Coffees and long tables to sit at and eat your food. Wines to taste and buy by the glass, beer to taste and buy by the glass, inside the "shed" but be sure to get there when they open. 9 a.m. I think. Arrive late and it is a glorious crush of people's tasting, trying, seeing friends and just generally having a good time. They have a couple of restaurants outside fo the "shed", a wonderful coffee roastery, all sorts of fun things to see and to do. Too many to mention. Don't miss the opportunity of seeing the Biscuit Mill if you are in Cape Town on a Saturday morning.

A Wonderful Place. What a wonderful way to start the day with a good breakfast and spend the day, buying fresh produce and browsing through all the interesting shops, as well as some of the shops on Lower Main Road. Get there early!
A delicious day out. What a delicious way to start the day. Get there early, pace yourself and have a good plan of attack. Elbow room is a premium but you want be disappointed.

Great Saturday markets in Cape Town. Was recommended this as a thing to do on aSaturday morning as was not disappointed. The area has such great food and this place showcases all things Cape Town food including two of the best restaurants in the city. Thoroughly recommend for locals and visitors. Get there earlier for on street parking (early is 8:30am).

Delicious distractions. Every Saturday there's a Neighbourgoods Food market, with several stalls selling various cuisines. There are also other crafts plying their trade. Get there early (they open at 9am), and you'll have to find parking in the street.

Fun but a bit overrated. Biscuit Mill is too busy. too popular. full stop. you have to arrive at 9am when it opens, eat a quick breakfast and grab your organic veggies, or homebaked bread or whatever and get out quick. Otherwise it becomes a slow moving human conveyor belt (fire hazard deluxe) that one has no choice but o get caught up in as the throngs of people move through the small passageways between the stalls. There is some good produce, and some yummy breakfasts to be had, but in my mind is overrated and not worth it unless you make a quick in and out, and where's the fun in that when you've come to a Saturday morning market?

Great place to be for having breakfast. This food market with zillions of different food to sample is the place to be for having breakfast/lunch. You can find there everything from SA 'braai', fish to belgium chocolate? Prices ranges from low to medium

Great food and ambience!. It was a wet, chilly morning but that didn't stop plenty of people turning out! The variety and quality of foods available were great! Not only can you eat, you get to do some of your shop too! The local cheeses and breads are definitely some of best I have ever had! The experience I got from the market was a good feeling of the wonderful tastes the Western Cape has to offer! You need a good couple of hours here. I hear from the stall holders that if the weather is great it is much busier! So. I'd say go early!

Oysters for breakfast anyone?. The biscuit mill is Saturday's morning market. Partly delicious food made by farmers, organics, italian pizzas and omelet boys, smoothies, sandwitches with every kind of bread and chss you can dream of, flowers, vegetables, olive pastes, ginger chocolates...and most of all, fresh oysters. Fresh, yummy, fluffy meaty salty oysters. For oysters lovers like me, you guessed it, it becomes oysters saturdays. Have your first dozen, roam around the market of African artifacts, wood carvings, vintage clothes and home decoratins, cameras, bags, lamps, handmade stuff, antiques, and after you have seen it all, go for your second oyster dozen, you wont regret it! Danielle.

Winter or Summer - get there early!. Regardless of the weather, whether as a local or a visitor to Cape Town, try to make this market on a Saturday morning. The selection of excellent and widely varying foodie attractions makes it well nigh impossible to sample everything, but it's worth having a full go! Adding to the casual and warm atmosphere is somebody somewhere in the background churning out the best music ever; stall-holders and visitors are all happy and the vibe is just ideal to start the week-end. Do NOT miss the world-class macaroons; fudge; brownies and cake-pops at Ma Mere in the front hall and make sure that you nudge your way through to the hot food and cold artisan beers in the rear section of the market .. and critically, bring cash as few stalls work with plastic.

Great food. I went when it was raining and still had a great time. Nice vibe and a very extensive selection of food to choose from. I particularly enjoyed the the "Come on Bert" crepes and the tuna biltong. Be sure to visit the neighbourhood shops, there are lots of hidden treasures waiting for you to find them. A really nice way to spend a lazy Saturday morning.

Amazing place to eat and shop. Several locals had mentioned the Old Biscuit Mill, but I was almost turned away by the parking situation (guys holding handmade signs pointing you to parking) in a somewhat dodgy neighborhood. Boy, am I glad we stuck it out. You walk into the outdoor area and you are met with quaint shops and vendors, beautiful people, and AMAZING food selection. Everything from eggs benedict to Ethiopian sauces. Delicious desserts - makes you wish you had an endless stomach. Check this out on Saturday mornings for what they call the "neighborgood".

Must come for the food!. The food is amazing. We tried hummus and pita that was out of this world. We also had crepes that were amazing. Reminds me a lot of the markets and festivals that we have in San Francisco and Oakland. Felt like a piece of home.
Good Food. Nothing spectacular about the shopping, but the food was excellent. A very diverse selection of foods...I stuffed myself like a pig!

Nice place to visit (Great food). Lots of arts and crafts, lovely home made foods(From german pizza's to ostrich steak gourmet burgers). A bit pricey, but it is to be expected of a touristy place. Please remember to draw some cash prior to your visit as most of the stalls only take cash, some do take cards. We went on a very busy weekend and it was hectically crowded! And we had to wait in line for most of the parcels/foods we bought.

A gastronomic delight. I expected the usual fare from local flea market -arts, cratfs, fast food. What I got was a teeming, festive market, with a lot less arts and crafts and a range of food that left one in state of shock- what to taste first?? The atmosphere was vibrant, the service friendly and quick. Eventually, we found some elbow space at one of creative table tops, where we devoured our exotic breakfasts and absorbed it all. The following morning, I was the one back on the Gautrein tugging the fresh proteas, smoked snoek and chilli olives bach home with me!Hopefully the Gauteng equivalent of this market is as interesting.

soooo crowded. The food available was the best food in one spot I have seen on this earth!! But, it was so crowded, I could hardly move. Getting a table or seat was so competitive- I saw a lady dive under a picnic table to get one! There must be a better way to spread out the vendors. I was expecting a farmer's market with homemade gifts type place, but this is more of a food stall with gourmet goodies

After a trip to the Old Biscuit Mill my taste buds are a mess. The girls in the family spend more time walking around the arts, crafts, handbags, accessories areas. I soon head for the food "tent". The first thing that you bump into is a trailer full of loaves of fresh bread. The senses get teased from the start. The flowers, especially proteas are exceptional. Then its waffles, pancakes, pestos, muffins, cheeses, unbelievable chicken and beef rolls, oysters, paellas, dumplings, pizzas, champagne, wines, chocolates, hot chocolate, coffee, smoothies, smoked salmon, curries. There is more, but the senses just cant take it all in. The crowds are an absolute pain, and moving around the area is very frustrating. Some people leave beacuse of it. I seem to have almost forgotten about the people, however the senses have not.

Don't go on a Full Stomach!. This is an amazing farmers market. There is a wide variety of foods from all over the world and it is all so good! I ate a ton just because everything was so interesting and delicious. There's nice clothing stores, art stores, etc. to shop at as well. It gets pretty busy so I'm guessing the earlier, the better. The crowd is fun and friendly. Make sure you go here if you are in Cape Town!

Cape Towns best market. The market at the old biscuit mill is, in my opinion, the best in Cape Town at the moment. The fare on offer is fresh and tasty, the crafts are unique and interesting and the atmosphere is great.One negative (and it is hardly a negative) is that it is extremely full, and getting around with 2 kids can be difficult.Otherwise, top notch!
Great Sat Morning Market. The Saturday morning market is a must-do if you are in cape town! Great vendors, great food. Really awesome. Very similar to the "Eastern Market" in Washington DC.

Exceptional Food Market in Cape Town. I went here on a recent visit back home and the Saturday morning market is a food lovers dream. 5 minutes from the city centre where you can get deli sized portions of the best food you will ever find under one roof along with great drinks and a great crowd.Highly recommended

If you like your food this is the place to visit. Frequnted by Capetonians and visitors alike The Biscuit Mill has something for everybody. Wonderful selection of foodstuffs to satisfy discerning palates including Ghoulash ( one of my favourites ) The downside, because it's so popular it tends to get super busy. My tip - go early and go hungry !

Good food and quirky things. A lovely way to spend your Saturday late morning-early afternoon! Take lots of cash, because they have the most amazing nibbles and thing to eat. You will find organic and free-range and all of it is delicious! Lots of quirky little stores to browse around in and you will most definitely walk out of there with something. The neighborhood might look a bit dodgy, but it is very save!

Best food, beer, wine to be had on a Saturday morning. If you love farmers markets, then you will love OBM. Look for the Princess Pestos. It gets busy by 10-11, so I strongly recommend going early. The surrounding neighborhood has developed several other antique shops and is worth exploring. Best Saturday of our trip!!
Recommend. Was very buzzy. A lot to see including stalls selling arts crafts and foods

Food glorious food. This review is of the weekly Saturday food market at the Old Biscuit MillTry the eggs benedict on potato rosti from Luke Dale Roberts' stall for a decadent breakfast. You can choose food from around the world, delicious French cheeses, German hot dogs, Italian pizza, Hungarian treats, and of course South African specials. The choice is wide and the flavours and smells will have you returning soon.

Now this is worth a visit or more. Great selection of shops restaurants, market etc on a Sunday etc etc. Unlike the waterfront and all the other identikit malls you will see things here you won't get at home. Easy to find and get to, some parking on site that's reasonably priced.

Great place.. All you need to do on a Saturday morning is found here. Shops selling top quality art, craft and gorgeous things. This place is definitely for foodies and people who like beautiful things. The choicesa are incredible. A fantastic BUZZ and quite European in feel. . Fantastic value. Arrive early as parking can be a problem. A must if you are in Cape Town on a Saturday.
PLEASANT. whilst strolling around the market, have a look at some upmarket items on sale, from food stalls to speciality jewellery, take a few hours on a saterday morning - it's worth a visit!

Great food bad locals.... The Pro: this is a great place to find local food and meet with purveyors who really know their product. We got a lot of tips on other food and beverage places to go around Cape Town.The Con: beware of the locals. This place is crowded! Some people were hostile and pushy others were there just to hangout and would suddenly stop to meet up with a long lost friend while a hundred people backed up behind them. This was one of the few places in Cape Town that I found too pretentious.
Great Place. Excellent traqsure trove and the organic market and eats are tops!!
Nice food but dang. It gets really rowdy so go early and go hungry cos theres a lot to eat but seats run out n they close early afternoon.

Saturday morning caffeine kick. Great Saturday morning market and eating options, located in Lower Main Rd in Observatory. Food and drink for all tastes (including lots of vegetarian options). Additional clothing and craft stalls, as well as fruit, veg and flower sellers. Excellent vibe.Main dislike: very overcrowded and can never find a "quiet" time to visit. Which is a pity, as this is otherwise the perfect hang out for a Saturday morning!

Don't miss it if in Cape Town on Sunday. As a tourist If you happen to be in Cape Town on a Sunday you must not miss this place. It is full of activity and people having fun, drinks and good food. There is a live band and live performances, break dancing etc all for free. People are walking around with champagne glasses in hand sipping champagne and tasting all sorts of food ranging from paella, grilled mushrooms, sushi, roasts and grills all set up like a farmer's market style. Great place to spend a nice Sunday morning soaking in the essence of Capetonian lifestyle

A food lover's paradise. What a buzz! Dozens of independent stall holders, all with their homemade food and goodies and so much to taste, smell and see. What a great spot to have breakfast on a Saturday morning but go early to eat the crush as it is extremely popular. Be prepared to perch on hay bales or share a bench and long table and delight in the offerings. Anything and everything goes but just because it is a market does not mean that there is any compromise on quality. Here, you will find the finest cakes and pastries, breads, smoked fish, wines, biltong, fruit and veg, dried fruit and nuts, relishes, dips, imported products, pizzas, steak rolls, oysters, the list is endless and anything goes. There are several shops in the mill, selling clothes, household nic-nacs and other wares. It's vibey and its fun.
Saturday morning snacks. Buzzy and smart - great food market and snacks, and interesting designer shops. Afrikaaner friend dismissed it as "too English" - but we're English and we liked it!

The height of L.I.F.E. This market is abound with people sharing. Sharing food, sharing ideas, sharing jokes...sharing life.It was a beautiful Saturday morning in the Mothercity when we visited the market and I would suggest you take a whole wad of cash with, cause there is barrow-loads of quality produce and products to buy. Set a whole day aside for this visit.I LOVED it!! Would definitely recommend it and will definitely return.

doesnt dissapoint. we went oin a saturday morning, the parking around it was difficult to find a place but once inside we really enjoyed it, good food good art shops and bric a brad etc etc definately worth a visit

Hipsters unite! Yummy organic / healthy food market on each Saturday. Awesome Saturday Market.Healthy / organic food fiesta. Cooked / baked on location. Wines, chocolate, various cuisine. And a few other artsy shops - that are open all week round. All this makes a favorite for local hipsters. I mean it in a good way :P

An exquisite treat for the palate!. Expect to wait a bit to get food BUT IT IS WELL WORTH THE WAIT!!! It was one of the highlights of my trip--so much so that I went twice and it's 1st on my list when I return in September!Ada Gallo

The place for Saturday Brunch in Cape Town. Whilst this place is pretty quite during the week and on Sundays it comes alive on Saturday mornings when the whole of Cape Town descends on it to buy local produce and more importantly have the best brunch you will ever have.Numerous stalls set up in a covered market area sell all manner of foods and wines and also there are stalls selling hot and cold foods of every imaginable type.Most popular are the large thin base pizzas (made to your spec) the Rosti (rosti base with cheese, crispy bacon, poached egg and hollandaise. and the Steak Burger. Curries noodles and Moroccan food is on sale also.Choose your dishes and then take them to a seat at one of the trestle tables and enjoy with a wine, beer or a smoothieGet there early because by 11 am it is heaving and it closes around 2pm.

Fantastic Market for Food and Shopping!. OK... I can't figure out why there aren't more reviews for this place! Granted, my husband and I will seek out local markets while traveling, but the Biscuit Mill on a Saturday should be on any travelers hit list when in Cape Town. We'd rented a car and had not problem finding it or parking quite close (thanks to the "parking monitors" you see all over town.) There are 2 parts to the market. The clothing and housewares section is to your left when you enter the main gate, and the food and drinks are to your right. The shopping was fun with a few good finds in some of the shops that carry vintage goods... but the food market was INCREDIBLE! We stopped first and grabbed a drink at the Brewers Union stall. This is locally made beer, and actually they now have a tapas style restaurant in the city. Once in the main food area you're hit with a sea of color and smell. There are one after one booths of fresh produce, local cheese, artisan meats, juices, oysters, sausage... you name it! We ate our way through and then brought bags of food back to the hotel to finish off over the next few days. The scene is fun and lively. There are large communal tables to join and enjoy the snacks you just picked up. It's just a great way to spend a Saturday.

Interesting shops but pretty small. I understand that Saturdays are the days to go but not having that option, I went midweek. The shops were interesting but there were only a few of them. I think I was done in about an hour and then had to find a taxi back to my hotel (the security guards were of no help and I ended up having to call a taxi to come pick me up). Glad I went but really wish there was more to see.

A vibrant, warmhearted little village in the heart of Cape Town..... The Neighbor Goods Market at Old Biscuit Mill is a great place to spend a Saturday morning, having brunch - treating your taste buds to some exquisite, sensory overloading tastes. It is every Saturday morning from 9h00 - 14h00. It's just a short drive from the city center. The atmosphere are warm and vibrant. The market serves fresh and locally produced, regional organic foods, hand-made cheeses, olives, home-made salami, sushi, tacos, crepes, smoothies, wine & luxury beers. I specially enjoyed the pomegranate smoothies and lamb & tuna burgers! There are plenty of large communal tables where you can enjoy your treats, unwrap your new purchases or just enjoy a bit of people-watching. Live music, the fresh flowers and herbs add to a vibrant atmosphere. There are also little shops selling, beads, jewelry, clothes etc. A ATM bank machine for drawing money are conveniently located. An excellent way to spend a Saturday morning!
